questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant presented with developmental delay, seizures, and eczema. His urine has a characteristic tom cat urine smell, and blood analysis indicated organic acidemia. The patient is advised to take biotin supplementation to treat which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple carboxylase/biotinidase deficiency

  • Autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in holocarboxylase synthase or biotinidase deficiency.
  • These are required to generate the active form of biotin required for carboxylation reactions (see fig).

Clinical features:-

  • Metabolic ketoacidosis
  • Diffuse rash
  • Alopecia
  • Seizures
  • Intellectual disability

Option B: Keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme for branch-chain dehydrogenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-keto acids derived from leucine, isoleucine, and valine, three essential amino acids.

Option C: Transketolase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of transketolase.

Option D: Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the dermatologic clinic to evaluate his skin lesions. His medical history is consistent with atopic asthma and neurofibromatosis 1. On examination, the following spots in the axillary region of the patient are seen:



Which of the following sign best describe the above-mentioned skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Crowe’s sign 

  • This patient with a history of neurofibromatosis-1 most likely has freckling of the axillary area. The presence of freckling in neurofibromatosis is known as Crowe's sign.
  • NF1, previously known as von Recklinghausen disease, is the most common type of neurofibroma.
  • The hallmarks of NF1 are multiple café-au-lait macules and neurofibromas. The condition is called "segmental NF1" when clinical features are limited to one area of the body due to somatic mosaicism of a pathogenic variant in the neurofibromin 1 (NF1) gene.
  • Freckling in the axillary or inguinal regions (Crowe sign) is a diagnostic criterion distinct from café-au-lait macules.
  • The freckles are smaller in size than café-au-lait macules, appear later, and usually occur in clusters in skin folds rather than randomly.
  • Freckling occurs mostly in regions of skin apposition, especially the axillary and inguinal areas. Freckling usually is not apparent at birth but often appears by age three to five years, typically first in the inguinal region.
  • Freckling may also occur in other intertriginous areas, such as the neckline or inframammary areas in women. In some individuals, freckling may occur elsewhere on the body and may be diffuse.
  • One or two small freckles or the presence of a café-au-lait macule in a skin fold does not fulfill the diagnostic criterion for skin fold freckling.

Option A: Button hole sign

  • In type 1 neurofibromatosis (von Recklinghausen's disease), neurofibromas can be invaginated with the tip of the index finger back into the subcutis and again reappear after the release of pressure.
  • This is known as the buttonhole sign.
  • Other conditions where one can find positive buttonhole signs are anetoderma and dermatofibroma.

Option B: Osler’s sign

  • Osler’s sign refers to scleral discoloration.
  • This is seen in metabolic disorders, most likely in Alkaptonuria.
  • This is not seen in neurofibromatosis-1.

Option C: Darier’s sign

  • Darier's sign refers to whealing, erythema, and pruritus (urtication), elicited after the mechanical stimulus to a lesion owing to an increase in the number of mast cells in the dermis.
  • It is seen in mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of difficulty swallowing and heartburn for 1 year. He also complains of progressively worsening difficulty swallowing liquids and solids; sometimes, the food is regurgitated. An upper GI endoscopy is done, which shows dilated oesophagus body and no peristalsis. Consequently, a barium swallow is done, and the result is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Achalasia cardia

  • The radiograph shows a bird's beak appearance (dilated oesophagus with narrowing of the distal end due to failure of the lower oesophageal sphincter to relax), the most likely explanation is achalasia.
  • As a patient is young and has no significant weight loss along with this result, barium swallow achalasia is more likely than oesophageal carcinoma.

Option B: Carcinoma oesophagus

  • More likely in elderly patients with significant weight loss and complaining of more dysphagia to first solids and then progressing to dysphagia to liquids as well.
  • Rat tail appearance: irregular mucosal narrowing (shouldering) on the distal part of the oesophagus.

Option C: Hiatus hernia

  • Displacement through oesophageal hiatus of GE junction or other stomach parts into the thoracic cavity.
  • Hiatal hernia is of 2 important types:
    • Sliding hiatal hernia: GE junction is pulled into the thorax.
    • Rolling hiatal hernia: GE junction is normally placed, but the fundus of the stomach is pulled up. Much higher risk of Volvulus.
  • Retrocardiac air-fluid level is typical for hiatal hernia.
  • Investigation of choice for hiatal hernia/Best Investigation: CECT + oral contrast (Iohexol).
  • To determine obstruction/volvulus: oral contrast is given.
  • CECT provides a 3D image of the part of the stomach herniating into the thorax.

Option D: Diffuse oesophageal spasm

  • Caused by Tertiary contraction / spasmodic contraction → Spasm →Esophageal blood supply cut off – Ischemia → Left-sided chest pain/ pain in the lower part of the neck (mistaken as angina).
  • Clinical features: Chest pain, dysphagia.
  • IOC – Manometry.
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • The amplitude of contraction > 120 mm Hg.
    • Duration of contraction > 2.5 sec.
  • On Barium Swallow:
    • Corkscrew appearance.
    • Pseudo diverticula appearance.
    • Rosary bead appearance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with seizures associated with high-grade fever for the last ten days. The patient is a known case of diabetes mellitus type 2. On examination, the patient appears confused and disoriented to time and place. There is no history of trauma. The contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the brain, showed a walled, well-defined, ring-enhancing mass.. Which of the following statements is true regarding central nervous system infections?

choices.text: Cranial osteomyelitis most frequently arises from the spread of bacteria through the bloodstream
Subdural empyema is ordinarily treated by administration of antibiotics without the need for surgical drainage
Most common site of brain abscess due to hematogenous spread is the temporal lobe.
A bacterial brain abscess is accompanied by systemic signs of infection, such as fever or leukocytosis

questions.solution:
Option C: Bacterial meningitis may lead to the development of hydrocephalus

  • Based on the symptoms of seizures, fever associated with an altered state of consciousness, and ring-enhancing mass on a CT scan, the most likely diagnosis is brain abscess.
  • One of the complications that can occur due to bacterial meningitis is hydrocephalus, usually due to the obliteration of subarachnoid spaces and interference with CSF reabsorption.
  • Intracranial abscesses are life-threatening infections. They include brain abscesses and subdural or extradural empyema.
  • Clinical symptoms and signs:
    • Headache
    • Focal neurologic deficits
    • Fever
    • Seizures
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Papilledema
    • Confusion and drowsiness
    • Neck rigidity
  • Investigations:
    • Routine investigations in patients with brain abscesses include the following:
      • CBC count
      • Serum C-reactive protein
      • Blood cultures
      • CT scan with contrast provides a rapid means of detecting the size, number, and location of abscesses, and it has become the investigation of choice.
      • MRI is also a reliable diagnostic method in diagnosing brain abscesses. It allows for accurate diagnosis and excellent follow-up of the lesions.
  • Treatment:
    • Once an abscess has formed, surgical excision or drainage combined with antibiotics according to the organism for 4 to 8 weeks remains the treatment of choice.
    • Prophylactic anticonvulsants are usually indicated.

Option A: Cranial osteomyelitis most frequently arises from the spread of bacteria through the bloodstream

  • Cranial osteomyelitis frequently occurs via direct spread from an infected paranasal sinus.
  • The spread from an infected paranasal sinus is more frequent than the hematogenous spread.

Option B: Subdural empyema is ordinarily treated by administration of antibiotics without the need for surgical drainage

  • Surgical drainage combined with antibiotics is the treatment of choice for subdural empyema.
  • It is not solely treated with antibiotics.

Option D: A bacterial brain abscess is accompanied by systemic signs of infection such as fever or leukocytosis

  • Systemic signs of infection do not ordinarily accompany a brain abscess. 
  • These can be present if the patient also has meningitis or an active infection elsewhere.

questions.text: Allowing equal interview time to cases and controls can reduce which of the following bias?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Interviewer bias

  • Investigatory bias: Interviewer bias, selection bias, misclassification bias.
    • Allowing equal time for interviews can take care of interviewer bias to some extent.
    • Interviewer bias happens in case-control studies where the interviewer knows about the disease status of the person and probes more for exposure amongst cases as compared to controls.

Option A: Berkesonian bias

  • Berksonian Bias is due to different rates of hospital admission.
  • Suppose we need to study cancer patients in the hospital.
  • But the investigator was unaware that the hospital has no oncology department.

Option B: Recall bias

  • Recall Bias is seen in a case-control study.
  • The study subject is not able to remember his history properly, leading to a mistaken estimate of the odds ratio.

Option C: Selection bias

  • Investigator bias is where a person who is conducting the study, do some errors.
    • Interviewer bias
    • Selection bias
    • Misclassification bias
  • Removal of Selection bias can be done by: Randomisation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 65-year-old lady is hospitalized for the treatment of cervical spondylosis. The laboratory work-up shows her serum calcium level of 12.5mg/dl. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Her only medications are a daily multivitamin and acetaminophen, which she took daily for hip pain two  months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. She seems a bit confused but oriented in time, place, and person. Laboratory studies show a haemoglobin concentration of 13.1 g/dl, a serum creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dl, and serum phosphate of 2.2mg/dl. Which is the first investigation to be ordered on this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Serum PTH

  • In an asymptomatic patient with hypercalcemia, the leading cause happens to be hyperparathyroidism.
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes increased calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and kidneys.
  • Furthermore, it causes urinary loss of phosphate, which explains low phosphate in the patient. (Normal phosphate=2.5-4.5mEq/dl).
  • PTH assay is the first investigation to be performed in this case.

Option B: PTH-RP levels

  • In symptomatic hypercalcemia, cancer is the leading cause.
  • PTH-RP is a protein produced by malignant cells, performing the same function as parathyroid hormone.
  • Production of PTHrP is the most common cause of hypercalcemia or malignancy, such as squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs and renal cell carcinoma.
  • But then, hypercalcemia due to malignancy is associated with features such as nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, bone pain, arthralgias, myalgias, constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.
  • None of these features is mentioned in the clinical vignette.

Option C: Serum electrophoresis for M spike

  • Serum electrophoresis for M spike is an investigation for diagnostic work-up of multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a malignancy of white blood cells characterized by the proliferation of B lymphocytes and their associated proteins (antibodies).
  • It manifests as impaired kidney function, hypercalcemia, anaemia, and lytic bone lesions.

Option D: Vitamin D3 levels

  • Hypervitaminosis D is a rare cause of hypercalcemia caused by excessive ingestion of vitamin D.
  • There is no history of taking excessive vitamin D in the clinical vignette.
  • Furthermore, both the calcium and phosphate are elevated in hypervitaminosis D, which is not the case in this patient.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to sudden loss of consciousness for about 45 minutes. He has a similar history of episodes of lightheadedness associated with diaphoresis, palpitation, tremulousness, and feeling of impending doom in the past, off and on for the last 3 years, which were relieved by eating something or taking glucose water orally. He has no other significant medical history. However, his father was diagnosed with a pituitary tumour some years back. Initial investigations are done. The physician suspects this is a case of insulinoma. Which of the following is the most sensitive imaging modality of choice for this diagnosis?

choices.text: Computed tomography scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Option D: Endoscopic ultrasound.

  • The pancreas is an abdominal organ derived from the endoderm.
  • It functions as both an exocrine and an endocrine gland.
  • The exocrine function of the pancreas includes the secretion of various enzymes that aid in the digestion of proteins, carbohydrates, and fats. Exocrine means that the secretions are drained through a duct, not via blood.
  • These enzymes are chymotrypsin, trypsinogen, elastase, carboxypeptidases, alpha-amylase, and lipases. It also secretes bicarbonate which helps neutralize the acid content in the intestine due to acidic stomach secretions. These enzymes drain through the pancreatic duct into the second part of the duodenum via the ampulla of Vater.
  • Pancreas also acts as an endocrine gland. Endocrine means that the secretions drain directly into the blood. It secretes various hormones into the vascular system.
  • The pancreas is made up of acini and a ductal system. Acini are clusters of cells called islet cells that produce secretory substances. The acini are made up of the following types of cells.
    • Beta cells produce insulin. Insulin is an anabolic peptide hormone. Its levels rise in the body after a meal, facilitating the entry of glucose into skeletal muscles and adipose tissues. It also increases glycogen synthesis and storage, triglyceride synthesis, protein synthesis, and cellular uptake of potassium and amino acids. It decreases glucagon secretion and lipolysis in adipose tissues.
    • Alpha cells produce a peptide hormone known as glucagon. Glucagon is a catabolic hormone that promotes glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, lipolysis and ketogenesis. It increases blood glucose levels during fasting states.
    • D cells of the pancreas secrete a hormone called somatostatin. Somatostatin is also released by gastrointestinal mucosa and decreases the secretion of many hormones, including insulin and glucagon. It reduces gastric acid, pepsinogen secretion, gallbladder contraction, and pancreatic and small intestinal secretions.
  • Pancreatic islet cell tumors include insulinoma, glucagonoma, and somatostatinoma. Pancreatic tumors are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasias(MEN), which are autosomal dominant syndromes of 3 types. MEN 1 is a triad of pituitary tumors, pancreatic endocrine tumors, and parathyroid adenomas. These are associated with a mutation of menin, a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 11.
  • Insulinoma is a benign tumour of beta cells of the pancreas. It causes overproduction of insulin which can cause signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia due to:
    • Sympathetic activation leads to palpitations, diaphoresis, anxiety, high blood pressure, and tremors.
    • Neuroglycopenic symptoms: lethargy, headache, visual disturbances, confusion, seizures, and coma.
    • Whipple’s triad can be seen, which includes: low blood glucose (<50mg/dl), symptoms of hypoglycemia, and relief of symptoms after normalization of plasma glucose levels.
  • Diagnostic evaluations for insulinoma can include:
    • Seventy-two hours fast: Patient will become hypoglycemic. Usually, there is a decrease in insulin levels as hypoglycemia develops. In a patient with insulinoma, insulin levels will be high despite a blood glucose drop.
    • Elevated C-peptide levels:  Insulin is synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the pancreatic beta cells as proinsulin, stored in secretory granules.
      • Cleavage of proinsulin yields insulin and c-peptide, which are released by endocytosis.
      • Using sulfonylureas (an oral hypoglycemic drug) and an insulinoma increases the blood c-peptide levels, while exogenous insulin does not. C-peptide levels differentiate between factitious insulin use and insulinoma or sulfonylurea in a hypoglycemic patient.

Diagnosis

Insulin Levels

Glucose Levels

C-peptide levels

Proinsulin levels

Insulinoma
  • High
  • Low
  • High
  • High

Factitious insulin
  • Very high
  • Low
  • Low
  • Low

Sulfonylurea abuse
  • High
  • Low
  • High
  • Normal
  • Imaging techniques for the diagnosis of  pancreatic endocrine tumors include:
    • Endoscopic ultrasound has the highest sensitivity of 77-100%. It can localize insulinomas. Endoscopic ultrasound can pick up an insulinoma even less than 1.5 cm in size.
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy can also be used, but it is less available in most countries.
    • A helical computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen has a sensitivity of 82-94% in diagnosing pancreatic endocrine tumors.
    • Gadolinium magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) sensitivity is 85% in detecting pancreatic endocrine tumors.
    • Calcium-stimulated angiography can be used to localize the tumor if the above tests are negative. The intra-arterial calcium test also allows differentiation of the cause of hypoglycaemia and indicates whether it is due to an insulinoma or a nesidioblastosis. Nesidioblastosis, diffuse hyperplasia of pancreatic islet cells, presents as hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia with unremarkable cross-sectional imaging and endoscopic ultrasound. Distal pancreatectomy can be done for nesidioblastosis.
  • Insulinomas are treated by surgical resection.

Option A: Abdominal ultrasound.

  • Abdominal ultrasound is not as sensitive as endoscopic ultrasound for detecting pancreatic endocrine tumors.

Option B: Computed tomography scan of the abdomen.

  • CT scan of the abdomen has a sensitivity of 82-94%, while endoscopic ultrasound has a sensitivity of 77-100% in detecting pancreatic endocrine tumours such as insulinoma.

Option C: Somatostatin receptor scan.

  • Somatostatin receptor scan is not a widely available modality, so endoscopic ultrasound is preferred over it in detecting an insulinoma.

questions.text: A community medicine intern during his viva was asked about the criteria of At Risk infants. All of the following are the criteria for identifying ‘At Risk’ infants, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Birth weight less than 2.8 kg

  • The number of infants (and children 1- 5 years of age) in a community, or attending a child health clinic, maybe so large that it may not be possible to give sufficient time and attention to all of them.
  • It is, therefore, necessary to identify those "at-risk" and give them special intensive care, because these " at-risk" babies contribute so mainly to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.
    Birth weight less than 2.5 kg is a criterion for At-risk infants.

Option B: Birth order 5 or more

  • Birth order 5 or more is a criterion for At-risk infants.

Option C: Protein-energy malnutrition

  • Malnutrition is a broad term that encompasses undernutrition (protein energy malnutrition), overnutrition (obesity), and specific nutrient deficiencies.
  • Protein-energy malnutrition shows an iceberg phenomenon.
  • Only the severe form of protein energy malnutrition (kwashiorkor and marasmus) comes to medical attention.
  • Significantly more, mild to moderate cases of protein energy malnutrition remains undiagnosed (below the iceberg).

Option D: Working mother

  • Children of working moms are prone to develop disruptive behavioral issues.
  • Before their first birthday, children of moms who worked part-time experienced fewer disruptive behavioral issues than children of mothers who worked full-time. At age three and during first grade, there was a noticeable increase in the likelihood of behavioral issues.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, Gravida 2 Para 1, at 15 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal visit. She has a history of frequent episodes of Generalised tonic-clonic seizures for 8 years and is currently on maintenance with antiepileptic drugs. She is currently concerned if she can continue the same pharmacotherapy for her seizures throughout her pregnancy. Based on the patient’s history, which of the following antiepileptics is the safest for Generalised tonic-clonic seizures?
questions.solution:
Option C: Levetiracetam

  • Safest Antiepileptic drug in pregnancy: Levetiracetam (least teratogenic) > Lamotrigine.
  • Levetiracetam is increasingly considered the initial drug of choice for women of childbearing age with epilepsies having mixed seizure types.

Option A: Lamotrigine

  • There have been reports of decreased lamotrigine plasma levels during pregnancy with a potential risk of loss of seizure control.
  • Lamotrigine serum concentrations in the woman should be monitored before, during, and after pregnancy, including shortly after birth.

Option B: Vigabatrin

  • Vigabatrin should only be used during pregnancy, where the benefits of treatment are considered to compensate for any potential risks.

Option D: Valproate

  • Valproic acid is effective in absence, myoclonic, and atonic seizures.
  • Valproate is highly teratogenic. 
  • It causes congenital malformations and neurodevelopmental disorders.

questions.text: A 33-yr-old male presented to your clinic with numbness from the lower trunk to the distal lower extremities, anteriorly and posteriorly, bilaterally equal. On examination, reflexes were hyperactive, and hypoesthesia was present with the neurological pinwheel exam. Initial investigations were done. A probable diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis was made. Which of the following tests is not useful for evaluating the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Electronystagmogram

  • Electronystomogram is not used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
  • It is used in patients with problems of vertigo and balance problems.
  • It helps in the diagnosis of Meniere's disease

Investigation of multiple sclerosis

  • Evoked Potentials 
  • E.P. marked delay in the latency of a specific E.P. component (as opposed to a reduced amplitude or distorted wave shape) is suggestive of demyelination
  • Cerebrospinal Fluid 
  • CSF abnormalities found in M.S. include a mononuclear cell pleocytosis
  • Increased level of intrathecally synthesized IgG.Oligoclonal bands
  • The total CSF protein is usually normal or mildly elevated.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging 
  • Lesions are frequently oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface, corresponding to the pathologic pattern of perivenous demyelination (Dawson's fingers).
  • Lesions are multifocal within the brain, brainstem, and spinal cord.

​​​​​​​

  • MRI figure showing periventricular plaques characteristic of multiple sclerosis

Option A: Lumbar puncture

  • Lumbar puncture is done for CSF, which is crucial for diagnosis as it shows oligoclonal bands characteristic of M.S.

Option B: Gadolinium-enhanced MRI

  • MRI is the first line of investigation for M.S., and it shows periventricular plaques

​​​​​​​Option C: Visual evoked potential

  • Visual evoked potential can help in diagnosing M.S. as it can detect the abnormalities in the nerves

questions.text: Which of the following is not a chest x-ray finding in a case of Staphylococcus pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hilar lymphadenopathy

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia.
  • It is mostly seen in patients post-influenza, i.e. the disease is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • It affects young and elderly individuals giving it a bimodal distribution.
  • Younger children are usually affected, especially those with malnutrition or previous skin infection.
  • In addition to respiratory symptoms like cough and signs of respiratory distress (nasal flaring, chest indrawing), children may also have gastrointestinal signs like diarrhea, vomiting, and painful abdominal distention.
  • 80% of patients infected with staphylococcus aureus develop pleural effusion and empyema.
  • The radiographic finding of staphylococcus aureus depends upon the stage of the disease.
  • The chest x-ray may show multiple consolidations, which are very common and are associated with pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  • Pneumatoceles (air-filled cavities) are seen and are present for a long period in those patients who remain asymptomatic for a prolonged period.

  • The above x-ray demonstrates right sides pneumonia, with extensive consolidation (white shadow) and a large rounded pneumatocele.
  • Hilar lymphadenopathy, which is the bilateral enlargement of the lymph nodes of the pulmonary hila, can occur as a result of sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, etc.

Option A: Pneumatocele

  • Pneumatoceles are thin-walled air cysts that are found in intrapulmonary parenchyma.
  • It is found in staphylococcal pneumonia.
  • It can also be found after trauma, burn, or chemical injury to the lung.

Option C: Empyema

  • Empyema is pus in the pleural space.
  • There are many causes of empyema, including bacterial pneumonia.

Option D: Absent air bronchogram

  • It is the phenomenon of air-filled bronchi.
  • It is not seen in staphylococcus pneumonia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male who had recently undergone surgery for gastric cancer presents to the emergency department with complaints of dyspnoea and mental changes that occurred two hours prior presentation. The patient's oxygen saturation in room air was 88% , and it is increased to 94% after supplementation with an oxygen mask. His blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and his body temperature is 37.8°C. His family claims that there is no history of trauma or chronic respiratory disease. If this is a case of air embolism, what will be your next step in the investigation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Doppler study

  • When one or more air bubbles enter a vein or artery and block it off, this is known as an air embolism, which is sometimes referred to as a gas embolism.
  • A venous air embolism is a condition that occurs when a bubble of air travels through the veins.
  • An arterial air embolism is a condition that occurs when a gas bubble travels through the arterial system.
  • These air bubbles have the potential to go to your brain, heart, or lungs, which could result in a heart attack, stroke, or failure of your respiratory system.
  • If the veins or arteries are exposed, and the pressure in the body makes it possible for air to enter them, a person may experience an air embolism.

This may occur in a variety of ways, including the following:

  • Injections and operations are both options.
  • Lung trauma
  • Injuries caused by explosions and blasts
  • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):- has the highest sensitivity for detecting the presence of air in the right ventricular outflow tract or major pulmonary veins.
  • It can detect as little as 0.02 mL/kg of air administered by bolus injection.
  • It also has the added advantage of identifying Paradoxical Air Embolism (PAE)
  • Doppler allows audible detection of venous air embolism (VAE).
  • Overall highest sensitivity : T.E.E > Doppler > E.T N2> E.T CO2

Option A: Decreased End-tidal CO2

  • The primary investigation of choice, in case of air embolism, is transesophageal echocardiography and doppler study, not decreased ETCO2.

Option B: Decreased End-tidal N2

  • The primary investigation of choice, in case of air embolism, is transesophageal echocardiography and doppler study, not decreased ETN2.

Option D: Ultrasound

  • The primary investigation of choice, in case of air embolism, is transesophageal echocardiography and doppler study, not ultrasound.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of headache and sometimes blurry vision. He also had one episode of passing out. MRI is done, which is suggestive of medulloblastoma. A biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following are histological features of medulloblastoma, as shown in the diagram?

choices.text: Normal amount of cytoplasm and normochromatic nuclei

questions.solution:
Option C: Homer-Wright rosettes

  • Medulloblastoma is very densely cellular, with sheets of anaplastic cells.
  • Individual tumour cells are small, with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that frequently are elongated or crescent-shaped.
  • Mitoses are abundant, and markers of cellular proliferation, such as Ki-67, are detected in a high percentage of the cells. The tumour may express neuronal (neurosecretory) granules, form Homer-Wright rosettes and express glial markers (e.g., GFAP)

Option A: Small round pink cells

  • Medulloblastoma contains small round blue cells.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B: Normal amount of cytoplasm and normochromic nuclei

  • Cells of medulloblastoma contain a small amount of cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D: "Chicken-wire" capillaries

  • Oligodendroglioma typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 36-year-old male worker visits the clinic complaining of lesions affecting his groin region for the last five days. He has been diagnosed with atopic dermatitis since childhood and has used topical corticosteroids frequently for its management. On examination, annular, scaly diffuse plaques are found in the groin. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tinea Incognito

This patient with itchy, annular, and scaly diffuse plaques affecting the groin with a history of topical corticosteroid use most likely suffers from tinea incognito.

  • Prolonged topical corticosteroids suppress the local immune response and allow the fungus to grow readily.
  • The diagnosis is made clinically based on the annular and scaly lesion with associated itchiness. However, it can be confirmed via visualization of characteristic branching hyphae on KOH preparation.
  • Management options include cessation of all topical corticosteroids and appropriate antifungal therapy.

Option A: Erythema Annulare Centrifugum

  • It is a chronic, reactive skin condition known as erythema annulare centrifugum (EAC) that causes arcuate or annular, erythematous patches or thin plaques that commonly have scale along the inner section of the lesions' advancing border.

Option B: Granuloma Annulare 

  • It is characterized by an annular lesion that is classically non-scaly.
  • The lesions commonly manifest on the extremities, particularly dorsal hands and feet.

Option C: Annular lichen Planus

  • It is classically associated with lesions on mucosal areas and not groins.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a four-week history of fatigue, weight loss, fever and night sweats. He has also noticed multiple painless lumps in his neck and axilla that have increased in size since he first noticed them 4 weeks ago. His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes, which are well-controlled with medication. On physical examination re numerous enlarged cervical and supraclavicular lymph nodes are seen. Biopsy shows lymphocytes that stain positive for CD20. Genetic analysis reveals a BCL6 mutation on chromosome 3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diffuse large b-cell lymphoma

  • B-symptoms, e.g., fever, fatigue and night sweat with weight loss, lymphadenopathy and a BCL6 mutation in CD20-positive lymphocytes, are features that suggest diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
  • DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults. 20% are associated with Follicular lymphoma (a t (14;18) BCL2 translocation.) Pathogenesis involves overexpression of BCL-6 (30%) and alterations in BCL2, causing a block in apoptosis, allowing continued division and growth of B-cells.
  • This mature B-cell tumour expresses pan-B cell markers CD19 and CD20, with variable expression of germinal centre B-cell markers (e.g., CD10 and BCL6).
  • The cells in DLBCL are relatively large (4 to 5 times the diameter of small lymphocytes) and exhibit a diffuse growth pattern that obliterates the underlying architecture. With 2 to 3 nucleoli, the nuclear shape is variable and vesicular; the cytoplasm is moderately abundant and can be pale or basophilic.

Option A: Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL)

  • It is a T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is associated with infection with the human T lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1).
  • HTLV-1 is endemic in certain parts of the world, e.g., Japan and the Caribbean and is transmitted via body fluids, e.g., IV drug use.
  • It has widespread lymph node involvement with extranodal disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, skin and bones, causing lytic lesions and hypercalcemia.
  • Neoplastic lymphocytes have multilobulated nuclei with a cloverleaf appearance.

Option B: Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma

  • Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is a histologic subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • This neoplasm contains a heterogenous cellular infiltrate consisting of Reed Sternberg cells surrounded by various cell types, e.g., eosinophils, plasma cells, lymphocytes and histiocytes.
  • Reed Sternberg cells don’t express CD20 and CD45 (markers normally seen on B cells). Instead, they test positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option D: Follicular lymphoma

  • An indolent B cell NHL caused by t (14;18). BCL2 on chromosome 18 is translocated to chromosome 14, causing over-expression of BCL2 and inhibiting apoptosis.
  • Presents with waxing and waning painless lymphadenopathy usually associated with infection with hepatitis C.
  • Follicular lymphoma may progress to DLBCL.

questions.text: A patient presents to the physician with the complaint of a painless area of induration on the lower limbs. It is reported that it began as a firm, painless nodule in the skin several weeks ago. Examination reveals a necrotic ulcer with undermined edges on lower limbs, extending to deeper tissues destroying nerves, blood vessels, and muscles. A direct smear is taken from the necrotic base of the ulcer and stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain to reveal clumps of acid-fast bacilli under a microscope. A skin test with burulin gives a positive response. This type of ulcer is caused by?
questions.solution:
Option B: M. Ulcerans

  • Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.
  • Often starts with painless swelling (nodule).
  • Large painless induration area (plaque) or diffuse painless swelling of legs, arms, or face (edema).
  • In later stages, the lesion presents with undermined edges showing necrosis with minimal inflammation.
  • Ulcers may be very deep and involve muscle and bone.
  • This disease can progress with no pain and fever.
  • A skin test with burulin gives a positive response.
  • Treat with antibiotics (rifampicin + clarithromycin).

Buruli ulcer. Top-left is an early ulcer. Top-right is a larger ulcer of the lower arm and wrist. The bottom one is a large ulcer on the thigh.

Option A: Mycobacterium Marinum

  • Causes Swimming Pool Granuloma.
  • Cutaneous granuloma in tropical fish enthusiasts.
  • Aka, Fish Tank Granuloma.
  • Linear lesions along lymphatics seen over extremities aka Sporotrichoid spread.
  • Treat with Minocycline or isoniazid, rifampin, or ethambutol.

Option C: Mycobacterium avium intercellulare.

  • Involve GI and respiratory tract.
  • Transmission is by respiratory droplet or ingestion.
  • HIV patients with cancer and Chronic lung diseases.
  • Treat HIV positive <50 CD4+ with macrolides + ethambutol.

Option D: Mycobacterium Tuberculosis

  • 20% Acid fast.
  • Acid fastness is the ability to resist decolorization. It depends on mycolic acid content.
  • Virulence factors include Cord factor, Lipo arabino mannan, and HSP (Heat Shock Protein).
  • Mode of transmission respiratory droplets.
  • Chronic respiratory granulomatous infection (pulmonary TB).
  • Caseous granuloma is often discovered on routine CXR.
  • Pathogenesis: Human (Pulmonary TB), milk source.
  • Treatment with RIPE therapy (RIFAMPIN, ISONIAZID, PYRAZINAMIDE, ETHAMBUTOL)
  • Left untreated can complicate the multisystem disease.

questions.text: A 48- year-old male presents to OPD with severe pain in his big toe, with multiple such episodes for the past 5 years. He has taken certain painkillers. He has been hypertensive for the last 3 years. He has been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease for the past 6 months. His lab investigations reveal hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and raised creatinine. Which of the following drugs is the best for treating the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Febuxostat

  • The given clinical scenario points towards over-producer in chronic gout with kidney impairment.
  • Febuxostat is administered orally and is metabolized mainly in the liver.
  • Therefore, febuxostat can be used in patients with renal impairment without dosage adjustment.
  • Febuxostat, a non-purine selective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, is a potential alternative to allopurinol in patients with gout.
  • Gout is a common form of monoarticular arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals.
  • It usually affects the big toe (podagra), ankle, wrist and finger joints.
  • Gout can only be diagnosed during a flare when a joint is hot, swollen, and painful.
  • The lab value of uric acid is important in diagnosis.
  • Other investigations are;
    • X-ray of the affected joint.
    • Synovial fluid examination. It shows negatively birefringent crystals
  • Treatment includes lifestyle modifications like;
    • Weight loss.​​​​​​​
    • Limiting alcohol consumption.
    • Eating less purine-rich food
  • Drugs like NSAIDs, steroids, Colchicine for acute attacks, allopurinol, and febuxostat for chronic gout.

Option A: Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is excreted mainly through the kidneys.
  • As the person is already suffering from chronic kidney disease, it is not the drug of choice.

Option C: Uricase

  • Uricase is a unique drug acting on urate, catalyzing the oxidation of urate into hydrogen peroxide and 5-hydroxyisourate that spontaneously decomposes to allantoin and carbon dioxide.
  • Allantoin is plasma soluble and easily excreted through the kidney.

Option D: Benzbromarone

  • It is a uricosuric drug non-competitive xanthine oxidase inhibitor.
  • It is a possible cause of acute kidney injury and urolithiasis

questions.text: A 1st-year resident is explaining the anatomy and physiology of ureters. He mentions that the ureters pass obliquely through the bladder wall. Although there are no ureteral sphincters, the oblique passage tends to keep the ureters closed except during peristaltic waves, preventing urine reflux from the bladder. Ureteric peristalsis is triggered by?

choices.text: Pacemaker activity of the smooth muscle cells in the renal pelvis

questions.solution:
Option D: Pacemaker activity of the smooth muscle cells in the renal pelvis

  • Ureteric peristalsis has long been triggered by pacemaker atypical smooth muscle cells (SMC) located in the proximal regions of the renal pelvis.
  • Ureteric peristaltic contractions occur 1 to 5 times per minute.
  • There are specialized smooth muscle pacemaker cells in the region of the renal pelvis; the contractions arise here.
  • Ureteral peristalsis is triggered by calcium-dependent pacemaker cells in ureteral smooth muscle.
  • With obstruction, ureteral peristalsis increases in amplitude and frequency.
  • Peristalsis decreases with chronic obstruction and may cease entirely with concurrent infection.
  • Immediately after the obstruction is relieved, peristalsis slowly normalizes.

Option A: Sympathetic innervation

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation.

Option B: Parasympathetic innervation

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation.

Option C: Both (A) and (B)

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation

questions.text: After family planning education in a rural PHC, a 29-year-old female presented to the hospital for sterilization, all of the following are the Guidelines for Sterilization except?

choices.text: The age of the husband should not ordinarily be less than 25 years, nor should it be over 50 years
The age of the wife should not be less than 22 years or more than 45 years
The motivated couple must have 3 living children at the time of operation
If the couple has 3 or more living children, the lower limit of the age of the husband or wife may be relaxed at the discretion of the operating surgeon

questions.solution:
Option C: The motivated couple must have 3 living children at the time of operation

  • It is a false statement; the motivated couple must have at least 1 living child at the time of surgery.
  • All other statements are true regarding the Guidelines for Sterilization.

Option A: The age of the husband should not ordinarily be less than 25 years, nor should it be over 50 years

  • The husband's age should not be < 25 years or> 50 years.

Option B: The age of the wife should not be less than 22 years or more than 45 years

  • The wife's age should not be < 22 years or > 45 years.

Option D: If the couple has 3 or more living children, the lower limit of the age of the husband or wife may be relaxed at the discretion of the operating surgeon

  • If the couple has ≥3 living children, the lower age limit of the husband/wife may be relaxed at the discretion of the operating surgeon.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl comes to the orthopaedic OPD complaining of painful swelling above the left knee joint. The swelling was initially small but increased rapidly to a large size. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. She also has a history of weight loss and anorexia. On local examination, there is an ill-defined diffuse swelling extending from the lower pole of the patella to the supracondylar region of the femur. An X-ray is performed, and the image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Osteosarcoma

The x-ray image shows a 'Sunburst appearance' around the knee that most likely suggests osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma:

  • It is a malignant tumor of the bone that most commonly affects adolescents and young adults.
  • It primarily affects the long bones of legs and sometimes arms but can involve any bones.
  • Symptoms:
  • Bone pain
  • A mass that can be felt through the skin
  • Swelling and erythema at the affected site
  • Limited movement (when it affects a joint)
  • Limping (when it affects the lower limb)
  • Intense pain with arms lifting (If it affects the arm).

Diagnosis:

  • X-ray: 'Sunburst appearance' of the affected bone due to the new bone being laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

Option A: Chondrosarcoma

  • It is a rare bone cancer that involves cartilage.
  • X-ray finding of chondrosarcoma: "Speckled" calcification
  • Occurs commonly in the 30 to 60 years of age group.
  • Treatment depends upon the behavior of the tumor. Amputation is necessary for most tumors. In some low-grade tumors, after proper assessment, wide resection of the tumor is done (limb-saving surgery).
  • .

Option B: Metastatic tumor in the bone

  • The x-ray shows a sunburst appearance consistent with osteosarcoma, a primary bone tumor.
  • Metastatic bone tumors are mostly osteolytic; some are osteoblastic in the x-ray.

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma

  • It is the second most common primary malignant tumor of bone.
  • The classic x-ray finding is the "onion skin" appearance.
  • Age group: 10 to 15 years, occasionally up to 30 years.
  • Bones: Tibia, femur, also flat bones – ileum, scapula, ribs.

questions.text: Which compensatory changes occur when a person moves from a supine position to a standing position?
questions.solution:
Option B: Increased contractility

  • There is a decreased venous return to the heart, decreased cardiac output and decreased arterial pressure when a person stands up or in a standing position because in this posture, the blood pools in the leg veins.
  • The baroreceptors detect a decrease in arterial pressure, and the vasomotor centre is activated to increase sympathetic outflow and decrease parasympathetic outflow.
  • There is an increase in heart rate (resulting in a decreased PR interval), contractility and total peripheral resistance (TPR).
  • Because both heart rate and contractility increase, cardiac output will increase towards normal.

Option A: Decreased heart rate

  • When the patient stands from a sitting position, the baroreceptors detect the decrease in arterial pressure.
  • This causes a compensatory increase in the heart rate of the patient.

Option C: Decreased total peripheral resistance (TPR)

  • When the patient stands from a sitting or lying position, the baroreceptors detect a decrease in arterial pressure, and the vasomotor centre is activated to increase sympathetic outflow and decrease parasympathetic outflow.
  • There is an increase in heart rate (resulting in a decreased PR interval), contractility and total peripheral resistance (TPR).

Option D: Decreased cardiac output

  • When the patient stands from a sitting position, both heart rate and contractility are increased.
  • So, cardiac output will increase towards normal.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty breathing, sweating, racing heart, and nausea for the last 30 minutes. He has a history of panic disorder in the past. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Arterial blood gases of the patient show the following results:


	pH= 7.52
	PaCO2= 20 mmHg
	HCO3-= 22 mEq/L


Which of the following condition would be found in this patient?

choices.text: He has decreased ionized Ca+2 in the blood
He has decreased total Ca+2 in the blood
He has an acid-base disorder caused by the overproduction of fixed acid

questions.solution:
Option B: He has decreased ionized Ca+2 in the blood

  • First, we should diagnose the acid-base disorder.
  • The patient is hyperventilating while having a panic attack. It leads to excess carbon dioxide excretion.
  • Alkaline pH, low PaCO2, and normal HCO3- are in line with respiratory alkalosis. ·
  • In respiratory alkalosis, the hydrogen ion concentration is reduced, and fewer H+ are available for binding to negatively charged sites on plasma proteins.
  • Hydrogen and calcium ions compete for the same binding sites on the plasma proteins.
  • In conditions of low hydrogen ion concentration, an increased number of calcium ions bind to plasma proteins.
  • This causes the concentration of ionized calcium ions to decrease in the blood.

Option A: He is hypoventilating

  • The patient hyperventilates in a panic attack, which is the reason for the respiratory alkalosis.
  • Hyperventilation causes the carbon dioxide to wash out from the body.
  • A decrease in carbon dioxide levels leads to a decrease in the pH of the blood and hence, respiratory alkalosis.

Option C: He has decreased total Ca+2 in the blood

  • Although the concentration of ionized calcium decreases in the blood, the total calcium concentration in the blood remains unchanged.

Option D: He has an acid-base disorder caused by the overproduction of fixed acid

  • Overproduction of a fixed acid leads to a low blood pH and causes metabolic acidosis.
  • This patient has respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation.

questions.text: The synaptic connection with the next neuron for a sensory nerve fibre connected to a Pacinian corpuscle located on the palmar surface of the right hand in the corresponding sensory pathway is located in which of the following locations?

choices.text: The dorsal horn of the right side of the spinal cord
The dorsal horn of the left side of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Option A: The right dorsal column nucleus

  • The Pacinian corpuscle transmits a sensation modality (vibration) communicated in the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway.
  • The first synaptic connection in this sensory route is in the dorsal column nuclei on the ipsilateral side of the body.
  • Therefore, in the case of the palmar surface of the right hand, the synaptic connection with the next neuron in the corresponding sensory pathway will be located in the right dorsal column nucleus.

Option B: The left dorsal column nucleus

  • The first synaptic connection in the sensory pathway of the Pacinian corpuscle is in the dorsal column nuclei on the ipsilateral side of the body.
  • Therefore, in the case of the palmar surface of the right hand, the synaptic connection with the next neuron in the corresponding sensory pathway will be located in the right dorsal column nucleus, not the left one.
  • The first-order neuron would be in the left dorsal column if the sensory information were carried from the palmar surface of the left hand.

Option C: The dorsal horn of the right side of the spinal cord

  • The dorsal horn is present at all spinal levels and comprises sensory nuclei that take in and interpret incoming somatosensory information.
  • Ascending projections appear from there and carry the sensory data to the diencephalon and midbrain.
  • They do not transmit tactile or pressure sensations.

Option D: The anterior horn of the right side of the spinal cord

  • The spinal cord's anterior horn contains neurons that transmit motor signals to the skeletal muscles.
  • They do not transmit tactile or pressure sensations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of headache, oliguria, and blurred vision for 1 day. Her BP comes out to be 180/110mmHg. Her urinalysis is positive for protein (+3). Which of the following is the immediate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option D: MgSO4 + antihypertensive therapy

  • The patient with blurring of vision, headache, oliguria, proteinuria, and high BP is a case of severe preeclampsia.
  • The immediate action is to give this patient anticonvulsant (MgSO4) and antihypertensive medication with constant monitoring.
  • Definitive treatment of such severe pre-eclampsia is termination of pregnancy vaginally or by cesarean

Preeclampsia

  • occurs when blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).
  • There is no definite treatment for preeclampsia. Only termination of pregnancy will relieve the patient of these symptoms.
  • The immediate action is to start MgSO4 (to prevent eclampsia) and antihypertensives (to lower the BP).
  • Patient of mild pre-eclampsia is constantly monitored, and the plan is to prolong the pregnancy as much as possible.
  • In case of severe preeclampsia, labour is induced irrespective of gestation age to save the mother and baby's life.

Option A: Antihypertensives

  • The first-line medications for this patient are MgSO4 and antihypertensives. Antihypertensives alone are not sufficient for this patient.

Option B: Antihypertensives followed by LSCS

  • The first-line medications for this patient are MgSO4 and antihypertensives.
  • Definitive treatment for severe pre-eclmapsia or eclampsia is termination of pregnancy but not necessarily by cesarean
  • Pre-eclampsia is not an indication for cesarean. 

Option C: Induction of labour

  • The immediate action is to give this patient anticonvulsant (MgSO4) and antihypertensive medication with constant monitoring.
  • Decision for induction of labour is made after giving these medications.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presented with a history of 2 episodes of hematemesis over 48 hours is diagnosed as a case of upper GI bleeding. Which of the following is helpful as a prognostic scale in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rockall score

  • Rockall risk scoring system attempts to identify patients at risk of adverse outcomes following acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • The scoring system uses clinical criteria (increasing age, comorbidity, shock) as well as endoscopic findings (diagnosis, stigmata of acute bleeding)
  • A convenient mnemonic is ABCDE - i.e. Age, Blood pressure fall (shock), Comorbidity, Diagnosis, and Evidence of bleeding.
  • Rockall scores are designed to combine information such as the patient's age, the occurrence of shock assessed from systolic blood pressure records and pulse rate, presence and severity of comorbid conditions, and stigmata of haemorrhage.

 

Option B: Gleason score

  • Gleason's score helps grade prostatic pathology.
  • The Gleason score is determined by adding the two most common grades.
  • For example, the most common grade of the cells in a tissue sample may be grade 3 cells, followed by grade 4 cells.
  • The Gleason score for this sample would be 7.
  • It is defined as "high-risk" as T3a, Gleason ≥8, or PSA ≥20, and “very high risk” as T3b or T4 disease.

 

Option C: West Haven criteria

  • West Haven criteria (CONN score) help grade Hepatic encephalopathy
  • The West Haven Criteria allow providers to classify the severity of encephalopathy, communicate clearly about a patient's level of consciousness, and trend changes in their mental status.
  • The West Haven criteria (WHC) are the most frequently used for grading HE. This grading system differentiates four grades of clinically manifest HE.
  • In grade I, patients show a lack of attention and some subtle personality changes that are obvious predominantly to their relatives.

 

Option D: Truelove & witts score

  • Truelove & witts score is used as a severity index for Ulcerative Colitis.
  • The Truelove-Witts criteria combine the frequency of bloody stools (⩾6 per day) with at least one marker of systemic toxicity, such as pulse rate >90 bpm, temperature >37.8°C, haemoglobin <10.5 g/dl, and an ESR >30 mm/h.
  • To help standardize endoscopic assessment, a validated endoscopic scoring system called the Ulcerative Colitis Endoscopic Index of Severity (UCEIS) had been developed.
  • This system assesses disease severity using a combination of 3 endoscopic factors: vascular pattern, bleeding, and ulceration/erosion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented in the Emergency with weakness, nausea and vomiting. On examination, there was jaundice, reduced alertness and poor concentration, progressing through behavioural abnormalities, such as restlessness and aggressive outbursts. He was found to have Ascites and hepatic failure on further workup. He stated that he had taken alcohol every day for the last 20 years. Which one of the following is NOT true about the Ascitic fluid on paracentesis?

choices.text: SAAG> 1.1 is seen with portal hypertension
SAAG < 1.1 is seen with Nephrotic syndrome
Pseudo-chylous ascites is milky, contains fatand seen with hypertriglyceridemia
Black ascitic fluid is seen with pancreatic necrosis

questions.solution:
Option C: Pseudo-chylous ascites is milky, contains fat  and seen with hypertriglyceridemia

  • Pseudo-chylous ascites is seen in TB. The fluid is milky white but does not contain fat.
  • White, milky fluid indicates the presence of triglycerides in levels >200 mg/dL (and often >1000 mg/dL), which is the hallmark of chylous ascites.
  • It results from the lymphatic disruption that may occur with trauma, cirrhosis, tumor, tuberculosis, or certain congenital abnormalities.
  • Dark brown fluid can reflect a high bilirubin concentration and indicates biliary tract perforation.
  • Black fluid may indicate the presence of pancreatic necrosis or metastatic melanoma.

Option A: SAAG> 1.1 is seen with portal hypertension

  • SAAG is a better discriminator of portal hypertension than ascites.
  • Patients with SAAG ≥ 1.1 gm/dL are considered as having high SAAG, indicating the presence of portal hypertension, while those with SAAG < 1.1 gm/dL are considered as having low SAAG, indicating the absence of portal hypertension.

Option B: SAAG < 1.1 is seen with Nephrotic syndrome

  • A low gradient (SAAG < 1.1 g/dL) indicates nonportal hypertension and suggests a peritoneal cause of ascites.
  • Low serum oncotic pressure can also cause low SAAG ascites.
  • Testing for nephrotic syndrome and protein‐losing enteropathy should be performed in patients with low SAAG ascites and suspicion of either one of these conditions.

Option D: Black ascitic fluid is seen with pancreatic necrosis

  • Black ascites are a rare property of ascites.
  • The differential diagnosis for black ascites can include metastatic melanoma, bowel perforation with leakage of fecal matter, fungal peritonitis, primary ovarian carcinoma, pancreatic ascites, and leakage of tattoo ink.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male with a gunshot wound to the abdomen presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of peritonitis. Upon transfer to the operating room for urgent surgery, the anesthetist administers a drug that inhibits excitatory NMDA receptors. What is the likely drug used?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ketamine

  • Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative.
  • It is used for the induction of anaesthesia.
  •  It acts by blocking NMDA receptors.
  • Adverse effects include hallucinations, delirium and vivid dreams during recovery from anaesthesia (emergence delirium).
  • It increases the intracranial blood flow, heart rate and cardiac output due to its indirect sympathomimetic action.
  • Ketamine increases intraocular pressure and intracranial tension. Therefore, it should be used cautiously in patients with intracranial pathology (increased ICP).
  • It is an appropriate drug for anaesthetising patients at high risk of bronchospasm.

Option A: Thiopentone

  • Thiopentone is a short-acting thiobarbiturate commonly used for the induction of anaesthesia and was largely replaced by propofol.
  • Barbiturates act on the GABAA receptors to induce their anaesthetic effects.
  • Thiopentone can lead to laryngospasm (prevented by atropine pre-medication), hypotension, bradycardia, respiratory depression, decrease in cerebral blood flow.

Option B: Halothane

  • Halothane is an inhaled anaesthetic which is commonly used for the induction of anaesthesia.
  • It acts by inhibiting acetylcholine receptors and voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • Due to the bronchodilator effect of halothane, it is an agent of choice in patients with respiratory pathology. ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Desflurane

  • Desflurane is also an inhaled anaesthetic. It should be used with caution in patients with bronchospasm due to its pungent smell.
  • Desflurane is a positive allosteric modulator of the GABAA and glycine receptors and a negative modulator of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. It also affects ligand-gated ion channels.
  • It can significantly increase heart rate because of less inhibitory effect on baroreceptors.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not generally used for long-term therapy in Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dobutamine

  • Acute decompensated HF presents with worsening signs and symptoms of HF, including dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), and peripheral oedema.
  • In the given scenario, long-term therapy is needed, and dobutamine is primarily used in the short-term treatment of acute HF as an intravenous infusion.
  • Dobutamine is the selective β1 agonist widely used in acutely decompensated heart failure patients.
  • It is used in acute heart failure because it causes an increase in cardiac output with a decrease in ventricular filling pressure.
  • It does not significantly elevate the oxygen demands of the myocardium and improves cardiac performance by causing a positive inotropic effect.
  • Intermittent dobutamine infusion may benefit some patients with chronic heart failure.

Option A: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside which comes from the digitalis (foxglove) plant.
  • It increases the contractility of cardiac muscles without a proportionate increase in oxygen consumption and, therefore, is used in managing heart failure.
  • Cardiac glycosides are one of the drugs used as maintenance therapy for chronic heart failure.

Option B: Ramipril

  • Ramipril is a drug of class ACE inhibitors which reduces both preload and afterload, thereby reducing cardiac work.
  • It may be considered for patients with asymptomatic and symptomatic HFrEF.
  • It is indicated in all cases of left ventricular failure and must be considered along with diuretics as first-line therapy for chronic heart failure.

Option D: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist, is a synthetic steroid that antagonizes aldosterone activity, resulting in the retention of K+ and excretion of Na+.
  • Its principal action in heart failure is to reduce venous pressure and ventricular preload.
  • It decreases preload and improves ventricular efficiency by reducing circulating volume.
  • It decreases morbidity and mortality in patients with severe heart failure who receive ACE inhibitors and other standard therapy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver gluconeogenesis

  • The patient is in starvation, given that he has not taken any food for the past 3 days.
  • During short-term fasting, the liver produces and releases glucose mainly through glycogenolysis. However, during prolonged fasting, glycogen is depleted, and hepatocytes synthesize glucose through gluconeogenesis using lactate, pyruvate Pyruvate, glycerol, and amino acids.
  • Glucagon released during starvation will cause the activation of gluconeogenic enzymes in the liver, which will maintain the blood glucose needed for the functioning of vital organs such as the brain, heart, and RBCs. Therefore, the answer is liver gluconeogenesis.
  • The Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism, while the fasted state shows a gluconeogenesis process from gluconeogenic substrates.
  • The figure below shows the role of the liver in the fed and fasting state under hormonal control.

Option B: Dietary Glucose

  • Dietary glucose can provide blood glucose up to 2 hours after feeding. The extra glucose consumed in food gets deposited in the liver and muscles as glycogen and fats in adipose tissues.

Option C: Muscle glycogenolysis

  • The glycogenolysis inside the muscles gives glucose-6-phosphate as an end-product, not D-Glucose, due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in muscles. Hence, muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly.

Option D: Liver glycogenolysis

  • Glycogen breakdown in the liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours. After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the primary source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: Which is the common amino acid between the urea cycle and TCA?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aspartate

  • In Urea cycle:-Aspartate (an amino acid) provides second nitrogen of urea (the first nitrogen is from free Ammonia).
  • Fumarate is also common in Urea cycle & TCA, but fumarate is not an amino acid
  • As, Question specifically ask about amino acid, Hence the answer is aspartate and not fumarate.
  • In TCA :-
    • Fumarate from the urea cycle enters TCA cycle and gets converted to malate, then oxaloacetate, which forms aspartate via transamination
    • Then aspartate enters the urea cycle in the arginosuccinate synthetase step.

Option B: Alanine

  • Alanine is not the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle.
  • Alanine undergoes a transamination reaction to form pyruvate, which can be metabolized to generate ATP.
  • Alanine is involved in acid and sugar metabolism. It also provides energy to the CNS, muscles, brain, etc.

Option C: Asparagine

  • Asparagine is not the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle.
  • The precursor of asparagine is oxaloacetate.
  • Asparagine synthase is involved in the formation of asparagine from aspartate and glutamate.

Option D: Fumarate

  • Fumarate is not the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle.
  • It is an intermediate of the TCA cycle. It is converted into malate in the TCA cycle.
  • Fumarate is derived from phenylalanine, tyrosine, aspartate, etc., for input to the TCA cycle.

questions.text: A 25 year old male returning from South America to India was kept in quarantine by the airport authorities. Due to recent advances in Health care system, quarantine has been replaced nowadays by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Quarantine has been replaced with active surveillance.
  • Quarantine is the restriction of activities of apparently healthy persons who have been exposed to a case of communicable disease during its period of communicability, for the duration of it's maximum incubation period.
  • Active surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of all aspects of a disease and application of information to heath promotion and to disease prevention and control.

questions.text: Incineration is a waste treatment process that involves the combustion of organic substances contained in waste materials. All of the following are incinerated except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Broken thermometers

  • Broken thermometers contain Mercury, its disposal is through recycling.

INCINERATION:

  • Temperature = > 1200oC.
  • Principle = High temperature + Dry oxidation.
  • Has Combustible matter > 60%; Non-combustible solids < 0.5%; Non-combustible fines < 20% and moisture content <30%.
  • Human anatomical wastes, animal wastes, solid waste, chemical waste/ discarded medicines, etc. can be incinerated.
  • Contraindications:
    • PVC plastic waste. [may cause angiosarcoma of the liver]
    • Pressurized waste. [explosion can occur]
    • Heavy metal waste. [ lead, cadmium, mercury - as they may cause poisoning]
    • Reactive chemical waste. [silver- x-rays]
    • Radio-active waste-sea burial is recommended.

Option A: Human anatomical waste

  • Human anatomical wastes can be incinerated.
  • Any identifiable body part, including limbs, organs, and tissue, may be considered anatomical waste, as well as pathology samples, biopsy samples, and specimens collected during surgery or an autopsy.

Option B: Animal waste

  • Animal wastes can be incinerated.
  • The majority of animal waste is composed of manures from cows, pigs, and chickens.

Option C: Soiled Waste

  • Soiled Waste can be incinerated.

questions.text: Fish and Shellfish concentrate this element in their bodies, often in the form of a highly toxic organic compound. Bioaccumulation in seafood carries over into human populations, where it can result in poisoning which causes severe neurological and kidney damage. Acute exposure can affect the respiratory and gastrointestinal systems. In its organic form, it can cross the blood-brain barrier and cause irreversible nervous system and brain damage which is collectively termed as "Swift Feer disease". Poisoning with which element is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mercury

  • Acrodynia (Pink Disease)/ Swift Feer disease: Due to chronic mercury poisoning

Option A: Arsenic

  • Chronic arsenic poisoning causes rain drop pigmentation and mees lines on the finger nails.

Option C: Copper

  • Copper is a metal and not a poison.
  • It is rarely used for suicide. Accidental poisoning can occur due to ingestion in food. sometimes it is rarely taken for abortion in form of salts.

Option D: Lead

  • Chronic lead poisoning causes Burtonian lines, colic and constipation, lead palsy, Encephalopathy.

questions.text: Vani, a 30 year old female, had persistent feelings of anxiety and worry associated with insomnia, irritability, tension, and fatigue. Over the years, her friends and family rebuked her for "worrying too much," and she reported difficulty controlling her anxiety over her financial situation, job security, and her children's safety, despite evidence that none of these were problematic. Her husband reported that he found her persistent anxiety and ongoing need for reassurance "exhausting" and that he noticed himself withdrawing from her, which led to significant tension between them. Drug of choice for this disorder is:
questions.solution:
• Generalised Anxiety Disorder is characterized by free-floating anxiety and excessive worries.
  • Treatment of GAD
    • Benzodiazepines
    • SSRIs
    • Venlafaxine
    • CBT: Supportive psychotherapy, Insight oriented psychotherapy

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with recurrent history of tonsillitis. This year he had 5 attacks of acute tonsillitis, which were managed without complications. He is admitted for elective tonsillectomy under general anaesthesia. His past history is significant for fracture of the humerus following an RTA for which he underwent repair and internal fixation under general anaesthesia. He is concerned about postoperative nausea and vomiting, which he suffered following previous surgery. What would be the ideal anaesthetic agent in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Propofol

  • Propofol is known for its least adverse effect of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and rapid emergence from anaesthesia.
  • Depending on the risk scoring of postoperative nausea and vomiting, propofol is an ideal anaesthetic agent, especially when used as total intravenous anaesthesia.
  • Propofol at a sub-anaesthetic dose (10 mg) produces direct antiemetic effects.
  • In addition, using propofol for the maintenance of anaesthesia produces a positive effect on PONV reduction.
  • Propofol decreases the level of serotonin in the blood, thereby resulting in the least activation of 5 HT3 receptors in the area postrema of the brain, thereby producing antiemetic effects.

Option A: Nitrous oxide

  • Significantly increased incidence of postoperative emesis has been documented with nitrous oxide as an anaesthetic agent.
  • Mechanism of PONV with Nitrous oxide includes increased middle ear pressure, bowel distension, activation of the dopaminergic system in the area posterema and interaction with opioid receptors.

Option C: Etomidate

  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting are increased in patients receiving etomidate induction.
  • Etomidate is rarely used in outpatient procedures and during examination because of its side effects, including postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and myoclonus.
  • Etomidate is associated with a high incidence of PONV (30–40%), which is higher than propofol.

Option D: Ketamine

  • Ketamine also increases the incidence of PONV by resulting in vivid dreams, hallucinations and delayed discharges in the central nervous system.
  • It also increases endogenous catecholamine levels contributing to emetic potential.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing superficial parotidectomy under general anaesthesia to manage pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid. Induction is done with Inj. Thiopentone sodium and cisatracurium are used to facilitate endotracheal intubation and maintenance. Which end-point is used as an indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker?
questions.solution:
Option D: Train-of-four ratio > 0.7

  • The indicator of adequate neuromuscular function after the use of nondepolarizing agents is the recovery of the train-of-four (TOF) ratio to > 0.70. It is used as an indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker.
  • Tests of respiratory function (vital capacity, inspiratory force, peak expiratory flow rate) and voluntary muscle function (tongue protrusion, head lift, hand grasp, and sustained eye opening) are reported to have returned to clinically acceptable values once the TOF ratio was > 0.70.
  • Clinically depression of at least 95% of a twitch is needed to obtain the absence of glottic movements.
Normal response to stimulation Percentage of free receptors
single twitch >20-25
train of four >25-30
30Hz tetanic >30
50Hz tetanic >40
100Hz tetanic >50
200Hz tetanic >60

Option A: Train-of-four ratio > 0.75

  • The indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker is a TOF ratio > 0.7.

Option B: Train-of-four ratio > 0.8

  • It is not the indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker.
  • The indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker is a TOF ratio > 0.7.

Option C: Train-of-four ratio > 0.9

  • The indicator to obtain recovery from the neuromuscular blocker is TOF ratio > 0.7, not 0.9.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the parathyroid gland except?

choices.text: Upper parathyroid glands are superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and Recurrent laryngeal nerve
Most common location of ectopic parathyroid glands is the paraesophageal
Lower parathyroid glands are inferior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and Recurrent laryngeal nerve
The superior parathyroid glands are located anterior to Recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Option D: The superior parathyroid glands are located anterior to RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)

IDENTIFICATION OF PARATHYROIDS:

  • Approximately 85% of the parathyroid glands are found within 1 cm of the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
  • Upper parathyroid glands
    • Superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN
    • Dorsal (posterior) to RLN
  • Lower parathyroid glands
    • Inferior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN
    • Ventral (anterior) to RLN
  • The normal size of the parathyroid gland is equal to the size of a rice grain.
  • Normal parathyroid glands weigh 35-50 mg and are 5 by 4 by 2 mm in size.
  • Enlarged parathyroid gland can weigh 50 mg - 20 grams.
  • Most common location of ectopic parathyroid gland in descending order:
    • Paraesophageal (28%)
    • Mediastinal (26%)
    • Intrathymic (24%)
    • Carotid sheath (9%)
    • High cervical or undescended (2%)

Option A: Upper parathyroid glands are superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)

  • Upper parathyroid glands are located 1-2 cm superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN. 

Option B: Most common location of ectopic parathyroid glands is paraesophageal

  • The underlying reason for the ectopic parathyroid gland is the failure of complete migration of the parathyroid gland. The most common location for the ectopic parathyroid gland is the paraesophageal.

Option C: Lower parathyroid glands are inferior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)

  • Lower parathyroid glands are located inferior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A three years old male child presented with mild pallor, icterus, and a history of on and off abdominal and joint pains. On examination, the child had mild splenomegaly. He had a history of two prior hospital admissions. He has had three transfusions till now; the last transfusion was 3 months back. There is a history of sibling death due to fever and jaundice at 5 years of age. The hemogram showed anaemia with leukocytosis. The peripheral smear is done, and images are shown below. Which of the following is true about the finding?

choices.text: It occurs equally in both heterozygous and homozy­gous variants
It is associated with reduced MCHC

questions.solution:
Option C: It is reversible with oxygenation

  • Sickle cell anaemia is intrinsic hemolytic anaemia resulting in both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.
  • Sickle cell disease is a common familial hemolytic anaemia caused by a point mutation in β-globin in which glutamic acid is replaced by valine at the 6th position.

 

 

  • It promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated haemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anaemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage. High altitude and acidosis precipitate sickling.
  • This sickling is reversible with oxygenation. Low oxygen states promote sickling.
  • Low oxygen levels cause haemoglobin to form long rods, disrupting the RBCs into a long abnormal sickle shape.
  • Hypoxia promotes a sickle shape in the red blood cells; it makes them more fragile and prone to rupture.
  • When the oxygen levels are adequate, sickling reverses.
  • The skull X-ray shows a crew cut appearance due to marrow expansion from increased erythropoiesis.
  • Dehydration [high MCHC] & deoxygenation, acidosis, and infections facilitate sickling.
  • Alkalosis does not facilitate sickling.
  • Sickle cell trait (heterozygosity) confers a protective effect against falciparum malaria.
  • Peripheral smear showing sickle cells, elliptocytes, and ovalocytes.
