  • In early childhood, the spleen is enlarged. However, as the disease progresses, there is chronic erythrocytosis leading to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage, only a small piece of fibrous splenic tissue is left, a process called an auto splenectomy.
  • The mainstay of treatment is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis, hydroxyurea.

 

Option A: It occurs equally in both heterozygous and homozy­gous variants

  • Sickling is more severe in the homozygous state than in the heterozygous state
  • So, sickling does not occur equally in both homozygous and heterozygous states.

 

Option B: Fetal haemoglobin facilitates this finding

  • HbS facilitates sickling, not HbF
  • Hydroxyurea which increases HbF, is used in the management of the disease.

 

Option D: It is associated with reduced MCHC

  • Dehydration is associated with an increased risk of sickling
  • Dehydration causes an increase in MCHC.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy born to a primigravida mother presented with hoarseness. On laryngeal examination, findings are seen as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is not true about the given condition?

choices.text: Caused by Human Papilloma Virus 16 and 18
Surgical Excision by Microdebrider is the treatment of choice
Interferon- α is used as adjuvant therapy to decrease recurrence
Radiotherapy is contraindicated as it may cause malignant transformation

questions.solution:
Option A: Caused by Human Papilloma Virus 16 & 18:

  • The JORPP is not caused by HPV 16 and 18; rather it is caused by HPV 6 and 11.
  • The patient is a young boy presenting with a complaint of hoarseness of voice and multiple papillomatous lesions on the vocal cords. These findings are consistent with juvenile-onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

Juvenile-onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (JORRP): describes the findings of options B, C, and D.

  • Most common benign tumor of the larynx.
  • Affects the boys and girls equally.
  • The patients present at the age of 4 months to 13 years.
  • It manifests the human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 11.
  • The first and most predominant site involved is the vocal folds due to their effect on the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. They can also involve subglottis, trachea, and bronchi.
  • The most common presenting symptom of JORRP is hoarseness of voice; Other findings include aphonia along with respiratory distress or even stridor.

There is a 2%-3% risk of malignancy.

Option B: Surgical excision by Microdebrider is the treatment of choice

  • Management is by excision using microdebrider.

Option C: Interferon-α is used as an adjuvant therapy to decrease recurrence

  • The chances of recurrence are very high; therefore, interferon alpha and cidofovir are given in the postoperative period, which has decreased the chances of recurrence.

Option D: Radiotherapy is contraindicated as it may cause malignant transformation

  • Radiotherapy is not used as it increases the chances of malignant transformation.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female presents to the ENT department with a hoarse voice for the past few days. She also has occasional gastric reflux symptoms and a constant desire to clear her throat. On laryngoscopy following finding is seen:



Which of the following is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Unilateral & over the vocal process of arytenoids
Speech therapy to correct the pitch of voice
Intralesional injection of steroid is given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma

questions.solution:
Option B: Throat pain improves on phonation

  • The location of various laryngeal lesions is as follows:
  • Vocal polyp- Unilateral & Junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd.
  • Vocal nodule- Bilateral & Junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd.
  • Reinke's edema- Bilateral & Diffuse.
  • Contact granuloma- Unilateral & Over the vocal process of arytenoids, associated with Reflux disease.
  • The laryngoscope findings in the question above are consistent with a contact granuloma.
  • Contact granuloma is almost always unilateral and is found over the vocal process of arytenoids.
  • It is usually associated with and caused by gastric reflux.
  • Chief complaints are hoarse voice, a constant desire to clear the throat, and throat pain worse on phonation. Management includes:
  • Anti-reflux therapy.
  • Speech therapy to stop throat clearing and correct pitch of voice.
  • Inhaled steroids or intralesional injection of steroid to stop inflammation and size of granuloma. Micro-laryngeal surgery may be needed to remove granuloma.

Option A: Unilateral & over the vocal process of arytenoids

This is false because:

  • Contact granuloma is primarily unilateral, and over the vocal process of arytenoids.

Option C: Speech therapy to correct the pitch of voice

This is false because:

  • Speech therapy is employed in its treatment to correct the pitch of voice in patients with contact granuloma.

Option D: Intralesional injection of steroid is given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma

This is false because:

  • Intralesional injection of steroid is often given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the clinic due to a sore throat for 4 days. It is associated with low-grade fever and generalized abdominal pain. On physical examination, there are enlarged right cervical lymph nodes and enlarged tonsils with a membrane over them. She has been prescribed an antibiotic course for 7 days. She returns to the clinic on the 9ᵗʰ day as the symptoms persist after the treatment. Which of the following is the specific test for this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Paul-Bunnell test

The clinical features are suggestive of Infectious Mononucleosis:

  • This often affects young adults.
  • EBV is an etiological agent.
  • Both tonsils are enlarged, congested, and covered with a membrane. Local discomfort is marked.
  • Lymph nodes are enlarged in the posterior triangle of the neck. Splenomegaly is present.
  • Attention to disease is attracted because of the failure of antibiotic treatment.
  • A blood smear may show more than 50% lymphocytes, of which about 10% are atypical.
  • White cell count rises in the second week.
  • Paul–Bunnell test (Monospot test) will show a high titer of heterophil antibody.

Option A: Throat swab and culture

  • This patient's clinical features are characteristic of Infectious mononucleosis.
  • Throat swabs and cultures diagnose infections with pyogenic bacteria, Vincent angina, Diphtheria, and Candida infection.
  • Paul-Bunnell test is used for the diagnosis of Infectious mononucleosis.

Option B: Tonsillar Biopsy

  • The clinical features are characteristic of Infectious mononucleosis. The Paul-Bunnell test identifies it.
  • A tonsillar biopsy is done for tonsillar malignancy.

Option D: Blood smear

  • The clinical features are characteristic of Infectious mononucleosis. The Paul-Bunnell test identifies it.
  • A blood smear shows atypical cells. Atypical cells are not specific for Infectious mononucleosis. They occur in other viral diseases as well.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. He was recently operated on for deviated nasal septum and turbinate hypertrophy. After a thorough history and examination, the following test was performed. Which of the following statement is false regarding the test?

choices.text: It is a cold spatula test.
Gives information about the patency of the nasal cavity
Test showing reduced fogging on any side implies nasal obstruction
Physiologically superior to the cotton wool wisp test.

questions.solution:
Option D: Physiologically superior to cotton wool wisp test.

The above test performed in the picture is a cold spatula test.

  • The cold spatula test is a simple, reliable, easy-to-perform, and noninvasive objective test; investigating cases of nasal block.
  • It is a simple, functional technique used to verify the patency of the nasal cavity.
  • It also helps the physician to decide the accuracy of the patient's complaint of nose block and offer treatment accordingly.
  • A clean cold tongue depressor is held below the nostrils to look for the area of mist formation; when the patient exhales, the two sides are compared.
  • This test gives information about the patency of the nasal cavity.
  • If the nasal obstruction is present, reduced fogging on the side of the obstruction will be noted.
  • Cotton wool wisp test: Fluff of cotton is held against each nostril, and its movements are noticed when the patient inhales and exhales.It is a better physiological test as both the inspiration and expiration phases are seen.

Cold spatula test                Cotton wool wisp test

Option A: It is a cold spatula test

  • The test performed in the picture is a cold spatula test.
  • The cold spatula test is a simple, noninvasive test.
  • It gives us information about the patency of the nostrils.
  • The test will show reduced fogging on the side of the nasal obstruction.

Option B: Gives information about the patency of the nasal cavity

  • The test performed in the picture is a cold spatula test.
  • The cold spatula test is a simple, noninvasive test.
  • It gives us information about the patency of the nostrils.
  • The test will show reduced fogging on the side of the nasal obstruction.

Option C: A test showing reduced fogging on any side implies nasal obstruction.

  • The test performed in the picture is a cold spatula test.
  • The cold spatula test is a simple, noninvasive test.
  • It gives us information about the patency of the nostrils.
  • The test will show reduced fogging on the side of the nasal obstruction.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents in the outpatient department after extreme bilateral nasal obstruction and pain in his nose. He also has been experiencing a fever with chills after septal surgery. He developed a furuncle over his upper lip 3 days ago. An anterior rhinoscopy shows a smooth, fluctuant swelling on both sides of the septum. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Septal Abscess

  • Smooth fluctuant swelling, history of fever with chills and furuncle over upper lip – Points towards septal abscess.

Septal Abscess:

Aetiology

  • Septal hematoma with superadded infection leads to a septal abscess.
  • It usually follows the furuncle of the nose or upper lip.
  • May also follow acute infection such as typhoid or measles.

Clinical Features

  • Severe bilateral nasal obstruction with pain and tenderness over the bridge of the nose.
  • The patient may also complain of fever with chills and frontal headaches.
  • The skin over the nose may be red and swollen.
  • Internal examination of the nose reveals smooth bilateral swelling of the nasal septum.
  • Fluctuation can be elicited in this swelling.
  • Septal mucosa is often congested. Submandibular lymph nodes may also be enlarged and tender.

Treatment

  • Systemic antibiotic therapy is prescribed for it.
  • Drainage of abscess is needed.

Option A: Deviated Nasal Septum

  • Etiology: It can be traumatic, congenital/developmental causes.
  • Symptoms: Unilateral/bilateral nasal obstruction, headache, crusting, and nasal discharge may be there.
  • Signs: 'C' or 'S-shaped deviation of nasal septum/maxillary crest or spur/ caudal dislocation of the septum may be present.
  • This patient's history of fever, chills and nasal obstruction make septal abscess the appropriate diagnosis; hence this is the incorrect choice.

Option B: Septal Hematoma

  • It is the collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum.
  •  It often results from nasal trauma or septal surgery. In bleeding disorders, it may occur spontaneously.
  • It presents with bilateral nasal obstruction is the commonest presenting symptom. This may be associated with frontal headaches and a sense of pressure over the nasal bridge.
  • This patient's history of fever, chills, and furuncle leads to a diagnosis of septal abscess instead of septal hematoma, making it the wrong choice for this specific vignette.

Option D: Septal Perforation

  • Iatrogenic (septoplasty)
  • Trauma and septal hematoma
  • Drug use (cocaine, inhaled narcotics)
  • Malignancy
  • Granulomatous disease (granulomatosis with polyangiitis [GPA], sarcoidosis)
  • Corticosteroid nasal spray (overuse)
  • Infection (tertiary syphilis)

Clinical Presentation:

  • It presents with wheezing and large crusts over the septum, which causes bleeding when peeled.
  • None of the clinical features are present in the patient, making it an incorrect choice. Fever, chills, nasal obstruction, and pain make septal abscess the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady claims the tree trunk outside her flat resembles Lord Ram's face. She can always see Lord Ram's face when she walks past that tree, but not on the other trees. The person's behavior is described by which one of the following terms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Illusion

  • The patient claims she can see Lord Ram's face in a specific tree.
  • This is an example of an illusion.
  • Illusion is a false perception of a real object or stimulus.

Option A: Delusional misidentification

  • Delusional misidentification syndromes are a group of delusional phenomena in which patients misidentify familiar persons, objects, or selves and believe they have been replaced or transformed.
  • These syndromes are delusional because the misidentifications are false and are not correctable by experience or reason.

Option B: Delusion of reference

  • It is a false and firm belief that irrelevant occurrences or details in the world relate directly to oneself.

Option D: Visual hallucination

  • Visual hallucination refers to the false perception in the absence of any stimulus or object.
  • It is as vivid as a real perception.
  • They occur in outer and objective space.
  • They are not under voluntary, willful control.
  • Visual hallucinations are commonly seen in Organic mental disorders.

questions.text: The forensic team has begun a thorough sweep of the bedroom where the victim's body was found. On immediate observation, a large exit wound was noticed which most likely was from a close contact shot. In the direction of the forward spatter, at a certain distance, some intact parts of the victim's brain were also recovered.  this would be documented as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kronlein shot

  • Seen only in contact wounds.
  • Most commonly with high-velocity missile.
  • A large exit wound is produced and a large portion of the brain or even the entire brain may be thrown out of the bursting skull and found relatively intact at a distance.

Option B: Back spatter

  • Once the bullet is fired, a spattering of blood back into the barrel.

Option C: Billiard Ball Effect

  • It occurs after the shotgun pallets strike an intermediate object like doors, etc.
  • When a group of shotgun pellets hits tissue, the first pellets are delayed and impacted from behind by subsequent pellets, causing them to scatter into the tissue, similar to a cluster of billiard balls struck by the cue ball.
  • On X-ray, the dispersal of pellets may suggest a distant shot, while actually, the weapon was fired from close range.

Option D: Balling of shot

  • Shotguns can ball or fuse their projectiles, which can result in a major entry wound that is circular or oval in shape and multiple smaller punctures that are circular in shape.
  • This suggests the usage of two weapons, one rifle and one shotgun.

questions.text: Under which section, if a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: S. 132 IEA

  • Witness not excused from answering on ground that answer will criminate.
  • If a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding.

Option B: S.151 IEA

  • Indecent or Scandalous questions.
  • Unless they relate to the facts at issue or to information that is required to be known in order to determine whether the facts at issue existed, the Court may prohibit any questions or inquiries that it deems to be indecent or scandalous, even though they may have some bearing on the questions before the Court.

Option C: S.152 IEA

  • Questions intended to insult or annoy.
  • Any inquiry that the Court determines to be needlessly offensive in form or that the Court believes is meant to offend or annoy someone will be prohibited.

Option D: S.148 IEA

  • Court to decide when question shall be asked and when witness compelled to answer.
  • The Court will decide whether or not the witness will be required to answer any such question if it relates to a subject not pertinent to the lawsuit or proceeding, with the exception of how it might jeopardise the witness's reputation.
  • The Court may also, if it sees fit, inform the witness that he is not required to answer the question.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female patient is brought to the clinic by her foster care parents. She was adopted from Iran, and according to her records, she was born to a mother who suffered from alcohol abuse. Referring to the image given below, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rickets

  • The Wrist radiograph shows an immature skeleton, and the lower ends of the radius and ulna show cupping, splaying and fraying suggestive of rickets.
  • Rickets is a bone disease due to defective osteoid or cartilaginous growth plate mineralization.
  • It mostly occurs in children due to nutritional deficiency, particularly vitamin D deficiency.
  • Some of the clinical features include:
    • Generalized hypotonic is observed in most cases of rickets.
    • Children affected with rickets are irritable, and their weight and height are below the 3rd percentile.
    • They have several dental carriers.
    • The spine may reveal kyphosis and enlargement of costal cartilage (rachitic rosary)
    • Long bones are shortened and deformed; fractures are common.
  • The anterior view of the knee is the best location for radiographic examination because of the rapid growth in this location.
  • The metaphysis exhibit features of splaying and cupping, which is widening and increased the concavity of metaphyseal edges.
  • There is also fraying, which is indistinct margins of the metaphysis.

 

 

Option A: Scurvy

  • The radiographic findings of scurvy include:
    • Periosteal hemorrhage
    • cortical thinning is described as pencil-thin cortex
    • ground glass osteopenia.
    • Corner angel sign which irregular metaphyseal margins.
    • Wimberger sign: a circular opaque radiologic shadow that surrounds the epiphyseal centers of ossification.
    • Frankel line: increased distal diaphysis opacity and a zone of decreased opacity.

 

Option C: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Osteofibrosa cystica is a classic presentation of advanced hyperparathyroidism.
  • X-ray reveals extremely thin bones that may be fractured, bone resorption, ground glass, or salt and pepper appearance of a skull.

 

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta

  • The radiographic features of osteogenesis imperfect include bone deformities, osteopenia, and bone fractures.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic presented in an unconscious state and recovered by injection of thiamine followed by overnight parenteral glucose. The next morning, he had normal serum thiamine with blood glucose = 73 mg/dL. Which of the following enzymes/proteins would have low significant physiologic activity in this patient soon after discharge?
questions.solution:
• After an overnight fast (plasma glucose 73 mg/dL), the glucose concentration will be low.
  • At low glucose levels, hexokinase with its higher afﬁnity for glucose can convert all the glucose to glucose 6-phosphate without triggering the release of its isozyme for glucokinase hence glucokinase concentration remains low.
  • Glucokinase has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than hexokinase, so, it is mostly active in post prandial state when glucose levels are high in the liver.
  • So, in this patient, the activity of glucokinase would be insignificant as it requires high glucose concentration to be effective.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the hospital with easy fatigability and a history of recurrent pneumonia. The patient was born full-term via normal vaginal delivery, and there was no known history of cyanosis or jaundice in the neonatal period. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, his temperature is 37.2 (98.9F), blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 102/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Cardiac examination reveals fixed splitting of S2 heart sound, and a murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest auscultation reveals crackles more pronounced at the middle lobe of the right lung. Upon further evaluation, the patient has been diagnosed with septum primum type of ASD. Which of the following heart chamber overburdens in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Right atrium plus right ventricle

  • ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECT (ASD): It is an abnormal connection between two atria of the heart.
  • Features of ASD:
    • In the majority of cases, it is asymptomatic.
    • Dyspnea, cardiomegaly, and atrial fibrillation can occur in severe cases.
    • Feeding difficulties, profuse perspiration, recurrent chest infection, and poor growth in children.
    • Auscultatory findings: Wide fixed splitting of S2
    • Large ASD → Diastolic murmur on the tricuspid area and/or ejection systolic murmur on the pulmonary area.
    • In ASD (ostium primum as well as secundum), overload of the right atrium and right ventricle occurs due to left to right shunting of blood. As more blood goes to the right heart, it enlarges to accumulate increased volume overload on the right side of the heart.

 

  • Assessment of severity: Severity is directly proportional to the intensity of murmurs & heart size
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary hypertension → by 2nd or 3rd decade due to overload of blood on the right side of the heart, which leads to the remodelling of the pulmonary vasculature and subsequent pulmonary hypertension.
    • Atrial arrhythmias
    • Heart failure → in late adulthood
    • Stroke
  • Treatment:
    • Small defects → < 8mm → observation, as spontaneous closure is seen in most cases
    • Larger defects → surgical closure of the defect

Option B: Left atrium plus left ventricle

  • Left atrium & Left ventricle enlargement occurs in ventricular septal defect (VSD) and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • It does not occur in ASD as there is right-sided blood overload in ASD, not left-sided.

Option C: Right atrium plus left atrium

  • Enlargement of the right atrium occurs in ASD, but the left atrium does not enlarge in ASD. 

Option D: Left atrium enlargement

  • Left atrial enlargement occurs in mitral Stenosis.
  • It does not occur in the atrial septal defect

questions.text: Which calcium channel blocker with peripheral action would be prescribed for a 55-year-old male presenting with mild headache and dizziness, having a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute, and already on once-daily dosing?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amlodipine

  • The patient mentioned above has a blood pressure of 140/100mmHg. Calcium channel blocker, especially Amlodipine, has a predominant peripheral action and lowers blood pressure.
  • Three groups of calcium channel blockers include:
    • Phenylalkylamines (verapamil, nor-verapamil)
    • Benzothiazepines (Diltiazem)
    • Dihydropyridines (Nifedipine, Nicardipine, Nimodipine, Nisoldipine, Felodipine and Amlodipine).
  • By inhibiting the calcium channels, these agents result in vasodilation and decreased heart activity (decreased heart rate, AV conduction and contractility).
  • The dihydropyridine (DHP) group has little direct cardiac activity and acts mainly on blood vessels, therefore is also called a peripherally acting calcium channel blocker.

Option A: Verapamil

  • Verapamil belongs to Phenylalkylamines class of calcium channel blockers.
  • Verapamil inhibits the calcium ion (and possibly sodium ion) influx through slow channels into conductive and contractile myocardial cells and vascular smooth muscle cells.

Option B: Diltiazem

  • Diltiazem belongs to the Benzothiazepines group of Calcium channel blockers.
  • Diltiazem inhibits the inflow of calcium ions into the cardiac, smooth muscle during depolarization.
  • Reduced intracellular calcium concentrations increase smooth muscle relaxation resulting in arterial vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

Option D: Nor-verapamil

  • Nor-verapamil belongs to Phenylalkylamines class of calcium channel blockers.
  • Non-Verapamil inhibits the calcium ion (and possibly sodium ion) influx through slow. Channels into conductive and contractile myocardial cells and vascular smooth muscle cells.

questions.text: A 49-year-old known diabetic has had symptoms of mild hematuria, itching of the skin, decreased appetite, difficulty in breathing after walking for 25 meters and fatigue for about 6 months duration. On examination, peri-orbital edema is noted, a panel of tests is ordered, and it confirms chronic renal failure. If a diuretic needs to be administered to the patient, which of the following options is suitable?
questions.solution:
Option B: Furosemide

  • Patients with chronic renal failure are hyperkalemic because they are unable to excrete potassium.
  • Furosemide can be given in chronic renal failure because it enhances the secretion of potassium into the tubular lumen.
  • Therefore, it does not put the patient at risk of hyperkalemia.

Option A: Amiloride

  • Amiloride is a potassium sparing diuretic.
  • Patients with chronic renal failure are not able to secret potassium into the urine and are at risk of hyperkalemia.
  • Therefore, diuretics increase potassium levels and can not be given in chronic renal function.

Option C: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is a potassium sparing diuretic.
  • Patients with chronic renal failure are not able to secret potassium into the urine and are at risk of hyperkalemia.
  • Therefore, diuretics increase potassium levels and can not be given in chronic renal function.

Option D: Eplerenone

  • Eplerenone is a potassium sparing diuretic.
  • Patients with chronic renal failure are not able to secret potassium into the urine and are at risk of hyperkalemia.
  • Therefore, diuretics increase potassium levels and can not be given in chronic renal function.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of cough for the past 2 days. It is not associated with fever and sputum, or any other symptoms. He suffered from a viral infection last week, which resolved after taking rest.. The physical examination is normal. In order to manage this patient, the patient receives cough syrup which contains a combination of two drugs. One of these drugs is labelled as an ''antitussive drug''. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this antitussive drug?

choices.text: Raise the threshold of the cough centre

questions.solution:
Option A: Raise the threshold of the cough centre

  • This patient with a nonproductive cough is suffering from post-viral cough syndrome.
  • The management of the post viral cough syndrome involves using a cough suppressant.
  • Cough suppressants are the drugs used for the symptomatic treatment of cough.
  • The mechanisms of action include suppression of the central cough receptor in the brain and inhibition of stretch receptors in the lungs and pleura.
  • Examples include:
    • Benzonatate
    • Codeine
    • Dextromethorphan
    • Pholcodine
    • Noscapine

Option B: Inhibition of the breathing centre

  • This is not the mechanism of action of antitussive drugs.

Option C: Inhibition of the respiratory centre

  • This is not the mechanism of action of antitussive drugs.

Option D: Increase tussal impulses

  • This is not the mechanism of action of antitussive drugs, as it can exacerbate the cough rather than decrease its severity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. The patient is a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and bronchial asthma. On examination, his pulse is 63/min, respirations are 25/min, and his blood pressure is 102/70 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Physical examination shows decreased air entry and bilateral wheezing. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following drug cannot be used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of severe asthma?
questions.solution:
Option B: Salmeterol

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma, and he needs treatment for his condition.
  • Short-acting β2 agonists (e.g., albuterol) are the treatment for acute asthma symptoms and should be used in patients with acute asthma exacerbation.
  • A long-acting beta-agonist such as salmeterol cannot be used in acute bronchial asthma attacks. However, the long-acting beta-agonist can be used in prophylaxis to prevent bronchial asthma.

Option A: Terbutaline

  • Terbutaline is a short-acting beta agonist, and it is used in the management of acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option C: Hydrocortisone

  • Hydrocortisone is a steroid which is part of the standard therapy for the acute exacerbation of asthma. 

Option D: Salbutamol

  • Salbutamol is also a short-acting beta agonist, and it is used in the management of acute exacerbation of asthma

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for patients with cerebral malaria?
questions.solution:
Option B: Artesunate

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cerebral Malaria as his blood was positive for malaria parasite plasmodium, and also he had an episode of seizure after that
  • Cerebral Malaria is commonly seen with severe P. falciparum infection.
  • The drug of choice for Cerebral Malaria is parenteral artemisinins because these are fast-acting, more effective, better tolerated and more conveniently administered.
  • Therefore artesunate (i.v./i.m.) or artemether ( i.m.), or arteether (i.m.) are now preferred over Quinine for severe cases of Malaria.
  • Cerebral Malaria is defined by definite evidence of malaria infection; asexual forms of P. falciparum in the blood film; and a GCS of less than 11 for at least 1 h
  • Seizures per se are not a criterion for diagnosis of CM
  • However, our patient had a seizure followed by prolonged unresponsiveness. Hence we considered the diagnosis of CM without a definite GCS value.
  • It is to be also noted that a definite diagnosis of CM requires postmortem examination of the brain either by autopsy or supra-orbital sampling, which was not possible in our case

Option A: Choloroquine

  • Chloroquine is not very effective against plasmodium falciparum because of resistance formed against chloroquine

Option C: Primaquine

  • Primaquine is used as casual prophylaxis against Malaria and is not used for acute treatment of Malaria

Option D: Sulfadoxine

  • Sulfadoxine is used but is not as effective as artesunate for cerebral Malaria

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the outpatient department with the given radiologic findings. Which of the following are used to treat the given condition yearly?
questions.solution:
Option B: Zolendronate

  • The given radiograph shows Diffuse osteopenia with cortical thinning and multi-level vertebral crush fractures, which is typical of Osteoporosis in postmenopausal women
  • Bisphosphonates taken orally are now regarded as the first-line medication for reducing fracture risk in postmenopausal women.
  • They act by reducing osteoclastic bone resorption and the general rate of bone turnover and are known to reduce the risk of hip and vertebral fractures.
  • Zoledronate can be given once per year intravenously.

Option A: Alendronate

  • Alendronate is used to treat Osteoporosis.
  • Route of administration: Oral
  • It is administered once a week.

Option C: Risedronate

  • It is a Bisphosphonate group of drug
  • Route of administration: Oral
  • Used in Osteoporosis
  • It is administered every 2 months.

Option D: Ibandronate

  • Used to treat and prevent Osteoporosis (Bisphosphonate group)
  • It is not given yearly but administered every 3 months.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with nocturnal urination, increased urinary frequency, an enlarged and asymmetric prostate on DRE, ultrasound indicating an enlarged prostate, and a PSA level of 17 ng/mL. If prostate cancer is suspected, which lobe of the prostate gland is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior lobe

LOBES OF PROSTATE GLAND:

The prostate is divided into several lobes.

Anterior Lobe

  • The anterior lobe is used to describe the anterior portion of the gland lying in front of the urethra.
  • It is devoid of glandular tissue formed completely of fibromuscular tissue.

Median Lobe

  • The median lobe is a cone-shaped portion of the gland situated between the two ejaculatory ducts and the urethra.

Lateral Lobes

  • The lateral lobes (right and left lobes) form the main mass of the gland and are continuous posteriorly. The prostatic urethra separates them.

Posterior Lobe

  • The posterior lobe describes the posteromedial part of the lateral lobes that can be palpated through the rectum during a digital rectal exam (DRE).
  • The posterior lobe roughly corresponds to the peripheral zone, the sub-capsular portion of the prostate gland’s posterior aspect surrounding the distal urethra.
  • 70–80% of prostatic cancers originate in this region

 

Option A: Anterior lobe

  • The anterior lobe is used to describe the anterior portion of the gland lying in front of the urethra. It is devoid of glandular tissue, being formed completely of fibromuscular tissue.
  • It is not involved in the cancerous process.​​​​​​​

Option B: Median lobe

  • The median lobe is a cone-shaped portion of the gland situated between the two ejaculatory ducts and the urethra.
  • Median lobe is the site for Benign Prostate Hypertrophy.

Option D: Central zone

  • The central zone surrounds the ejaculatory ducts and is located posterior to the transition zone and the urethra proximal to the verumontanum.
  • It is rarely associated with prostate carcinoma.
  • However, the most common site for prostate carcinoma is the posterior lobe.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate his right arm. On evaluation, he cannot do abduction and internal rotation of the right arm. Which of the following muscles is responsible for both movements?
questions.solution:
Option B: Deltoid

  • The deltoid muscle is a large triangular-shaped muscle associated with the human shoulder girdle.
  • It originates from the scapula's spine and the clavicle's lateral third.
  • It inserts into the lateral side of the body of the humerus on a point known as the deltoid tuberosity.
  • The deltoid is composed of anterior (or clavicular fibers), lateral (or acromial fibers), and posterior (or spinal fibers). 
  • When all three parts contract simultaneously, the deltoid will assist in abducting the arm past 15 degrees.
  • It cannot initiate abduction because the direction of pull of the deltoid muscle is parallel to the axis of the humerus.
  • Throughout abduction, the anterior and posterior parts of the deltoid play a significant role in stabilizing the arm, while the lateral head assists in raising the arm from 15 to 100 degrees.
  • Paralysis of the deltoid muscle results in the inability to abduct and internally rotate the arm.
  • The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid. Both C5 and C6 contribute to the axillary nerve. The nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

Option A: Pectoralis major

  • The medial and lateral pectoral nerve supply it.
  • It adducts, medially rotates, and transversely adducts the arm at the glenohumeral joint.

Option C: Subscapularis

  • The subscapular nerves supply it.
  • It is involved in internal rotation and adduction of the arm.

Option D: Teres major

  • The axillary nerve supplies it.
  • It is involved in adduction, medial rotation, and extension.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl who emigrated from Pakistan 2 weeks ago is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of progressive weakness of her left leg. One week ago, she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. The patient has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right lower extremity and absent in the left lower extremity. Vaccination is integral for kids. Concerning vaccination, what is the principle on which vaccination is based?
questions.solution:
Option C: Immunologic Memory

  • The above given is a case of polio.
  • In this unvaccinated child, anterior horn cell destruction is the most likely cause of acute flaccid paralysis (weakness with decreased deep tendon reflexes).
  • Vaccination is based on Immunologic Memory.
  • Vaccination induces artificial active immunity. Therefore, Immunologic Memory is created.
  • Immunologic memory: specifically recognizes an antigen, the body has previously encountered and initiates a corresponding immune response.

Cells involved in immunological memory are:

  • Memory B cells
  • Memory T cells: both CD4 and CD8 T cells

Option A: Agglutination

  • Insoluble (Particulate) antigen binds to the antibody (at optimal temperature, pH, electrolytes) to form clumps.

Option B: Phagocytosis

  • Process of engulfment of particles and microorganisms by cells.
  • The innate immunity cell kills the pathogens by phagocytosis, followed by inter-cellular killing by different methods.

Option D: Clonal Deletion

  • By contact with self-antigens during development, self-tolerance is developed by clonal deletion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has been admitted to the surgical ward with a complaint of subacute intestinal obstruction. He is taken to the surgical operation theatre for the laparotomy under general anaesthesia. Inj. Propofol 100 mg is used for induction of anaesthesia; endotracheal intubation is facilitated with Inj. Succinylcholine. Ether is used as an inhalational agent during the intraoperative period. Which of the following would be least likely to be observed in this patient with ether anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rapid recovery

  • The recovery from the anaesthesia is usually slow for the ether anaesthesia.
  • Ether anaesthesia:
    • Ether anaesthesia has a major demerit of slow induction and recovery.
    • WTG Morton introduced diethyl ether in Boston on October 16, 1846, which is of historical importance but still widely used in several continents. It is a safe anaesthetic used by the open drop method on a gauze mask or in the plenum or draw-over vaporizers. It is commonly given from an EMO draw-over vaporizer.
    • MAC-1.92
    • Saturated vapour pressure at 20 degrees celsius-55 KPa
    • It produces excellent relaxation, so muscle relaxant is unnecessary. Using opioids and regional blocks reduces the concentration of ether, lessening the side effects. But the use of opioids makes postoperative nausea and vomiting worse.
    • It liberates catecholamines that maintain blood pressure with little cardiac depression, and cardiac arrhythmias are rare. Epinephrine is relatively safe with ether, and bronchial smooth muscle is relaxed.
    • Products of metabolism of ether-alcohol, acetaldehyde, and acetic acid are relatively nontoxic
  • Disadvantages of Ether:
    • Flammability in air and explosive in oxygen. Diathermy should not be used in airways because of the risk of fire or explosion, although this has not occurred when air is used to carry ether
    • High blood gas partition coefficient of 12-lengthens induction time and recovery
    • Airway irritation/laryngospasm, which also makes induction even slower. It stimulates salivary and bronchial secretions, so anticholinergic medication is advisable.
    • Increased salivation and postoperative nausea and vomiting
    • Sympathetic stimulation-maintains blood pressure with a low incidence of arrhythmias and increases blood sugar levels

Option A: Minimal cardiac depression

  • Ether anaesthesia causes sympathetic stimulation.
  • This effect maintains cardiac function and blood pressure

Option B: Hyperglycemia

  • Because of sympathetic stimulation, the patient's blood glucose level rises because of increased glycogenolysis.

Option C: Good muscle relaxation

  • The ether agent produces excellent muscle relaxation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to Gynecology OPD with lower abdominal pain, abnormal bleeding, and painful intercourse over the last 1 year. Her ultrasound shows a cyst pushing her bladder, causing difficulty with urination. She also reports nausea, vomiting, weight changes, and pressure in the pelvis. In the cut section of the ovary given below which is the ovarian tumor:
questions.solution:
Option C: Dermoid cyst

  • The above image is of a Dermoid cyst as tooth and hair are visible in the picture. Dermoid cysts present with abdominal masses and may manifest with pain or torsion. These contain components of all three germ cell lines.
  • The picture below shows the dermoid cyst.

​​​​​​​

  • 10-15% of dermoid cysts are bilateral.
  • Dermoid cyst / Benign cystic teratoma has all 3 germ cell layers present.
    • Endoderm: bone and teeth.
    • Mesoderm: sebaceous secretions.
    • Ectoderm: hair, endocrine glands.
  • They can have malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma.
  • These are the most common ovarian tumors in pregnancy. And most common ovarian tumors to undergo torsion.
  • Dermoid cysts are formed during fetal development when skin and skin structures are trapped.
  • Their cell walls are almost identical to the outer skin and may have multiple skin structures like hair follicles, sweat glands, teeth, or nerves.
  • Surgical removal of the dermoid cyst is the gold standard treatment for any dermoid cyst.

Option A: Serous cystadenoma

  • These ovarian epithelial tumors are filled with serous fluid and are usually uninoculated and bilateral. So, it is an incorrect option.

Option B: Dysgerminoma

  • It is the most common germ cell tumor of the ovary, and it is a large solid tumor, usually more than 10 cm, with a smooth outer surface. It is fleshy on the cut section, may be homogenous or nodular, and may have hemorrhage and necrosis.
  • According to the tumor shown in the picture above, it is not a true option.

Option D: Mucinous cystadenoma

  • Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-filled large ovarian tumor that may be as large as to occupy the whole abdominal cavity. So, it is a false option.

questions.text: A 26-week pregnant woman complains of vaginal discharge. During examination, a doctor finds a friable cervix that easily bleeds on touch. Microscopic examination reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. What is the best treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Ceftriaxone single dose IM + Metronidazole for 14 days
Ceftriaxone plus Doxycycline 100 mg for 7 days + Metronidazole for 14 days

questions.solution:
Option B: Ceftriaxone plus single azithromycin dose

  • The patient has symptoms and examination findings consistent with cervicitis.
  • Two important causative organisms are chlamydia trachomatis and neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Clinical presentation of cervicitis:

  • Mucopurulent yellowish discharge can be seen exuding from the endocervix.
  • Cervical oedema and hypertrophy.
  • Cervical ectopy.
  • A friable cervix that bleeds easily on touch.
  • It may be associated with symptoms of urethritis, bartholinitis, and proctitis.

Investigations for cervicitis to detect neisseria and chlamydia:

  • Grams staining of cervical swabs: gonococcal cervicitis shows gram-negative diplococci, while chlamydia cervicitis shows > 30 PMN per field in the absence of gram-negative diplococci. This test is not very sensitive or specific.
  • ELISA or DFA (Direct Fluorescent Antibody) detection is 60-80% and 80-85% specific, respectively.
  • NAAT: Nucleic Acid Amplification is the most sensitive and specific test (99%).

Treatment of Gonorrhoea:

  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM in a single dose + Azithromycin 1g single dose (doxycycline is used in place of azithromycin in non-pregnant women).
  • Alternative treatment: Cefixime 400mg orally in a single dose + Azithromycin 1g single dose.

 

 

Option A: Ceftriaxone single dose IM + Metronidazole for 14 days

  • Azithromycin must be added with ceftriaxone to treat possible chlamydial co-infection in gonococcal cervicitis.

Option C: Ceftriaxone plus Doxycycline 100 mg for 7 days + Metronidazole for 14 days

  • Doxycycline can be used with ceftriaxone in non-pregnant women with cervicitis.
  • But doxycycline is avoided in pregnant for potential teratogenic effects.

Option D: Ceftriaxone single dose IM

  • Ceftriaxone alone can treat the gonococcal infection, but there is a potential risk of chlamydial co-infection.
  • Therefore, azithromycin needs to be added.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the emergency department by his mother due to loose stools for 2 days. The patient passes 6-7 watery stools per day. It is not associated with a fever or vomiting. His mother reports that the child is irritable and only drinks water when given. Physical examination reveals sunken eyes and slow retraction of the skin. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre
Start IV fluids and IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.solution:
Option D: ORS with zinc for 14 days

  No Dehydration Some/Mild Dehydration Severe/Serious Dehydration
Consciousness Alert Irritable Lethargic
Eyes Normal Sunken Very sunken
Thirst Normal Drinks eagerly Unable to drink
Buccal mucosa Normal Dry Very dry
Skin pinch Goes back quickly Slowly Very slowly
Tears Present Absent Absent
Treatment Plan A Plan B Plan C
  • The patient presents with irritability, drinking water eagerly, sunken eyes, and slow retraction of skin, suggesting mild (some) dehydration due to diarrhoea.
  • Treatment for some dehydration includes Plan B:
    • Oral fluid resuscitation
    • Zinc for 14 days
  • The daily fluid requirement is calculated as follows:
    • Up to 10 kg = 100 ml/kg
    • 10-20 kg = 50 ml/kg
    • >20 kg = 20 ml/kg
  • Deficit replacement or rehydration therapy calculated as 75 mL/kg of ORS is to be given over 4 hours.
  • Maintenance fluid therapy to replace losses: This phase begins when signs of dehydration disappear. ORS is administered in volumes equal to diarrheal losses, usually to a maximum of 10 ml/kg per stool.

Option A: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre.

  • Urgent referral to the higher centre is made in case of severe dehydration.
  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • The absence of fever or blood in stools makes the bacterial cause less likely.

​​​​​​​Option B:  Give oral antibiotics and ORS.

  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • The absence of fever or blood in stools makes the bacterial cause less likely.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Start IV fluids and IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre

  • ​​​​​​​Urgent referral to the higher centre is made in case of severe dehydration.
  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • IV fluids are given in severe dehydration (PLAN C)​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1 female presents to the obstetrics outpatient department with a positive Indirect Coombs test with high titers. The mother is Rh negative, and the father is Rh positive. The physician is planning for umbilical blood sampling to detect the degree of fetal anemia and to plan further management. What is the ideal time for this investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
Option B: 18-20 weeks

Cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)-

  • Rh-positive father and Rh-negative mother are at risk of developing a Rhesus isoimmunisation, in which the fetus Rh antigen crosses the placenta and enters into the Rh-negative maternal blood, resulting in the formation of anti-Rh antibodies.
  • The positive indirect Coombs test means that the mother is sensitised by the Rh-negative fetus and has developed anti-Rh antibodies against the fetus's blood. This can cause haemolytic disease of the fetus.
  • Cordocentesis is performed when fetal blood is needed or when a rapid culture of karyotype is needed.
  • A needle is passed under ultrasound guidance through the abdominal wall and myometrium and, most commonly, into the umbilical cord at the point where it inserts into the placenta.
  • It is mostly done after 18 weeks and gives results in 24-48 hours, especially in these cases where transfusion is needed.
  • Mostly done to detect and treat blood conditions like fetal anaemia or thrombocytopenia.
  • Cordocentesis helps in the Assessment and treatment of platelet alloimmunisation and for fetal karyotype determination.

Option A: 11-14 weeks

  • CVS is performed during this time with less risk of miscarriages for chromosomal abnormality, but it is too early for cordocentesis.

Option C: 26-28 weeks

  • Too late for detection of isoimmunisation. Early detection is necessary for early transfusion.

Option D: 28-32 weeks

  • 28-32 weeks is too late for detection of isoimmunisation. For early transfusion early detection is necessary.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 33 weeks of gestation, presents to the emergency department with labour pains. She does not take any medications except multivitamins. Her previous pregnancy had ended in a spontaneous vaginal delivery at term. After all routine investigations and the confirmation of fetal well-being, she is started on oral nifedipine for the arrest of labour. All of the following may occur during the course of therapy, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
The correct option is: 3. Hyperglycemia

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to stop or delay preterm labor by relaxing the smooth muscles of the uterus. While nifedipine can have side effects, hyperglycemia (high blood sugar) is not a typical adverse effect associated with its use. The other options and their explanations are as follows:

  1. Tachycardia: Nifedipine can cause tachycardia (increased heart rate) in some individuals. It may lead to palpitations or a sensation of a racing heart.

  2. Hypotension: Nifedipine is known to cause vasodilation, which can lead to a drop in blood pressure. Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a common side effect of nifedipine.

  3. Hyperglycemia: As mentioned earlier, hyperglycemia (high blood sugar) is not a typical side effect of nifedipine. It is not known to have a direct impact on blood glucose levels.

  4. Fever: Fever is not a common side effect of nifedipine. If fever occurs during the course of therapy, it is more likely to be due to an underlying infection or other unrelated causes.

questions.text: After initially diagnosing a 50-year-old man with acute intermittent porphyria due to elevated urinary δ-aminolevulinic acid, a subsequent discovery revealed that 70% of his circulating red blood cells displayed increased levels of zinc protoporphyrin. What is the most probable corrected diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lead poisoning

  • Lead inhibits ferrochelatase (which increases zinc protoporphyrin III) and ALA dehydratase (which increases aminolevulinic acid).

​​​​​​​

  • It causes microcytic anaemia and basophilic stippling (rRNA aggregates) as it inhibits rRNA degradation.
  • Most common causes are low socioeconomic status; immigrants; exposure to lead paint and batteries.
  • If a deficiency exists, patients with lead poisoning should also be screened for iron deficiency and prescribed ferrous sulfate because iron deficiency can increase gastrointestinal absorption of lead.
  • It manifests as encephalopathy, abdominal pain, constipation, and behavioural problems, but sometimes, patients may be asymptomatic.
  • Chronic or long-term lead poisoning causes hypertension and nephropathy.
  • A diagnosis is made by measuring venous lead levels. The patients also have elevated serum zinc protoporphyrin levels.

Option A: protoporphyria

  • Protoporphyria also cause increased protoporphyrin due to mutation in ferrochelatase but cannot show increased ALA.
  • The main symptoms are skin photosensitivity but no neurological symptoms.

Option B: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria   

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is a rare inherited disorder due to a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen III synthase, causing hemolytic anaemia and photosensitivity.

Option D: Barbiturate addiction  

  • Barbiturate addiction manifests as slurred speech, drowsiness, lack of concentration, and misjudgment by stimulating GABA receptors.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the pulmonology ward with shortness of breath, a productive cough, chest pain, mild fatigue, weight loss, and a history of hypertension. She is a school teacher with a 45-pack-year smoking history. She is still an active smoker. On physical examination, she has mild dullness on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The chest x-ray shows a left hilar mass and a 5.4 cm left upper lobe mass. A CT scan reveals a hilar mass with bilateral mediastinal extension; no distant metastatic disease is found. The interventional radiographic test and biopsy of the lung revealed small cell lung cancer. Which of the following hormones was found to have normal levels in the case mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option B: Growth hormone

  • Clinical signs: Known smoker has a history of hypertension and presents with shortness of breath on examination, dullness on percussion, and reduced breath sound on further evaluation of bilateral hilar lymph mass, of course, suggestive of small cell carcinoma, which is not associated with growth hormone, so it remains same as normal and has no change at all.
  • Tobacco smoking is the most prevalent cause of small-cell lung cancer.
  • All lung cancer deaths (about 80%) result from smoking; even for small cell lung cancer (SCLC), this number is probably higher.
  • Small cell lung cancer is a tumour that characterizes differentiation of the neuroendocrine system and various types of hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), antidiuretic hormone (ADH), atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), arginine vasopressin (AVP), calcitonin, and serotonin.
  • These increased secretions of hormones lead to paraneoplastic syndrome development, and some symptoms include consciousness, weakness or disturbance that precedes other clinical features of cancer.
  • A growth Hormone is a central regulator for developing tissues and organs. It has anabolic as well as catabolic effects in a tissue-dependent manner.
  • Fluctuations in growth hormone levels are not associated with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) compared to other hormones.

Option A: ACTH

  • Small cell lung cancer is the most common cancer that secretes ACTH.
  • The patient's pituitary gland with small cell lung cancer releases a large amount of ACTH.
  • A large amount of ACTH stimulates the release and production of cortisol (a stress hormone).

Option C: ANF

  • Atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) is a hormone secreted by cardiac atria.
  • In small cell lung cancer, the levels of ANF are elevated because ANF inhibits the adhesion of tumour cells to pulmonary arterial and microvascular endothelial cells; ANF does it by suppressing the expression of E-selectin that inflammation promotes.
  • ANF prevents cancer metastasis and inhibits the adhesion of tumour cells to inflamed endothelial cells.

Option D: AVP

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) produces various mitogenic neuropeptides, usually not found in normal respiratory epithelium. Arginine vasopressin (AVP) is detected in up to two-thirds of SCLC tumours. However, normal physiological expression of AVP is essentially restricted to the hypothalamus.
  • In patients with small-cell lung cancer, hyponatremia can be caused by arginine vasopressin (AVP) tumour production. This results in the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old Asian woman comes to hospital complaining of occasional night sweats during the past two months.There is a nontender skin lesion near the right large toenail. A photograph of the lesion is shown below:



The examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Malignant melanoma

  • This patient's clinical presentation, such as a painless, irregularly shaped, brown-black pigmented macule involving the toe and nail bed, is consistent with acral lentiginous melanoma.
  • This tumour mainly affects dark-skinned and Asian populations. 
  • One subtype of acral lentiginous melanoma is subungual melanoma.
  • Subungual melanoma usually develops within the nail matrix and manifests as a longitudinal black or brown band.
  • Moreover, periungual pigmentation of the proximal or lateral nail folds can also develop, which is the Hutchinson sign of the nail. This sign is illustrated in the image below:

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

  • Squamous cell carcinoma can rarely involve the nail bed.
  • However, SCCs are usually small, red tumours that may result in paronychia, pain, and bleeding, as shown in the image below:

Option B: Traumatic subungual hemorrhage

  • Subungual hematomas may manifest as dark-coloured macules. However, this diagnosis is unlikely because this patient has no history of trauma to the foot and the absence of pain and swelling of the affected nail.

Option D: Onychomycosis

  • This patient presents with a single dark-coloured subungual macule. However, onychomycosis typically involves the whole nail and manifests as discoloured, such as white, grey, or yellow. In addition, brittle nails are also seen in the case of onychomycosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of bleeding per rectum, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping from the last month. On examination, vitals are blood pressure 130/80 mmHg, pulse rate 98 beats/min, and respiratory rate 18/min. The patient is evaluated and found to have ulcerative colitis. The patient underwent a colectomy. Among the following extraintestinal manifestations of disease mentioned above, which is most likely to resolve after colectomy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Clinical signs: Bleeding per rectum, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. It has extraintestinal manifestations, which could be treated in different ways, like colectomy.
  • Its chances of resolving after colectomy are 3% to 5%
  • Occurs in patients who are HLA-B27 positive or have a family history.
Extraintestinal Manifestations of Ulcerative Colitis
  • Arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)

 

  • Arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, erythema nodosum, and pyoderma gangrenosum typically improve or completely resolve after colectomy.
  • To maintain continence in individuals who need a colectomy, ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) or ileorectal anastomosis (IRA) is used.
  • Different extra-intestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis are shown below:

Option B: Primary Sclerosing cholangitis

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is least likely to resolve after colectomy.
  • 5% to 8% of patients with ulcerative colitis suffer from this.
  • Patients are younger than 40 years, and most are men.

Option C: Sacroiliitis

  • Sacroiliitis is one of the extra-intestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can help with sacroiliitis pain and inflammation. Colectomy is not needed in case of Sacroiliitis.

Option D: Uveitis

  • Uveitis is one of the extra-intestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis. 
  • Patients with IBD-associated uveitis are generally treated with immunomodulatory drugs such as
    • Methotrexate
    • Azathioprine
    • Cyclosporin
    • Biologic therapy, such as Remicade or Humira

questions.text: What is the primary action of sulfasalazine when used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Inhibition of NF-KB Activation

  • These clinical features are suggestive of ulcerative colitis.
  • Its mainstay therapy is sulfasalazine.
  • Sulfasalazine exerts its anti-inflammatory action by inhibition of NF-KB and inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

Option A: Folic acid synthesis

  • All cells require folic acid for development, produced by bacteria from the substrate para-amino-benzoic acid (PABA).
  • Sulfasalazine is unable to synthesize by this mechanism.
  • Mammalian cells are diffused or transported with folic acid (a vitamin in meals). By diffusion or active transport, folic acid cannot penetrate bacterial cell walls.

Option B: Formation of prostaglandins (PG)

  • After sequentially oxygenating arachidonic acid, DGLA, or EPA, cyclooxygenases (COX-1 and COX-2) and terminal prostaglandin synthases create prostaglandins. The traditional tenet is as follows:
    • The basal prostaglandin levels are caused by COX-1.
    • COX-2 produces prostaglandins through stimulation.

Option D: Formation of interleukins

  • Monocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, and CD4 helper T lymphocytes are responsible for most interleukins synthesis.
  • They support the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells, including T and B lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the Gynaecology clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual cycles for the last 4 years. She does not wish to take injections or daily tablets. She insists on a hysterectomy. Which of the following statements is irrelevant regarding the use of this device?

choices.text: Use as a contraceptive is associated with an increased incidence of menorrhagia
Not suitable for women with a history of hormonal imbalances
Irregular uterine bleeding can be a problem initially.

questions.solution:
The correct option is:

  1. Use as a contraceptive is associated with an increased incidence of menorrhagia.

Explanation of options:

  1. This statement is relevant and important information about the use of Mirena. Menorrhagia refers to abnormally heavy menstrual bleeding, and while Mirena is generally associated with a reduction in menstrual bleeding, some women may experience increased bleeding initially before experiencing a decrease in menstrual flow.

  2. This statement is relevant and accurate. Mirena is a long-acting intrauterine device (IUD) that provides contraception for up to 5 years after insertion.

  3. This statement is relevant as it highlights a precaution for the use of Mirena. Women with certain hormonal imbalances or conditions may not be suitable candidates for Mirena, and it's essential for healthcare providers to consider such factors before recommending its use.

  4. This statement is relevant and important information about Mirena. Irregular uterine bleeding, including spotting or breakthrough bleeding, is a common side effect, especially during the first few months after Mirena insertion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old P1L1 woman with secondary infertility presents for evaluation at the fertility clinic. Her husband's semen analysis report is normal. They have had regular unprotected sex for the past 18 months without using contraception. Genital examination shows no abnormality. On ultrasound abdomen and pelvis, no significant findings were present. Her hormonal profile was done on the second day of her periods. Her reports are as follows: LH 4 IU/L, FSH 4.8 IU/L, Anti-mullerian hormone 0.3 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
Option D:  Decreased ovarian reserve

  • This patient is presented with secondary infertility, having decreased AMH levels, normal LH and FSH.
  • Decreased AMH is a sign of decreased ovarian reserve (normal value >1 ng/mL)

Antimüllerian hormone (AMH)

  • Expression inhibits the development of the female reproductive tract in the male embryo.
  • It is secreted by granulosa cells of women's preantral and small antral follicles.
  • It regulates folliculogenesis by inhibiting the recruitment of follicles from the resting pool to select a dominant follicle.
  • Its level decreases with declining ovarian reserve. AMH is mostly used as a reliable marker of ovarian reserve.

Secondary infertility:

Infertility in a person who has previously achieved at least one pregnancy.

Causes of female infertility:

  1. Systemic conditions, e.g. Diabetes, thyroid disorders
  2. Ovary-related causes, e.g. menstrual cycle abnormalities, premature ovarian failure, diminished ovarian reserve, PCOS.
  3. Tubal/ pelvic causes, e.g. PID, endometriosis.
  4. Uterine causes, e.g. septate uterus, bicornuate uterus, leiomyoma.
  5.  Cervical causes, e.g. trauma, immune factors.
  6. Psychiatric causes e.g. viginismus

Diminished ovarian reserve

  • A decline in normal functioning oocytes by either a reduced number or impaired development
  • A normal consequence of age but can also be caused by an underlying disorder (e.g. endometriosis).

Option A: Disruption of the ovarian–hypothalamic-pituitary axis

  • The HPO axis is a tightly regulated system controlling female reproduction.
  • It is a condition of decreased gonadal function due to a disease that primarily affects the pituitary gland and hypothalamus.
  • HPO axis dysfunction can cause ovulation disorders.
  • If HPO axis dysfunction is present, the hormonal level of FSH and LH will decrease.
  • This patient's LH and FSH levels are in the normal range, so this option is incorrect.

Option B: Endometrial pathology

  • Endometrial pathology would not show reduced AMH

Option C: Increased androgen production from ovaries

  • In this condition, the ovaries overproduce the androgens, i.e. too much testosterone is produced.
  • AMH would not be low is such condition.

questions.text: A 34 weeks primigravida presents for routine check up and is diagnosed with IUGR. She is advised strict fetal monitoring and high protein diet. One week later she returns with absent fetal movements for few hours and now the doctor advices an antenatal doppler. Which of the following Umbilical artery doppler finding will most significantly predict the intrauterine death of the foetus -
questions.solution:
Option A: Reversal of diastolic flow

  • The question asks the most significant predictive sign of intrauterine fetal death (IUD) in umbilical artery doppler.
  • Reversal of diastolic flow most significantly predicts the intrauterine death of the fetus.

Umbilical artery doppler:

  • It is used to assess fetal well-being in high-risk pregnancies.
  • Abnormality in doppler is a marker of placental insufficiency and consequent fetal risk (IUGR, IUD).
  • The order of worsening fetal outcome is estimated in the following sequences:
  • Diastolic notching
    • Increased S/D ratio due to decreased diastolic flow
    • Absent end-diastolic flow
    • Reversal of end-diastolic flow: most ominous sign, requiring immediate intervention.

 

Option B: Absent diastolic flow

  • It indicates increased placental resistance and suggests poor fetal outcomes.
  • An absence of diastolic flow is indicative of severe fetal compromise and requires intensive fetal monitoring with NST and frequent doppler up to 34 weeks or occurrence of reversal of flow (whichever is earlier) after which pregnancy should be terminated

Option C: Absent systolic flow

  • It is diagnostic of IUD, but the question doesn't ask about the diagnostic sign but rather the most predictive sign.

Option D: Presence of diastolic notch

  • Diastolic notch is the earliest finding of fetal insufficiency and doesn't best predict the IUD.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with severe weakness and an unusual gait—his weight s 13 kg. On examination, a severely malnourished child is seen with bony abnormalities, as shown in the picture below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct anwer Option C: Rickets

  • Rickets is a disorder that develops due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • These deficiencies result in defective mineralization of the bones, making them weak and leading to skeletal deformities and short stature.
  • It is common between the ages of 6 and 36 months when children experience rapid growth.
  • Symptoms include stunted growth, short statures, bone pain, fractures, muscle cramps, teeth deformities, etc.
  • Skeletal deformities include pathologic bow legs (genu varum) and bead-like costochondral junction (rachitic rosary).
  • Rachitic Rosary is the Flaring Of anterior ends of ribs at the costochondral junctions seen in rickets.
  • The radiographic features of rickets include:
    • Splaying: widening of metaphyseal ends.
    • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis.
    • Cupping: increased concavity of metaphysis

 

  • The above figure demonstrates the expansion of the anterior ends of ribs on both sides.

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Neurofibromatosis

  • Group of genetic disorders that cause tumors in the nervous system
  • It is characterized by superior and inferior rib notching.

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Osteofibrosa cystica is a classic presentation of advanced hyperparathyroidism.
  • X-ray reveals extremely thin bones that may be fractured, bone resorption, ground glass, or salt and pepper appearance of a skull.

Option D: Coarctation of the aorta

  • Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital birth defect.
  • Inferior rib notching is seen in the coarctation of the rib.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of ionic bases of slow type of action potential?
questions.solution:
Option A: K+, Na+(funny), Ca2+(T), Ca2+(L)

  • The above-given case is Romano-Ward syndrome.
  • It is caused by a gene mutation that affects the ion channels around the heart.
  • There is no deafness in this disease.
  • There is a long QT interval.
  • The correct sequence of ions in the context of the spontaneous depolarisation of the pacemaker cells are K+, Na+ (funny) current, Influx of Ca2+ through Ca2+ (T) channels, Influx of Ca2+ through Ca2+ (L) channels.
  • At the end of every repolarisation, the autorhythmic cells in the heart exhibit spontaneous depolarisation to the threshold.

Action Potential in the pacemaker cells

Option B: Ca++(L), Ca++(T), K+

  • This sequence is incorrect because repolarisation via K+ efflux is the first step in depolarisation in pacemaker cells.
  • The second step is Na+ (funny) current through the Na+ channels.

Option C: Na+(F), K+

  • The Na+ funny is the second step of depolarisation in pacemaker cells.
  • The first step is K+ efflux.

Option D: Na+(F), Ca++(L), K+

  • The depolarisation in pacemaker cells and the K+ efflux is the first step.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby presented in the emergency department with the complaint of having the following rash for 3 days. She has just started weaning and has had a history of loose stools for the last week. Her mother gives a history of similar episodes among her siblings, too. On examination, there is alopecia. What should be given for the management of this disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Zinc

  • The recent shift to weaning, diarrhoea and positive family, along with physical findings of alopecia, suggest zinc deficiency.
  • A deficiency of zinc leads to Acrodermatitis enteropathica.
  • Rashes saw especially around the orifices.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a genetic autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It occurs due to a mutation in the SLC39A4 gene, which encodes the proteins involved in
  • zinc transport.
  • It is characterized by periorificial dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhoea.
  • Treatment is oral zinc supplementation within pharmacological doses.
  • Zinc is an essential trace element which plays a role in tissue repair, wound healing, carbohydrate tolerance, testicular hormone synthesis and immune responses.
  • The recommended intake is 2mg/day in infants to 9mg/day in adolescents.

Option A: Calcium

  • Calcium deficiency is also a common problem in children
  • It causes tetany, Rickets, and osteoporosis

Option B: Pyridoxine

  • Pyridoxine deficiency results in Peripheral neuropathy, refractory seizures, dermatitis, and microcytic anaemia.

Option C: Niacin

  • Niacin deficiency causes pellagra.
  • Pellagra is characterized by dermatitis (Casal necklace), diarrhoea, and dementia

questions.text: A 4-month-old neonate born full-term came to the hospital for a routine follow-up. Vitals and sub-vitals are within normal ranges. The pediatrician then performs a thorough physical examination of the baby and assesses all primitive reflexes. When he flexes the baby’s head forward, his legs straighten, and his upper extremity is flexed. Which of the following reflexes was tested?
questions.solution:
Option B: Symmetric tonic neck reflex (STNR)

  • Important Neonatal reflexes appearing after birth are parachute reflex & symmetric Tonic Neck reflex.
  • When the child's head flexes forward, extending the back of the neck, the upper extremities will contract and the lower extremities will extend. Conversely, when the child's head is extended backward, contracting the back of the neck, the upper extremities will extend and the lower extremities will contract.
  • This reflex appears at 4-6 months of age and disappears at 8-12 months.
  • This reflex helps the baby learn to use the upper and bottom half of their body independently of each other.
  • It helps the baby get onto their knees and hands, often called a crawling reflex.

Option A: Moro’s reflex

  • Moro reflex is a normal primitive, infantile reflex which consists of symmetric abduction and extension of arms, opening of hands followed by adduction and flexion of arms as in an embrace, and crying.
  • This reflex is established after 28 - 37 weeks of gestation and disappears at 5-6 months after birth.
  • It is elicited by placing the baby in the supine position on the examination couch and allowing the head to drop, supported by the examiner's hands.

Option C: Crossed extensor reflex

  • When one of the baby's legs is held in an extended position, and firm pressure is applied to the sole of the same leg, the baby's free leg flexes, adducts and then extends.
  • It usually appears at 30-34 weeks of gestation.
  • It disappears at 2 months of age.

Option D: Asymmetric tonic neck reflex

  • ATNR is tested when the baby lies supine and the head is rotated to one side. This causes extension of the arm and leg on the ipsilateral side and flexion of the arm and leg on the contralateral side.

  • It is present at 35 weeks of gestation and disappears at 5-6 months of age.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child, accompanied by his parents, is waiting restlessly for his turn to meet the child specialist in a camp organized in their village. The doctor noticed that the child was restless, agitated, and hyperactive throughout. He then prescribed amphetamines for the patient. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Impulsivity

  • The child is most likely suffering from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
  • ADHD is characterized by the following:
    • Inattention
    • Hyperactivity
    • Impulsivity
    • Other symptoms include destructive behaviour, irritability, and aggression.
  • Onset up to 12 years of age.
  • It is a neurodevelopmental disorder associated with impaired social, occupational and academic performance.
  • It may be associated with other personality disorders.
  • The first line of treatment is behavioural therapy in preschool children.
  • Medications are used as the first line after six years of age.
  • Most commonly, stimulants such as amphetamine derivatives are used.

Pharmacotherapy

  • Stimulants
    • Methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate
    • Amphetamines
    • Modafinil
  • Non stimulants
    • Atomoxetine
    • Bupropion Modafinil
    • Clonidine, Guanfacine
    • Venlafaxine

Option A: High concentration

  • Individuals with ADHD are very low in concentration, and they are inattentive.

Option C: Decreased activity

  • Hyperactivity is a characteristic feature of ADHD.

Option D: Mental retardation

  • Mental retardation is not seen in ADHD.

questions.text: A 9-year-old previously healthy girl presents to the emergency department with 4 days of dizziness, vomiting, and diarrhea. She is conscious, alert, and stable. Tests show severe hyponatremia (126 mmol/L), urine osmolality > 1200 mOsm/kg, and urine sodium of 47.9 mmol/L. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: SIADH

  • SIADH should be suspected in any patient with hyponatremia, hypoosmolality, and a urine osmolality above 100 mOsmol/kg
    • In SIADH, the urine sodium concentration is usually above 40 mEq/L, the serum potassium concentration is normal, no acid-base disturbance, and the serum uric acid concentration is frequently low.
  • In normal individuals, plasma ADH levels are very low when the plasma osmolality is below 280 mOsmol/kg, thereby permitting the excretion of ingested water. ADH levels increase progressively as the plasma osmolality rises above 280 mosmol/kg.

 

  • ADH regulation is impaired in SIADH; five different patterns have been described.
    • Type A is characterized by grossly elevated levels of ADH unresponsive to osmotic deviations.
    • Type B is characterized by an abnormally low osmotic threshold for ADH release (i.e., a threshold below the level of plasma osmolality at which plasma ADH becomes detectable in normal individuals) and a linear increase in plasma ADH in response to a rising plasma osmolality.
    • Type C is characterized by ADH levels persistently in the physiologic range and are neither suppressed by a low plasma osmolality nor stimulated by a rising plasma osmolality.
    • Type D is characterized by normal osmoregulation (i.e., ADH secretion varies appropriately with the plasma osmolality), but the urine is concentrated even if ADH release is suppressed.
    • Type E is characterized by a decline in plasma ADH as the serum sodium concentration increases during hypertonic saline infusion.

Option A: Water Deprivation

  • Water deprivation results in hyperosmolality of both serum and urine, which is not the case in the given scenario.

Option C: Central Diabetes Inspidus
