  • Serum osmolality increases and urine osmolality decreases in the setting of central diabetes insipidus, but that is not the case in this scenario.

Option D: Nephrogenic Diabetes Inspidus

  • Serum osmolality increases and urine osmolality decreases in the setting of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, but that is not the case in this scenario.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came to the clinic complaining of easy fatigability and generalised body malaise. A complete blood count revealed hemolytic anaemia and a creatinine level of 2.2 mg/dl. Ophthalmic examination revealed Kayser-Fleischer rings. Which of the following is correct about the above disease?

choices.text: Low serum ceruloplasmin, high urine copper
Low serum ceruloplasmin, low urine copper
High serum ceruloplasmin, high urine copper
High serum ceruloplasmin, low urine copper

questions.solution:
Option A: Low ceruloplasmin, high urine copper

  • The patient presenting with easy fatigability and generalised body malaise has Kayser–Fleischer rings which are pathognomic for Wilson disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation of the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13.
  • The clinical features include:
    • Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, hepatitis, liver failure, portal hypertension, and ascites
    • Hematologic: Hemolytic anaemia
    • CNS: Tremors, dysarthria, dystonia, and chorea
    • Eye: Kayser Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract
    • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure
  • Investigations for Wilson disease:
    • Serum ceruloplasmin: Decreased
    • Urinary copper excretion: increased to >100 μg/day (Normal <40 μg/day)
    • Serum free-copper levels: Elevated in early disease
    • Hepatic copper content: >250mg/g of dry liver weight
  • Treatment: Copper chelation therapy by Zinc, d-penicillamine and trientine

Option B: Low ceruloplasmin, low urine copper

  • In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin is decreased, but urinary copper is not decreased; instead, it is increased.

Option C: High ceruloplasmin, high urine copper

  • In Wilson disease, urinary copper excretion is increased, but serum ceruloplasmin is low, not increased.

Option D: High ceruloplasmin, low urine copper

  • In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin is decreased, and urinary copper is increased, not decreased.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male accident victim at the emergency room is in urgent need of blood. Because his red cell and plasma groups do not match, the blood bank is unable to determine his ABO group. The patient's emergency blood transfusion should include the following:

choices.text: RBC corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/ crystalloid
Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group

questions.solution:
Option C: O-positive RBC and colloids/crystalloid

  • If the blood group of the patient is known, an unmatched blood group from the same group can be used.
  • If the patient's blood type cannot be determined, red blood cells from Group O should be used. When utilised in women of childbearing age who do not want to be sensitised to Rh antigen, such unpaired blood should be Rh (–ve).
  • Rh-positive blood is used in the emergency transfusion of elderly females and males of uncertain blood groups since Rh-negative blood is typically in short supply. Sensitisation may occur in such instances, although the likelihood of an acute hemolytic reaction is limited.
  • Because the O blood group is the universal donor, it should be donated to this patient.

Option A: RBC corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/ crystalloid

  • The ideal treatment is to transfuse red blood cells corresponding to the recipient's red cell group along with crystalloids.
  • However, in the given scenario patient needs an urgent transfusion and his ABO blood group is unidentified
  • Therefore, the best option is to transfuse O-positive red blood cells with crystalloids/colloids because O-positive red blood cells are universal donors as they contain no A & B antigens to which the recipient's anti-A or anti-B antibodies could react.

 

Option B: Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group

  • In the given scenario, the patient's ABO group is unidentified. Therefore, the best way to transfuse is group O red blood cells rather than whole blood because donor plasma contains anti-A & anti-B antibodies, which can react with the recipient's A or B antigens.

Option D: AB negative whole blood

  • AB-negative whole blood contains A & B antigens and no anti-A & anti-B antibodies
  • When AB blood is transfused to either A or B-positive blood, the recipient's blood anti-A or anti-B antibodies react with A & B donor antigens. Thus, precipitating an AB incompatibility reaction.
  • Therefore, transfusion of AB-positive whole blood to either A or B-positive patients carries a high AB incompatibility transfusion reaction.
  • AB-positive blood should only be transfused to AB-positive recipients.
  • On the other hand, AB positive is a universal recipient as it contains no anti-A & anti-B antibodies to react with donor antigens

questions.text: The body of the 24-year-old German female tourist in Goa has been recovered. Prima facie, appears to be a case of abduction, sexual assault and death by suffocation. Both the conjunctiva showed signs of Bayard's spots. Which one statement among the following is true about Bayard's spots?

choices.text: Due to the rupture of arterioles
Well-defined, dark red spots seen over conjunctiva, subpleural surface of lungs, heart etc.

questions.solution:
Tardieu’s or Bayard’s ecchymoses/spots:

  • Round, dark-red, well-defined, pin-head sized spots, found in those parts where capillaries are least.
  • Supported, e.g. conjunctiva, face, epiglottis, subpleural surface of lungs, heart, meninges and thymus.
  • They tend to be better made out in fair-skinned persons, readily visible in fresh bodies.
  • It can be seen in other forms of death-electrocution, poisoning, coronary thrombosis, in persons on anticoagulants, with bleeding disorders such as scurvy, leukemia and thrombocytopenia, but distribution is more generalized.

questions.text: An investigator finds out that 5 independent factors influence the occurrence of a disease. Comparison of multiple factors that are responsible for the disease can be assessed by:
questions.solution:
Option D: Multiple logistic regression

  • In the given question, the investigator finds out that 5 independent factors influence the occurrence of a disease. So to compare these 5 factors one should use multiple logistic regressions.
  • Multiple logistic regression: Is used if the target variables are binary having only two possible values.

Option A: ANOVA

  • ANOVA: Analysis of variance is a parametric test used for the polytomous independent variable

Option B: Chi-square test

  • Chi-square test: is a non-parametric test used for testing association between 2 or more qualitative variables

Option C: Multiple linear regression

  • Multiple linear regression: Is used if the target variables are dimensional having multiple possible values

questions.text: A rural PHC reported cases of iron deficiency in the village. Which of the following is the best test to detect iron deficiency in the community?
questions.solution:
Option B: Serum ferritin

  • The Single most sensitive tool for evaluating the iron status is by measurement of serum ferritin.
  • It reflects the size of iron stores in the body.
  • Values below 10 mcg/L probably indicate an absence of stored iron.

Other options

Option A: Serum transferrin

  • This is not the most sensitive indicator for iron deficiency anemia.
  • Serum transferrin saturation: Normal value is 30%.

Option C: Serum iron

  • Serum iron concentration: Normal range is 0.80 – 1.80 mg/L
  • Iron deficiency anemia serum iron decrease.
  • Serum Iron depletes only after the Iron stores are depleted, so this is not the most sensitive marker.

Option D: Hemoglobin

  • Hemoglobin concentration is a relatively insensitive index of nutrient depletion.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department physician for four days because of generalized fatigue and dark urine. Four weeks ago, she was treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), and her blood pressure is 132/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 1+ pretibial oedema bilaterally. Her serum creatinine is 1.7 mg/dl. Urine studies show:


	
		
			
			Blood
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			Protein 
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			RBC
			
			
			12–14/HPF with dysmorphic features
			
		
		
			
			RBC casts
			
			
			numerous
			
		
	


A sample was sent for culture, and the organism showed a unique phenomenon given in the image below. Identify the phenomenon.
questions.solution:
Option D: Dienes phenomenon

The phenomenon in the above image is the Dienes phenomenon.

  • When two different strains of swarming, proteus mirabilis, and proteus vulgaris, encounter one another on an agar plate, swarming ceases and a visible line of demarcation forms. This boundary region is known as the dienes line.
  • However, if similar strains of proteus mirabilis are cultured on an agar plate, they are not confined/ restricted to boundaries and intermingle.

  • PROTEUS: Gram negative coccobacilli.

Option A: Antibiotic susceptibility testing

  • Microbiological test results assess a bacterial pathogen's susceptibility to various antibiotics.
  • The antibiogram reports the sensitivity of a pathogen as "susceptible", "intermediate", or "resistant".
  • Based on the antibiogram, the patient can be treated with targeted antibiotic therapy instead of empiric antibiotic therapy.

Option B: Swarming

SWARMS:

  • Swarming motility was seen on Blood agar, and Nutrient agar.
  • The image given below shows Swarming:

Swarming is inhibited by:

  • Increasing concentration of agar from 2% to 6%.
  • Addition of boric acid & chloral hydrate.
  • MacConkey Agar → Produce Non-lactose fermenting [NLF] colonies.
  • Fishy smell/seminal smell produced on culture media.

Biochemical test:

  • PPA test (Phenyl Pyruvic Acid) positive.
  • Tests the ability of an organism to produce enzyme deaminase.
  • PPA test +ve - converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid.
  • This test used to differentiate proteus, morganella, and providencia (Positive) from other members of Enterobacteriaceae (PPA negative).
  • The most common clinical manifestation of UTI (Urinary tract infection) leads to struvite/triple phosphate stones/staghorn calculi.

Option C: Nagler's reaction:

  • Exhibited by clostridium perfringens.
  • Due to alpha lecithinase.
  • Neutralization reaction.
  • Done on egg yolk agar.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy who has been on treatment for tuberculous spondylitis is now presenting with low back pain with difficulty walking. The image is given below. Which are the most common sequelae?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bony ankylosis (ankylosing spondylitis)

  • The above-given image shows the fusion of two vertebrae.
  • Bony ankylosis, also known as ankylosing spondylitis, is an inflammatory disease with abnormal stiffening and immobility of a joint due to fusion either by fibrous tissues or bone.
  • The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in the spine is bony ankylosis, and in contrast to any other site where fibrous ankylosis is the usual outcome, the spine is the only site where tuberculosis heals with bony ankylosis.
  • Physiotherapy and exercise can improve the symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • The medication to improve the symptoms include:
    • Painkillers
    • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
    • Ibuprofen

Option A: Fibrous ankylosis

  • Fibrous ankylosis is a disease in which the fibrous tissue intrudes into the condylar bone marrow by degeneration of condylar cartilage.
  • Fibrous ankylosis is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis hip, and tuberculosis knee.
  • Painful (because some movement is present in fibrous).

Option C: Pathological fracture

  • A pathological fracture is a condition in which the continuity of the bone breaks due to any disease.
  • Vertebral bodies (thoracic and lumbar) are the most often affected bones, followed by the neck of the femur and the lower end of the radius (collie's fracture).
  • The most common cause is osteoporosis, followed by metastasis.
  • In developing countries, the commonest cause of pathologic fracture is nutrition.
  • The most common local cause of pathological fracture is secondary to the malignant lesion.
  • The most common site is the thoracic vertebrae.

Option D: Chronic osteomyelitis

  • Chronic osteomyelitis is the infection of the bone that lasts for more than 3 weeks with no response to medication.
  • Above-the-knee amputation is recommended in chronic osteomyelitis with dead bone.
  • Complications: Amyloidosis and squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Paprika sign: While removing the dead bone, there is the presence of bleeding from the live bone underneath the dead bone, known as the paprika sign.
  • Sequestrum (dead bone) is the hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the physician's office complaining of shoulder movements. On examination, the physicians find a problem with the shoulder joint and difficulty performing the latter part of the movement, as shown below in the diagram. What root values of the nerve-supplying muscle are needed for the latter part of the following action?
questions.solution:
Option D: C5, C6, C7

Shoulder abduction:

  • Supraspinatus supplied by the suprascapular nerve causes the first 0° to 15° arm abduction.
  • The next 15° to 90° arm abduction is caused by the Deltoid muscle supplied by the axillary nerve.
  • Beyond 90°, the arm abduction is done by Trapezius and Serratus anterior muscles supplied by the accessory and long thoracic nerves, respectively.
  • Serratus anterior is innervated by the long thoracic nerve by the nerve roots C5, C6, and C7.
  • It protracts (draws forward) the scapula as a prime mover in all reaching and pushing movements.
  • The upper part with the levator scapulae and the upper fibers of the trapezius suspends the scapula.
  • The more extensive lower insertion pulls the inferior scapular angle forwards around the thorax, assisting the trapezius in the upward rotation of the bone (an action essential to raise the arm above the head).
  • In the initial stages of abduction, the serratus anterior helps other muscles to fix the scapula so that the deltoid acts effectively on the humerus and not the scapula.
  • While the deltoid raises the arm to a right angle with the scapula, the serratus anterior and trapezius are simultaneously rotating the scapula, thus raising the arm to be vertical.
  • Serratus Anterior is responsible for the latter part of abduction along with the trapezius.
  • The long thoracic nerve (Nerve of Bell) originates from the C5–C7 roots and descends in the axilla, posterior to the brachial plexus, to innervate the serratus anterior muscle.

Option A: C7, C8

  • Palmaris longus originates from the C5–C7 roots

    • Median nerve (C7, C8)

    • Flexes the hand

Option B: C8, T1

  • Flexor digitorum profundus Medial part & Lateral part

  • Originates from the C8, T1 roots

  • Flexes distal phalanges at distal interphalangeal joint

Option C: C5, C6

  • Teres minor originates from C5, and C6 roots Axillary nerve

  • Laterally rotates the arms and Holds the humeral head in the glenoid cavity

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with weakness on the left side of the face, inability to close his left eye, drooping of the mouth, and drooling of saliva. There is no wrinkling on the left side of the forehead. The rest of the examination findings are shown below.



The structure damaged in the given condition is responsible for all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Parotid gland secretion

  • The condition given here is Bell's palsy, i.e., lower motor neuron lesion of the Facial Nerve.
  • Parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland begins with the glossopharyngeal nerve, which synapses in the otic ganglion. The otic ganglion then provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland through an auriculotemporal nerve. This parasympathetic pathway controls the secretions of the parotid gland.
  • On the other hand, the auriculotemporal nerve provides sensory innervation to the gland, whereas the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the fascia.

Option A: Taste sensation of anterior 2/3rd tongue

  • Taste from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

Option B: Lacrimal gland secretion

  • The facial nerve controls the secretions of the lacrimal gland through the greater petrosal Nerve.

Option D: Platysma contraction

  • The platysma is supplied by one of the five terminal branches of the facial nerve called the cervical nerve. Therefore, contractions of platysma will be affected by Bell's Palsy.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented to your clinic with complaints of gait disturbance. He reports that it is difficult for him to get out of bed daily and do simple everyday tasks. His neurological examination shows muscle weakness and a gait, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely gait pattern?
questions.solution:
Option D: Shuffling gait

  • The patient in the above scenario is walking with a short stepping gait seen in Parkinson's disease.
  • A person's manner of walking is known as gait. In neurologic lesions, various types of gait disturbances can be seen. A specific gait disturbance is specific to the disease and can help diagnose neurological lesions. The types of gait seen in neurological diseases are as follows:
    • Shuffling gait is seen in Parkinson's disease, in which dopaminergic neurons have decreased activity in the substantia nigra of the brain's basal ganglia. Short shuffling steps characterize this gait. It is also seen in drug-induced Parkinsonism. It is associated with bradykinesia, resting tremors, postural instability (stooped posture), and decreased arm swing.
    • Magnetic gait (gait apraxia or frontal gait) is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus and frontal lobe degeneration. This gait is characterized by difficulty initiating forward movements of the feet when they are in contact with the ground. Damage to the cortico-cortical white matter fibres of the frontal lobe (e.g. in normal pressure hydrocephalus) can lead to gait apraxia (Bruns ataxia). Strength, coordination, and sensory functions are intact.
    • Cerebellar gait is ataxic, staggering broad-based gait. It is associated with cerebellar lesions signs such as dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria, nystagmus and Romberg's sign. It can be caused by cerebellar degeneration, stroke, drug/alcohol intoxication, or vitamin B12 deficiency.
    • Steppage gait or neuropathic gait is seen in foot drop. It is associated with excessive knee and hip flexion while walking, slapping quality of gait and recurrent falls. Distal sensory loss or weakness may be present.
    • Vestibular gait is an unsteady gait causing falls to one side. It can be associated with nausea or vertigo. It is seen in acute labyrinthitis or Meniere's disease.
    • Spastic gait is seen in cerebral palsy or multiple sclerosis. It is associated with leg stiffness and dragging the legs in semicircular motion while walking. Scissoring gait is seen in spastic diplegia.

​​​​​​​Option A: Neuropathic gait

  • Neuropathic gait is seen in foot drop when there is excessive hip and knee flexion while walking.
  • It is also known as steppage gait.

​​​​​​​Option B: Spastic gait

  • Spastic gait is seen in spastic cerebral palsy.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Broad-based gait

  • Broad-based gait is seen in cerebellar lesions.
  • It is also known as drunken gait or ataxic gait.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic for his routine checkup. He complains of difficulty in arm lifting during his work. The strength of the muscle is tested using an empty can test as shown below. For which of the following muscle this test is done, and what is its nerve supply?
questions.solution:
Option C: Supraspinatus C5,C6

The test shown in the video is for Supraspinatus (C5, C6)

Empty can test: This tests the strength of Supraspinatus.

  • The patient is asked to raise his arms to a position of 900 abduction,300 of forward flexion, and internal rotation(thumbs pointing to the floor, as if emptying an imaginary can)
  • The examiner applies downward pressure on both arms while standing behind the patient. The patient resists the downward motion.
  • The result is positive; if the affected side is weaker than the unaffected side, the result is positive, and a tear of the supraspinatus tendon is likely to present.

Option A: Infraspinatus C6the, C7

  • For the infraspinatus test the patient is asked to externally rotate both forearms against the examiner's resistance.
  • The test is positive when there is weakness or pain in external rotation. Infraspinatus tears are usually painless so external rotation weakness strongly suggests an infraspinatus tear.

Option B: Subscapularis C5, C6

  • The most common tests of the subscapularis are the belly-press test, the belly-off sign, the bear-hug sign, the lift-off test, and the internal rotation lag sign.

Option D: Teres minor C6, C7

  • Hornblower's Sign is used for the teres minor tear.
  • To conduct the test has the patient in a sitting position with the arm abducted to 90° in the scapular plane. Flex the elbow to 90° and instruct the patient to perform external rotation against your resistance.
  • A positive test results in the inability of the patient to externally rotate in this position.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of muscle weakness in the left hand. A diagnosis of the injury to the nerve which runs posteriorly in the arm and the forearm and hand is made. The suspected lesion is at a site where all the muscles supplied by the nerve are paralyzed. At which of the following sites is the lesion most likely present?
questions.solution:
Option A: Radial groove

Low Radial nerve palsy: Injury is before the spiral groove. All muscles supplied by the radial nerve are paralyzed. Low radial nerve injuries may be of two types.

1) Type 1: Injury occurs between the spiral groove and elbows.

Muscles involved are:

  • Elbow extensors (Triceps, Anconeus) are spared.
  • The wrist, elbow, and finger extensors are paralyzed.
  • There is a sensory loss in the first web space on the dorsum side.

2)Type 2: Injury occurs below the elbow joint.

  • Elbow extensors, brachioradialis, and wrist extensors, for example, extensor carpi radialis longus, are spared.
  • Finger extensors (extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis), extensor carpi radialis brevis, and thumb extensors (extensor pollicis longus and brevis) are paralyzed.
  • Sensory loss in the first web space (on the dorsal side).

Option B: Lower 1/3 of the forearm

  • Fracture of the forearm may lead to ulnar and radial nerve injury

Option C: Neck of radius

  • Posterior interosseous nerve: Damaged in injuries around the elbow, like elbow dislocations or radial neck/head injuries

Option D: At the wrist

  • If the median nerve is damaged by wrist injury leads to Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • In Guyon's canal syndrome, injury at the wrist leads to entrapment of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presented to OPD with a complaint of intermittent episodes of tachycardia for the last ten months. The patient is a known smoker with a history of 20 pack years. All the examinations and investigations are unremarkable. The doctor advised the patient to perform the following manoeuvre. Which of the following is the physiological effect of the scheme shown below in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Decreased venous return

  • The manoeuvre shown is the forced expiration against a closed glottis, also known as the Valsalva manoeuvre.
  • Decrease venous return occurs as a result of the Valsalva manoeuvre.
  • Individuals usually perform this manoeuvre during defecation ("straining at stool") or attempting to lift a heavy object.
  • In brief periods of straining, there will be changes in the pulse and blood pressure, and by monitoring them, the function of the receptors can be tested.
  • There is an increase in the intrathoracic pressure at the onset of straining, which is added to the pressure of the blood in the aorta, increasing the blood pressure.
  • Then, as the vein is compressed in the high intrathoracic pressure, the blood pressure falls:
    • Decreasing cardiac output
    • Decreasing venous return
  • The decrease in pulse pressure and arterial pressure inhibits the baroreceptors, causing.
    • A rise in peripheral resistance
    • Tachycardia
  • The combination of an episode of high peripheral venous pressure followed by a spell of elevated arterial pressure and pulse pressure is hazardous for people who are candidates for cerebral vascular accidents (strokes) because this combination may rupture a weakened blood vessel.

Option A: Increase in BP

  • A fall in BP is an effect of the Valsalva manoeuvre and not the increase in BP.

Option B: Decrease in HR

  • Valsalva manoeuvre results in a decrease in pulse pressure, and arterial pressure results in tachycardia. So, a decrease in HR would be wrong.

Option C: Increased stroke volume

  • The increased intrathoracic pressure that occurs during the Valsalva strain causes decreased venous return resulting in decreased stroke volume.

questions.text: A young woman enters puberty with around 40,000 primary ovum cells in her ovary. How many of these primary ova are ovulated during her reproductive life?
questions.solution:
Option C: 480

  • During puberty, at the time of ovulation, meiosis I completed, and the primary oocyte is converted to a secondary oocyte and first polar body.
  • After fertilization, the second polar body and ovum are released.
  • A mature ovum is released from the ovary during ovulation.
  • During her reproductive period, a woman will ovulate approximately 480 ova.
  • A woman will ovulate 12 primary ova per year as long as she is not taking oral contraceptives, does not become pregnant, or does not have any anovulatory cycle.
  • Assuming that a reproductive time of 40 years gives 40 x12 = 480 ova.

Option A: 40,000

  •  
  • The hormonal changes in the young woman stimulate the ovarian and menstrual cycles; 5 to 15 oocytes will then begin maturation to form ova with each ovarian cycle throughout the woman’s reproductive life.
  • All of the ova (40000) don't ovulate during the entire reproductive age.

Option B: 35,000

  • Most of the ovum doesn’t ovulate during the entire reproductive age, as a woman will ovulate approximately 480 ova. 

Option D: 48​​​​​​​

  • Although, all ovum doesn't ovulate during the entire reproductive age.
  • Approximately 480 ova will be ovulated, whereas the number of 48 is significantly few.

questions.text: Which structure is the most medial content of the cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Option D: Median nerve

  • The most medial content of the cubital fossa is the median nerve, which would be compromised in this case due to a stab wound.

  • The anterior aspect of the elbow has a triangular depression called the cubital fossa. The boundaries of the cubital fossa consist of
    • Medially: Pronator teres
    • Laterally: Brachioradialis
    • Superiorly: A line joining the medial and lateral epicondyles of the humerus
  • Supinator and brachialis muscles form the floor of the cubital fossa.
  • Brachial fascia, bicipital aponeurosis, subcutaneous fascia, and skin form the roof of the cubital fossa.

 

  • The contents of the cubital fossa from medial to radial side (mnemonic MBBR) are:
    • Median nerve
    • Brachial artery
    • Bicep brachii tendon
    • Radial nerve
  • Cubital fossa is bisected by the tendon of the biceps brachii, almost in the midline.
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally in the groove between brachioradialis and brachialis, and in the fossa, it divides into superficial and deep branches.
  • Brachial artery gives radial and ulnar arteries in the lower part of the fossa.
  • Median nerve is the most median content of the cubital fossa.

Option A: Bicep brachii tendon

  • Bicep brachii tendon is present laterally in the cubital fossa. Therefore, injury to the medial aspect of the fossa does not damage the bicep brachii tendon

Option B: Radial nerve

  • Radial nerve is the lateral most content in the cubital fossa, and a wound on the medial aspect of the cubital fossa does not damage it.

Option C: Radial artery

  • The radial artery is the terminal branch of the brachial artery and is formed in the inferior portion of the cubital fossa. It runs along the lateral aspect of the forearm. Hence, a stab wound in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa would not damage it.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic male came into your clinic complaining of sudden painless vision loss in his left eye, along with flashes and floaters. He says a curtain has fallen on his eyes. You do a fundoscopy and see the retina ballooning forward. A diagnosis of retinal detachment is made. Explain to your intern that the site of detachment is:

choices.text: Between the inner nuclear layer and the outer nuclear layer
Between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones

questions.solution:
Option D: Between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones

  • The site of retinal detachment is between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones;
  • It corresponds to the intra-retinal space between the inner and outer layers of the optic cup.
  • There is a space between the neurosensory retina and retinal pigment epithelium called sub-retinal space. The adhesions between these layers are relatively weak, making them susceptible to detachment.
  • Retinal detachment occurs when fluid from the vitreous compartment passes through a retinal hole and separates the pigment epithelial layer from the layer of outer segments of rods and cones.

Option A: Within the outer plexiform layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • There is no potential space within the outer plexiform layer.

Option B: Within the inner plexiform layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • The inner plexiform layer is not a potential site for detachment.

Option C: Between the inner nuclear layer and the outer nuclear layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • These two layers are not continuous, making it the least favorable option.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident presents with lower body paralysis and swelling of the spinal cord due to a vertebral column crush injury. Which structure would be trapped between the dura and the vertebral body due to the swelling of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior longitudinal ligament

  • A crush injury of the vertebral column can cause the spinal cord to swell.
  • The structure that would be trapped between the dura and the vertebral body by the swelling of the spinal cord is the posterior longitudinal ligament.
  • The posterior longitudinal ligament connects the vertebral bodies and intervertebral disks posteriorly and runs anterior to the spinal cord within the vertebral canal.
  • The posterior longitudinal ligament is weak and narrow.
  • It is attached to the posterior border of intervertebral discs.
  • This ligament holds the vertebrae firmly together but also permits a small amount of movement between them.

Option A: Anterior longitudinal ligament

  • The anterior longitudinal ligament runs anterior to vertebral bodies.
  • So, swelling of the spinal cord will not affect it.

Option B: Alar ligament

  • The alar ligament also lies anterior to the spinal cord.
  • So, swelling of the spinal cord will not affect it.

Option D: Cruciform ligament

  • The cruciform ligament also lies anterior to the spinal cord.
  • So, swelling of the spinal cord will not affect it.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, and overt blood in the stools. A complete blood count reveals anaemia with haemoglobin of 10 g/dL. A colonoscopy and subsequent colonic biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing lesion or disorder that leads to this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tubular adenoma

  • The patient is most likely a case of sporadic colon cancer.
  • Adenocarcinoma of the colon develops through a progression of mutations in oncogenes and tumour suppressor genes in a multi-step process.
  • Normal mucosa evolves into tubular adenoma with malignant potential resulting in carcinoma (Adenoma-Carcinoma sequence)
  • Most sporadic colon cancers (70-80%) follow this sequence and usually have left colon cancers.
  • The rest of the sporadic cases have defects in DNA mismatch repair or DNA hypermethylation (arise from serrated adenoma and develop more commonly in the right colon).
  • Carcinoma of the rectosigmoid (left-sided) colon causes early obstruction, with a change in bowel habits & decreased calibre of stool.
  • Carcinoma of the right colon (right-sided) can present late, with Iron deficiency anaemia due to chronic blood loss from the lesion.

Option B: FAP syndrome

  • Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome patients, often before age 30 and nearly always by age 50.

Option C: Hyperplastic polyp

  • Hyperplastic polyps are without malignant potential.

Option D: HNPCC syndrome

  • Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome patients tend to occur younger than sporadic colon cancers and are often located in the right colon.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady presents to the hospital with uncontrolled hypertension for the last 15 years. She was diagnosed with systemic hypertension at 30, initially controlled with amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. Her condition progressed, and she was later diagnosed with chronic kidney disease. She undergoes akidney transplant, but the graft fails to produce urine. "Hyperacute transplant rejection" is detected after a kidney biopsy. Which of the following immune and inflammatory mediators is this patient's primary cause of graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Option D: Preformed antibodies

  • Occurs within minutes to hours after transplantation.
  • Manifested clinically as a sudden cessation of urine output, along with fever and pain in the area of the graft site.
  • Patients can present with symptoms while still in surgery
  • It is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Preformed anti-ABO bodies in the recipient react with the ABO antigens on the surface of endothelial cells of the graft. Moreover, complement activation products also mediate this immediate rejection.
  • To prevent hyperacute rejection, the ABO blood group of the donor and recipient must be matched. Cross-matching test is necessary.
  • It is characterised by widespread thrombosis of graft vessels.
  • Thrombosis results in ischaemia and necrosis of graft vessels.

Option A: Cytotoxic T lymphocytes

  • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes commonly involve in acute graft rejection against donor cells. 
  • It presents in weeks to months after the organ transplant making this diagnosis unlikely.

Option B: Helper T lymphocytes

  • Helper T-lymphocytes are involved in acute or chronic graft rejection.
  • They are activated against donor Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs).

Option C: Mononuclear phagocytes

  • Mononuclear phagocytes and macrophages are involved in acute and chronic graft rejection along with T lymphocytes.
  • They are not involved in hyperacute graft rejection.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Option A: 

  • The picture represents Rigor mortis which is the early sign of death.

Option B:

  • The picture represents Adipocere which occurs in the late phase of death.

Option C:

  • The picture represents Postmortem marbling which occurs in the late phase of death.

Option D:

  • The picture represents mummification which occurs in the late phase of death.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of swelling and redness of the skin in the groin area, painless ulcers and constipation for 1 week. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. After further investigations, the diagnosis of Lymphogranuloma venereum was made by the physician. Which of the following inclusion bodies are present in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Miyagawa’s granulocorpuscles

  • This is a case of lymphogranuloma venereum in which the patient presents with complaints of swelling and redness of the skin in the groin area, painless ulcers and constipation for 1 week.

  • Features of LGV (Lymphogranuloma venereum):

    • Lymphogranuloma venereum is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3.

    • The Incubation period is 3 days -6 weeks.

    • Primary lesion: Papule, pustule, vesicles.

    • The number of lesions is usually 1.

  • Ulcers:

    • The diameter of the ulcer is 2-10mm.

    • The edges of the ulcer are elevated.

    • The depth of the ulcer: Superficial/deep.

    • The base is usually variable and non-vascular.

    • Induration: Firm

    • Pain: Variable

  • Lymphadenopathy: Tender

  • Complication: Esthiomene

Option A: Levinthal-Cole-Lillie (LCL) bodies

  • In Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies, micro-colonies will form and can be seen microscopically as cellular inclusions.

  • It is seen in chlamydia psittaci.

Option B: Halberstaedter-Prowazek (HP) bodies

  • It is seen during Giemsa stain of chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It is usually seen in the infection of the eyes caused by chlamydia trachomatis.

Option D: Henderson-Peterson (HP) bodies

  • Henderson-Peterson (HP) bodies are also known as molluscum bodies.

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies containing poxvirus particles, seen in keratinocytes.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of vaginal itching, discharge, and pain during intercourse. She has had 3 different sexual partners over the past 2 years. As part of the workup, the doctor did a wet mount of vaginal secretions that showed flagellated organisms with "twitching motility". Identify the organism
questions.solution:
Certainly, based on the clinical presentation and the description of flagellated organisms with "twitching motility" in the wet mount, the most likely organism responsible for these symptoms is Trichomonas vaginalis.

Correct options:

  1. Trichomonas vaginalis: This is the correct answer. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. It commonly presents with symptoms like vaginal itching, frothy discharge, and pain during intercourse. The characteristic "twitching motility" is due to its flagellated nature, which can be observed under a microscope.

Other Options:

  • Candida albicans: Candida is a yeast that can cause vaginal infections known as yeast infections or candidiasis. However, it does not exhibit flagellated motility. Symptoms include itching, white cottage cheese-like discharge, and pain during intercourse.

  • Gardnerella vaginalis: Gardnerella vaginalis is associated with bacterial vaginosis, a common vaginal infection. It causes a fishy-smelling discharge. However, it is a bacterium and does not exhibit flagellated motility.

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacterium responsible for gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection. It can cause vaginal discharge and discomfort, but it does not exhibit flagellated motility.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male immigrant from rural Brazil presents with a swollen face and extremely poor dental hygiene over the last 06 days. He also reports the loss of an adult tooth, which appears to be the focus of the current infection. On examination, two open ulcers on the outside of the swollen cheek appear to be small yellow ‘‘grains’’ in one of the ulcers. On histopathology, the gram stain shows purple-staining fine filaments. What is the most likely disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Actinomycotic mycetoma

  • Based on the clinical history, examination, and investigations, the patient is most likely suffering from oral actinomycosis.
  • Actinomyces cause it.
  • Actinomyces is a Gram-positive anaerobe that is not acid-fast and branching filamentous structures.
  • Oral actinomycosis has a triad of:
  • Sinus
  • Swelling
  • Sulphur granules

The picture shows two open ulcers on the outside of the swollen cheek, which appear to be small yellow ''grains''.

  • The most common site – is cervicofacial.
  • When sulphur granules crush and are under the microscope, there is a sun ray appearance.
  • Management:
    • High doses of intravenous penicillin G over two to six weeks, followed by oral penicillin V.
    • Surgery is one of the options for management if there would be persistent fistulas, necrotic tissue, and sinus tracts and if patients do not respond to medical therapy.        

Other Options

Option B: Chromomycosis

  • It is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by any of several pigmented fungi normally found in soil and wood.
  • It causes verrucous lesions over the body.

​​​​​​​Option C: Eumycotic mycetoma

  • It is caused by Madurella, which is not Gram-positive.
  • The grain contents show fungal hyphae.

Option D: Sporotrichosis

  • It is an infection caused by a fungus called Sporothrix.
  • It causes multiple ulcers along lymphatics after a thorn prick

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and left ear discharge from the last 5 days. The patient is febrile with neck rigidity and positive Kernig’s sign on examination. The doctor advised him of gram staining of his ear discharge. Gram-positive cocci are visualized in the gram-stained specimen of the discharge. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Gram-positive cocci) is the most likely pathogen.
  • The history and clinical features are suggestive of otitis media with meningitis.
  • Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are Gram-positive cocci (mentioned in the Question) but not common causes of otitis media.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most frequent cause of otitis media in children.
  • Causes:
  • Meningitis in adults
  • Typical lobar pneumonia
  • Otitis media, sinusitis
  • Conjunctivitis

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Causes:
    • Toxin-mediated illness
    • Skin infections
    • Acute osteomyelitis, acute mastitis
    • The most common cause of Native valve endocarditis
    • Right-sided valve endocarditis in IV drug abusers.

Option C: Haemophilus influenzae

  • Haemophilus influenza is a gram-Negative Coccobacilli.
  • Hemophilus influenza type b causes various disorders, including meningitis, bacteremia, and pneumonia.

Option D: Staphylococcus epidermidis

  • Associated with interventions - IV cannula, CSF shunts, prosthetic valve surgery, catheters.
  • Causes early prosthetic valve endocarditis [<1yr].

questions.text: A researcher plots a graph of cell membrane action potential. The graph shows various phases of ion permeation leading to a change in action potential, hence causing action potential propagation. Which among the following point has the greatest ratio of K+ permeability to Na+ permeability (P K+/P Na+)?
questions.solution:
Option D: F

  • Point F represents only K+ permeability, no Na+ permeability.
  • Therefore, the ratio of the permeability of K+ to the permeability of Na+ (P K+ / P Na+) is maximum at this point.

The complete graph

  • Point A: Resting membrane potential (the equilibrium potential of potassium ion is closest to the membrane potential)
  • Point B: Threshold potential
  • Point C: Due to Hodgkin cycle rapid Na+ influx voltage-gated gated channels
  • Point D: Na+ permeability maximum
  • Na+ equilibrium potential is closest to the membrane potential; Ratio of (P Na+/ P K +) maximum
  • Point E: Potassium permeability maximum
  • Point F: Only K+ permeability, no Na+ permeability. The ratio of (P K + / P Na+) is maximum

Option A: A

  • Point A represents the resting membrane potential (the equilibrium potential of potassium ion is closest to the membrane potential).
  • It does not have the greatest (P K+ / P Na+) ratio.

Option B: C

  • The Hodgkin cycle is shown at Point C, which involves fast Na+ inflow from voltage-gated channels.
  • Because the ratio (P K+ / P Na+) is not maximal.

Option C: E

  • Point E: Because potassium permeability is greatest at this point, the ratio (P K+ / P Na+) drops.

questions.text:
Which of the following best describes the acid-base disorder using the laboratory values mentioned below?

Plasma pH = 7.12

Plasma pCO2 = 60 mm Hg

Plasma [HCO3−] = 19 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Option C: Combined metabolic and respiratory acidosis

  • pH < 7.4, thus acidosis
  • Pco2 > 40 mm Hg, thus respiratory acidosis
  • HCO3- < 24 mEq/L, thus metabolic acidosis

Option A: Respiratory acidosis with renal compensation

  • It does not explain the HCO3- < 24 mEq/ as the value of HCO3- should be greater than 24 mEq/L as compensation for respiratory acidosis.

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

  • As the pH < 7.4 thus, it is acidosis rather than alkalosis.

Option D: Combined metabolic and respiratory alkalosis

  • As the pH < 7.4 thus, it is acidosis rather than alkalosis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child complains of mild greasy blemishes emitting a strong odor over the scalp, knees, elbows, and behind the ears and keratotic papules over the seborrheic areas. The histopathological examination shows corps ronds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Keratosis follicularis:

  • Darier disease consists of hyperkeratotic papules and plaques. 
  • Abnormal Keratinization below the Stratum Granulosum is seen in darier's disease.
  • These lesions develop in seborrheic and intertriginous areas
  • The condition commonly starts on the upper trunk or neck.
  • Rounded dyskeratotic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (called 'corps ronds') appear, which gives rise to small cells with shrunken cytoplasm (corps grains).
  • In darier's disease, Transversely elongated keratinocytes are present in the upper epidermis known as Corps grains.
  • Vertically elongated keratinocytes are present in the lower epidermis known as Corps ronds

Option B: Hailey-Hailey disease/ benign familial pemphigus

  • Occurs due to a defect in the ATP2C1 gene, which codes for SERCA (Sarco Endoplasmic reticulase Ca2+ ATPase).
  • Therefore, in this disease Ca2+ ATPase is defective.
  • Ca2+ is required for the attachment of two desmosomes.

Option C: Pemphigus Foliaceus

  • Defect in Dsg-1
  • Site of separation: Stratum granulosum (subcorneal Lesions)
  • Superficial bullae are present

Option D: Pemphigus vegetans

  • Rarest type of pemphigus
  • Variant of Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • MC Site: Axilla
  • Shows Vegetative / Rough keratotic lesions

questions.text: Which of the following would be associated with parallel changes in aldosterone and cortisol secretion?
questions.solution:
Option A: Addison’s disease

  • Addison’s disease occurs due to an inability of the adrenal cortices to produce sufficient adrenocortical hormones.
  • In a patient with Addison’s disease, there is a diminished secretion of both glucocorticoids (cortisol) and mineralocorticoids (aldosterone).
  • Primary adrenal insufficiency due to disease processes that destroy the adrenal cortex is called Addison disease.
  • It used to be a relatively common complication of tuberculosis, which is usually due to autoimmune inflammation of the adrenal gland.
  • The patients lose weight, are tired, and become chronically hypotensive. Also, there is diffuse tanning of the skin and spotty pigmentation, particularly at the skin creases of the hands and the gums.
  • Due to a deficiency of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids, the ACTH levels are elevated (from loss of negative feedback inhibition).

Option B: Cushing’s disease

  • When Cushing's syndrome is secondary to excess secretion of ACTH by the anterior pituitary, this condition is called Cushing’s disease.
  • In persons with Cushing's disease, cortisol secretion is elevated, but aldosterone secretion is normal.

Option C: Cushing’s syndrome

  • Hypersecretion by the adrenal cortex causes a complex cascade of hormone effects called Cushing’s syndrome.
  • When Cushing's syndrome is secondary to excess secretion of ACTH by the anterior pituitary, this condition is called Cushing’s disease.
  • In persons with Cushing’s disease, cortisol secretion is elevated, but aldosterone secretion is normal.

Option D: Conn’s syndrome

  • Conn's syndrome is a primary adrenal disease that results in primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • It occurs due to adenoma of the zona glomerulosa, unilateral or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia , adrenal carcinoma, or by Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism.
  • Excess mineralocorticoid secretion leads to potassium depletion and sodium retention, usually without edema but with weakness, hypertension, tetany, polyuria, and hypokalemic alkalosis. (Hyperaldosteronism).

questions.text: A physician examines a severely depressed 75-year-old woman. The woman relates that she feels so low that she cannot enjoy anything in her life, and that even winning the state lottery would not make her feel any better. The best description of this patient’s mood is
questions.solution:
• This severely depressed 75-year-old woman is showing anhedonia, the inability to feel pleasure, a characteristic of severe depression.
  • Euphoric mood is an elated mood, while euthymic mood is a normal mood, with no significant depression or elevation.
  • Dysphoric mood is a subjectively unpleasant feeling. Labile moods (mood swings) are alterations between elevated and dysphoric moods.

questions.text: A newborn girl is evaluated in the neonatology unit due to some concerning physical exam findings. She was born to a 27-year-old G2 P1 at 39 weeks gestation. Her APGAR scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The paediatrician notices a slit in her lipjoining the nose, polydactyly, and microphthalmia. Further evaluation reveals a genetically inherited syndrome. The given image depicts her lip defect. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trisomy 13

  • The case mentioned above shows that the newborn suffers from Patau syndrome and has features of cleft lip, polydactyly, and microphthalmia.
  • The image depicts a cleft lip, a typical feature of Patau syndrome.
  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) symptoms:
    • Microphthalmia
    • Microcephaly and mental retardation
    • Polydactyly
    • Cleft lip and palate
    • Renal defects
  • The diagnosis can be confirmed prenatally by chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.
  • There is no specific cure for Patau syndrome.
  • Management focuses on the treatment of symptoms

Option B: Trisomy 18

  • Trisomy 18 is Edward's syndrome.
  • Its features are:
    • Micrognathia
    • Low-set ears
    • Rocker bottom feet
    • Overlapping of fingers

Option C: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21 is Down's syndrome.
  • Its features are:
    • Palpebral fissures
    • Low-set ears
    • Providing tongue
    • Hypotonia
    • Single palmar crease

Option D: None of the above

  • The case mentioned above has features suggestive of Trisomy 13, Patau Syndrome

questions.text: A 63-years-old woman with a history of essential hypertension went to the emergency room with black, tarry stools. She discovered it two days before her emergency room presentation. Abdominal pain, tiredness, or weight loss were not linked to symptoms. Moreover, no significant risk factors, i.e. smoking, alcohol intake or family history of pancreatic cancer, were reported upon her presentation. The skin was paler as usual but otherwise ordinary. There were no palpable lumps and dark tarry stools on digital rectal examination. An upper endoscopy detected active bleeding stomach varices throughout the operation. CT Abdomen is shown below. The most frequently altered oncogene in this condition/disease is:
questions.solution:
Option A: K-RAS

Pathogenesis of pancreatic cancer:

Multiple genes are somatically mutated or epigenetically silenced in each pancreatic carcinoma
KRAS (chromosome 12p)
  • Most frequently altered oncogene in pancreatic cancer
CDKN2A gene (chromosome 9p)
  • It is the most frequently inactivated tumor suppressor gene in these tumors.
SMAD4 tumor suppressor gene (chromosome 18q)
  • It is inactivated in 55% of pancreatic cancers
  • Inactivation of the TP53 tumor suppressor gene (chromosome 17p) occurs in 70% to 75% of pancreatic cancers.

Option B: CDKN2A

  • "Cyclin-Dependent Kinase Inhibitor 2A" is what the name CDKN2A stands for. The gene contains instructions for many proteins that prevent tumour growth. On chromosome 9 lies the CDKN2A gene.
  • Several proteins can be produced using the CDKN2A gene's instructions.
  • The proteins p16(INK4A) and p14(ARF) have received the greatest attention.
  • Both act as tumour suppressors, preventing cells from proliferating and expanding out of control.

Option C: SMAD4 

  • SMAD4 is a highly conserved protein found in all metazoans. It is also known as SMAD family member 4, Mothers against decapentaplegic homolog 4, or DPC4.
  • It is a member of the SMAD family of transcription factor proteins, which serve as signal transduction mediators for TGF.
  • Making a protein that sends chemical signals from the cell surface to the nucleus is made possible by the SMAD4 gene.
  • The mutation causes Juvenile Polyposis syndrome (JPS).

 

Option D: TP53

  • The TP53 gene provides instructions for making a tumour protein p53 (or p53).
  • This protein acts as a tumour suppressor, which regulates cell division by keeping cells from growing and dividing (proliferating) too fast or uncontrolled.
  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a rare genetic condition that can increase your risk of certain cancers.
  • These cancers include breast, bone, leukaemia, and soft tissue, also called sarcomas.

questions.text: Regarding this dose-response curve, which parameter does the drug on the left side of the log DRC indicate?
questions.solution:
Option A: More potent

Dose-response curve:

  • It is a graphical representation of drug dose and effects.
  • The drug dose is put on the x-axis and the effects produced are plotted on the y-axis.
  • The DRC is hyperbolic in shape.
  • The log DRC is a sigmoidal shape.
  • Three important parameters can be determined from the DRC, including-
    • Potency→ potency tells which drug produces the same effect as another but at a lower dose. The left-side graph is a more potent drug than the right-side graph (see image below).
    • Efficacy→ efficacy tells the maximum effect of a drug. It is detected from the height of the DRC (see image below).
    • Slope→ Slope tells the safety of the drug as the more the slope, the less the safety.

Option B: More safe

  • Drug safety can be determined by its therapeutic index.
  • The higher the therapeutic index, the safer the drug is.

Option C: More efficient

  • The efficacy of a drug is determined by the height of the curve in DRC.
  • The more peak the curve, the more efficient the drug is.

Option D: Lower therapeutic index

  • The formula calculates the therapeutic index-

         TI = TD50 /ED50 [Here, TD50=median toxic dose, ED50=median effective dose]

  • A lower TI indicates a high-risk drug that requires close-dose monitoring.

questions.text: A rural PHC was screening the women population of the village for cervical cancer. PAP smear is used for screening. It is classified under which of the following level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secondary

  • Early diagnosis with a help of a screening test (PAP smear) is a secondary level of prevention.
  • The secondary level refers to an action that halts the progress of a disease.

Other options

Option A: Primary

  • It refers to an action taken prior to the onset of a disease, that removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur.
  • It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a health problem or disease.

Option C: Tertiary 

  • Tertiary prevention is defined as measures available to limit or reduce impairments and disabilities, and minimize suffering.
  • When the illness process is sufficiently advanced, this action is conducted.
  • Two types of intervention - disability Limitation and rehabilitation - can be used for tertiary prevention.

Option D: Primordial 

  • It is the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors.
  • It is done through health education.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the hospital with complaints of fever for the past 5 days and painful blisters on the left side trunk for the past 3 days. Initially, the blisters were small and fewer, but they eventually grew in numbers and covered the whole left half of the trunk. Which of the following characteristics is not appropriate for this condition?

choices.text: The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals
It can be associated with meningoencephalitis
Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay hunt syndrome

questions.solution:
Option C: Bilaterally symmetrical dermatomal vesicular eruption

  • Herpes zoster is also known as shingles.
  • It is a viral condition caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which has been latent in the sensory ganglia of the cranial nerve or the dorsal root ganglia following a prior varicella infection.
  • Varicella, sometimes known as chickenpox, affects children, but herpes zoster affects adults or the elderly.
  • Zoster is thought to be caused by the immune system's inability to control the virus's latent replication.
  • When the virus is reactivated, it replicates in neuronal cell bodies, and virions are shed from the cells and transmitted down the nerve to the region of skin innervated by that ganglion.
  • Zoster often begins with a fever, lethargy, and acute burning pain, followed by a breakout of vesicles in one to three crops over three to five days. Within a single dermatome, lesions are dispersed unilaterally.
  • PCR testing of a corneal lesion, vesicular fluid, or blood in ocular involvement or widespread infection cases.
  • The vesicular fluid Tzanck smear indicates multinucleated giant cells.
  • Antiviral medication helps accelerate the resolution of lesions, reduces excruciating pain, and aids in preventing post-herpetic neuralgia, particularly in the elderly. 
  • The antiviral medications used to treat herpes zoster include acyclovir 800 mg, five times daily for five days; valacyclovir 1 gm, three times daily for five days; and famciclovir 500 mg, three times daily for seven days.

Option A: The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals

  • Varicella-zoster virus-specific IgM antibody is identified in blood during active chickenpox or shingles infection but not when the virus is latent.
  • The virus can be spread by direct skin contact or breathing contaminated droplets.
  • Seronegative people who come into touch with these patients can get chicken pox.

Option B. It can be associated with meningoencephalitis

  • Secondary bacterial infection, post-herpetic neuralgia, scarring, nerve palsy, and encephalitis are all possible complications of herpes zoster.
  • Because the neurological system is involved, complications such as cranial neuropathies, polyneuritis, myelitis, aseptic meningitis, meningoencephalitis or partial facial paralysis might ensue.

Option D: Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay hunt syndrome

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome type II is another name for shingles oticus.
  • It is caused by the virus moving from the facial nerve to the vestibulocochlear nerve, which affects the ear and causes hearing loss and vertigo (rotational dizziness).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old boy is diagnosed with meningitis. The chief resident discusses the causes of papilledema with his junior residents. He puts forward the following statements regarding this case:

Assertion: Increased intracranial pressure can lead to a choked disc, but it doesn't affect the pituitary gland.

Reason: Meninges, along with subdural and subarachnoid spaces, run along the entire course of the optic nerve, but these spaces cease at the margins of diaphragma sellae.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.solution:
Option A: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient presented with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure due to meningitis. The increased pressure causes headache, vomiting, and papilledema, as shown. On the other hand, a history of high-grade fever and neck stiffness suggests meningitis. The CSF analysis indicates bacterial meningitis.
  • The dura mater of the brain extends as a sheath around the optic nerve and then connects with the eye's sclera. The retinal artery and vein pierce the optic sheath a few millimeters behind the eye and then pass along with the fibers of the optic into the eye itself.
  • As the cerebrospinal fluid pressure increases, the pressure inside the optic nerve sheath increases and rises along the spaces between the optic nerve fibers to the eyeball's interior.
  • Increased pressure decreases outward fluid flow in the optic nerves, causing accumulation of excess fluid in the optic disc at the retina's center. Moreover, the blood flow in the retinal vein is impeded, increasing the retinal capillary pressure throughout the eye and hence causing retinal edema.
  • The tissues of the optic disc are more distensible than those of the remainder of the retina. Hence, the disc is far more edematous. The swelling of the optic disc is viewed as “papilledema” (chocked disc) by an ophthalmoscope.
  • Three protective coverings of the brain are meninges, with two spaces between them containing the CSF. The layers are dura, arachnoid, and pia mater, while the spaces are subarachnoid space (between arachnoid and pia) and subdural (between dura and arachnoid).
  • The diaphragma sellae is a circular, horizontal sheet of dura mater that forms the roof of sella turcica and covers the pituitary gland. It separates the pituitary gland from the subdural space. Hence, the three meninges and the two spaces do not cross the margins of the diaphragma sellae. It is an important anatomical landmark for surgical intervention as well. Hence, option A is correct.

Option B: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

  • The increased intracranial pressure causes swelling of the optic disc resulting in papilledema; however, it will not affect the function of the pituitary gland.
  • The meningeal coverings and the subarachnoid and subdural spaces are present along the optic nerve fibers to the eyeball's interior, resulting in edema.
  • But these coverings, along with spaces, do not cross the margins of the diaphragma sellae (dural covering of pituitary) and therefore do not affect its function.
  • Hence, “Reason” is the correct explanation for "Assertion," and this option is incorrect.

Option C: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

  • The increased CSF pressure results in swelling of the optic disc but does not affect the pituitary gland and its function.
  • It is because the meninges run along the entire course of the optic nerve fibers but cease at the margins of the dural covering of the pituitary gland.
  • Therefore, “Reason” is independently a true/correct statement, and this option is incorrect.

Option D: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

  • Increased intracranial pressure does not affect the function of the pituitary gland. However, it does cause an increase in pressure of the spaces between the optic sheath resulting in a choked disc.
  • Therefore, “Assertion” is independently a true/correct statement, and this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 26 weeks presented for an antenatal check-up. A routine check-up showed a platelet count of 1,40,000 per microliter. She has no fever or any other complaint. Her Blood pressure, liver, and renal functions were normal. A repeat platelet count after a month showed similar counts. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Only monitor platelet counts

Gestational thrombocytopenia

  • In gestational thrombocytopenia, there is a decrease in platelet counts, which in most cases is moderate (130-150,000/microliter).
  • An increase in total body fluid levels in pregnancy leads to hemodilution. As a result, the platelet concentration is partially decreased.
  • It manifests typically in the second half of pregnancy, and the counts return to normal within the first two months postpartum.
  • Platelet consumption is likely augmented because of splenic enlargement
  • Counts are never below 70,000/cu.mm and return to normal levels after delivery. Levels below 50,000/microliter account for causes other than gestational thrombocytopenia.
  • Management involves periodic platelet count monitoring and does not pose a risk to the mother or the foetus.

Option A: Start prednisolone therapy

  • Prednisolone therapy is for those suspected of immune thrombocytopenic purpura; the counts are between 50,000 and 80,000 per microliter. Steroids such as prednisolone have no therapeutic benefit in gestational thrombocytopenia, and the absence of response reports such a diagnosis.

Option B: Test for autoimmune diseases

  • The platelet count in this patient is isolated and moderate (140,000) and has no signs of systemic autoimmune disease: joint pains, swelling, rash, and skin changes. Immune thrombocytopenia is considered when the platelet counts are between 50,000 to 80,000 per microliter.

Option D: Advise papaya leaf extract

  • Papaya leaf extract may help to treat chronic immune thrombocytopenia and Dengue fever-related thrombocytopenia as it increases platelet counts.
  • However, this patient’s thrombocytopenia is due to hemodilution related to the volume expansion of pregnancy. No treatment is advised for such patients except for periodic platelet count monitoring.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology department with the complaint of blurring of vision in his right eye. He does not have any systemic disease. On examination, right-sided corneal opacity covering the pupil is noted. The doctor decides to administer azithromycin because he suspects which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trachoma

  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • In trachoma, the tear's pH is acidic.
    • Conjunctival congestion is seen in the upper tarsal and forniceal conjunctiva, and papillary hyperplasia seen.
    • Hallmark: sago grain follicles.
    • Conjunctival scarring - Linear scar present in sulcus subtarsalis – Arlt's line.
    • Herbert's follicles - present at the limbus, Herbet's pits seen -oval/ circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert's follicles.
    • Pannus: Progressive (infiltration of the cornea is ahead of vascularisation) or regressive.
    • Superficial keratitis and corneal opacity may be found.
    • Corneal scarring is the main cause of blindness in trachoma.
    • Trichiasis and cicatricial entropion may be seen.
  • WHO classification (FISTO) :

1. TF : Trachomatous inflammation - follicular

2. TI : Trachomatous inflammation - Intense

3. TS : Trachomatous Scarring

4. TT : Trachomatous trichiasis

5. CO : Corneal opacity

  • Serotypes
    • A,B,C- Hyperendemic Trachoma
    • D, K- Inclusion Trachoma
  • Treatment
    • DOC: 1gm Azithromycin Single Dose.
    • Other options: Doxycycline 100 mg BD 3-4 weeks.
    • Topical therapy: Tetracycline Ointment (1 %) or erythromycin (1%) four times a day for 6 weeks.
    • Combined topical and systemic therapy - Preferred when the ocular infection is severe (TI) or when there is associated genital infection.

Option A: Herpes keratitis

  • The hallmark of HSV keratitis is the presence of multiple small branching epithelial dendrites on the surface of the cornea.
  • Acyclovir is given instead of azithromycin.

Option C: Pterygium

  • The treatment used for the pterygium is the bare sclera technique.
  • Mitomycin can be used.

Option D: Cataract

  • A surgical extraction is the treatment of choice for the cataract.
  • Moreover, lens opacity rather than corneal opacity is found in cataracts.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the patient because he cannot see clearly near objects. His present reading glasses are 5 years old. He is otherwise fit. On further examination, his pupillary reflex response is normal, and anterior segment examination is normal with deep AC. IOP as 28 and 30mmhg in the right eye and left eye, respectively. You decided to check their patient's visual field to confirm the glaucoma diagnosis. Which of the following is the gold standard for detecting visual field defects?
questions.solution:
Option A: Humphrey field perimeter

  • Diagnosis of glaucoma field defect is best made by Humphrey field perimeter (Gold standard).

  • EARLIEST VISUAL FIELD DEFECT- PARA CENTRAL SCOTOMA.

  • The visual field is an area of space visible to the human eye without moving the eye from the central target.

  • Rule of thumb: Earliest visual field defect in glaucoma always begins from close to the centre, i.e. Paracentral > Bjerrum > Generalized constriction.

Extra edge:

  • In glaucoma, the Temporal visual field is the last visual field to be affected.

Option B: Goldmann perimeter

  • Goldmann perimetry is a form of kinetic perimetry: a stimulus is moved from beyond the edge of the visual field into the field.

  • The location at which the stimulus is first seen marks the outer perimeter of the visual field for the size of the stimulus tested.

  • Automated perimetry was developed in the 1970s.

  • It requires the examiner to move the target at the same speed in each direction.

Option C: Listers perimeter

  • Automatically records the field to 90 degrees in all meridians.

  • The carrier mechanism is smooth, silent and invisible.

  • The patient perceives only the test object to move.

  • Spring check :An audible click to every 15 degrees of arc rotation in either direction.

Option D: Bjerrum screen

  • A flat, usually black surface is used to measure the central 30 degrees of the field of vision.

  • Synonym(s): tangent screen.

  • The Bjerrum Tangent Screen is a flat, usually black surface used to measure the central 30 degrees of the visual field.

  • The Bjerrum screen is made of black matte material and stitched with radial lines at 15-degree intervals and circles at 5-degree intervals.

  • For use at 1 meter with Traquair or similar stimuli.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a history of intellectual disability and seizure comes to the doctor with a month of shortness of breath. His BP is 138/82 mm Hg, his pulse is 75/min, and his BMI is 21 kg/m2.On physical examination, the doctor notices numerous papules on the boy's face. In addition, echocardiography shows tumour-like growth in the left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient heart condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rhabdomyoma

  • Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by developing hamartomas and benign neoplasms involving the brain and other tissues.
  • The most frequent clinical manifestations are seizures, autism, and mental retardation.
  • Hamartomas within the CNS take the form of cortical tubers, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant-cell astrocytomas.
  • Half of the patients with tuberous sclerosis develop rhabdomyomas, primary tumours of cardiac muscle that, although benign, may compromise cardiac function.
  • They may be found on atrioventricular valves or ventricle walls, causing outflow obstruction.
  • The nuclei of the rhabdomyoma cells are central or eccentrically located. In some cells, eosinophilic septa stretch from the cell membrane to a centrally placed nucleus, imparting a spiderlike appearance to the cell known as 'spider cells'
  • Spider cells are pathognomonic for cardiac rhabdomyomas and represent degenerating rhabdomyocytes.

Image showing spider cells

Option A: Lipoma​​​​​​​

  • Lipoma can create ball valve obstruction, and with a history suggesting tuberous sclerosis, a lipoma is less likely.​​​​​​​

Option B: Myxomas​​​​​​​

  • Myxomas are almost exclusively seen in adults and are usually located in the atria, making this a less likely diagnosis.

Option D: Dilated cardiomyopathy

  • Dilated cardiomyopathy involves hypertrophy, dilation, and eventually heart failure and is not associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling in both knees for the past day. He finished a cycle of chemotherapy 1 week ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of both knees and the base of his left big toe, as shown in the picture below.

 



The symptoms started a day before presenting to the clinic. Serum uric acid is raised. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating this condition? Laboratory studies show:


	
		
			
			Leukocyte count
			
			
			13,000/mm3
			
		
		
			
			Serum uric level
			
			10 mg/dL
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			2.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			8.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Phosphorus
			
			
			7.2 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Option A: Indomethacin

  • The clinical condition shown is Acute Gout. DOC for acute Gout is NSAIDs like Indomethacin.
  • The other drugs mentioned are used in the treatment of chronic Gout.

Gout:

  • An inflammatory crystal arthropathy is caused by the precipitation and deposition of uric acid crystals in synovial fluid and tissues.
  • It is typically associated with hyperuricemia but can also occur if uric acid levels are normal.
  • Hyperuricemia can be caused by the following:
  • Underexcretion of uric acid (90% of patients)—largely idiopathic, potentiated by renal failure; can be exacerbated by certain medications (e.g., thiazide diuretics).
  • Overproduction of uric acid (10% of patients)—Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, PRPP excess, cell turnover (e.g., tumour lysis syndrome), von Gierke disease.
  • Crystals are needle-shaped and negative birefringent under polarized light (yellow under parallel light, blue under perpendicular light.

  • Acute severe pain with overlying erythema decreased range of motion, swelling, and warmth.
  • Possibly fever.
  • The joint is swollen, red, and painful. Classic manifestation is the painful metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) of the big toe (podagra).
  • Gonagra: inflammation of the knee.
  • Chiragra: inflammation of finger joints, especially the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb 
  • Others: ankle, tarsus, other toe joints, wrist, elbow

Management of Gout:

  • Acute Gout is managed by using the following:
  • NSAIDs (e.g. indomethacin)
  • glucocorticoids (oral, intra-articular, or parenteral)
  • Colchicine: binds and stabilizes tubulin to inhibit microtubule polymerization, impairing neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation. It has acute and prophylactic value.
  • Chronic Gout is treated by using the following drugs:
  • Probenecid inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule. Can precipitate uric acid calculi.
  • Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase competitively, decreasing the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to urate.
  • Also used in lymphoma and leukaemia to prevent tumour lysis–associated urate nephropathy. It increases the concentrations of xanthine oxidase active metabolites, azathioprine, and 6-MP

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a long history of cigarette smoking presents with gangrene of the left foot.  An amputation of the left foot is done. A representative section from the specimen reveals the presence of arterial thrombi with neutrophilic infiltrate in the arterial wall. The inflammation also extends into the neighbouring veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option C: Thromboangiitis obliterans

  • BUERGER’S DISEASE (Thromboangiitis obliterans) is a segmental inflammatory disease affecting small and medium-sized arteries in the upper and lower extremities.
  • In this case, the patient presents with left foot gangrene, for which amputation of the left foot was done.
  • It is typically seen in young male smokers.
  • It is an inflammatory process that involves neighbouring veins and nerves. Thrombus contains micro abscess.
  • Treatment is total abstinence from smoking and amputation may require in advance of the disease.
  • Buerger's disease is a very rare disorder that, in most cases, affects young or middle-aged male cigarette smokers with onset of symptoms before 40-45 years of age.

Other Options

Option A: Takayasu arteritis

  • Takayasu arteritis is an arteritis of large vessels. It usually originates from the aortic arch.
  • It can lead to an aneurysm and a tear in vessel walls.

Option B: Temporal arteritis

  • Temporal arteritis is also known as giant cell arteritis. It is characterized by arterial occlusion secondary to infiltration and inflammation.
  • It is characterized by headache and palpable, pulseless arteries in the scalp. 
  • The ophthalmic artery becomes occlusion may lead to irreversible blindness.

Option D: Raynaud’s disease

  • It is an idiopathic condition that occurs in a young female, characterized by vasoconstriction of the arterioles of fingers, turning white.
  • Later on, vasodilation occurs, and digits become swollen.
