  • Treatment of Raynaud’s disease is protection from cold and calcium channel blockers such as nifedipine.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant female visited the sub-center for her check-up. Which of the following test is done at Sub-centre during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Haemoglobin

  • Of all the mentioned above, Hemoglobin level estimation can be done at Sub center.

Tests done at Sub center:

  • Pregnancy detection test
  • Hemoglobin level estimation
  • Urine test for albumin and sugar
  • Rapid malaria test

Option A: USG

  • USG is done at PHC/CHC/DH levels.

Option C: OGTT

  • One technique for determining a person's apparent insulin sensitivity and insulin resistance is the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).
  • It is not done at the sub-center level.

Option D: Triple test

  • The triple screen test is a maternal blood screening examination that tests for AFP, hCG, and estriol.
  • Its goal is to SCREEN the developing infant for potential neural tube abnormalities, Down syndrome, and Trisomy 18.
  • It is not done at the sub-center level.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with Parkinson's is admitted with abdominal pain, irregular bowel movements, and weight loss, all associated with occasional flushing episodes for the past ten months. Physical examination revealed spider-like facial veins, and hepatomegaly. Urinary 5-HIAA level is 320 mg/24 h (range1200 ng/ml (range<98 ng/ml). A barium enema revealed a filling defect in the ileocecal valve. Which of the following is correct regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Omeprazole injection reduces symptoms of flushing and diarrhea
It occurs when the tumours metastasize to the adrenal gland
Pale-looking skin is a typical feature

questions.solution:
Option A: Occurs in <10% of carcinoid tumours

  • The given condition with elevated 5-HIAA and chromogranin A indicates carcinoid syndrome.
  • Carcinoid syndrome occurs in <10% of patients with carcinoid tumours.
  • Intestinal carcinoid tumours / neuroendocrine tumours (NET) arise from enterochromaffin cells located at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They occur most commonly in the appendix, ileum, and rectum.
  • They produce a number of vasoactive peptides, most commonly serotonin, but also histamine, prostaglandin, and kallikrein.
  • When they metastasize to the liver, carcinoid syndrome becomes evident.

Option B: Omeprazole injection reduces symptoms of flushing and diarrhea

  • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor and has no role in reducing the symptoms of flushing and diarrhea.
  • These symptoms can be reduced by octreotide injection in carcinoid syndrome.
  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analog. It reduces GI motility, inhibits gastric acid secretion, and decreases IG mucosal blood flow.

 

Option C: It occurs when carcinoid tumours metastasize to the adrenal gland

  • When carcinoid tumours metastasize to the liver, carcinoid syndrome becomes evident.
  • In patients with no liver metastases, serotonin released by carcinoid tumours will become inactive in the liver.
  • In a patient with liver metastases, serotonin bypasses the first-pass metabolism in the liver and directly enters the bloodstream, causing symptoms.

 

Option D: Pale-looking skin is a typical feature

  • The most common presenting symptom of carcinoid syndrome is skin flushing.
  • The skin colour of the face and upper chest changes from red to purple, and it feels hot.
  • Bright-red patchy flushing is typically seen in Gastric carcinoids.

questions.text: A community medicine intern in his viva session with his senior incharge was asked to define saturation index. Which of the following is the correct definition of Saturation index?

choices.text: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants.
Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity and pH.
Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops.
Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

questions.solution:
B: Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity and pH

  • Langelier saturation index is used for assessment of water quality, therefore option B is correct answer.

Langelier Saturation index:

  • Langelier saturation index indicates degree of saturation of CaCO3 in water.
  • Used in industry to stabilize water.
  • LSI is based on
    • pH of water
    • Total dissolved solids
    • Alkalinity
    • Calcium concentration
    • Water temperature
  • LI positive: It leads to deposition & scaling.
  • LI negative: It leads to corrosion.
  • LI should be kept zero: To avoid corrosion & scaling.

A/ C/ D: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants/ Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops/ Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

  • These all choices do not correctly describe the saturation index

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of resistance in Methicillin Resistant Staphulococcus aureus(MRSA)??
questions.solution:
Option A: Altered penicillin-binding proteins

  • MRSA is resistant to all β-lactams because of the presence of mecA, a gene that produces a penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) with low affinity for β-lactam antibiotics.
  • B lactams like penicillin bind to the Penicillin-binding proteins like transpeptidases through which they inhibit the formation of the cell wall
  • MRSA is mainly acquired through hospitals, but it can also be community-acquired and acquired after an open wound, like in this patient who had a wound in his tibia. After that, Pus started coming out from them, pointing towards osteomyelitis and culture revealed MRSA Osteomyelitis
  • The treatment for MRSA is vancomycin
  • The treatment for Vancomycin-resistant Staph aureus is Linezolid

Option B: Beta lactamases

  • Some staphylococci form beta-lactamases as a low-level resistance, targeting the beta-lactam ring in the beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin and cephalosporin. Clavulanic acid is a beta-lactamase inhibitor given with penicillins

Option C: Efflux pump

  • Efflux pumps are the mode of resistance of some organisms  against aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones

Option D: Thick biofilm

  • Thick biofilm is a property of the Pseudomonas aureginosa and its mode of resistance against antibiotics

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. The physician notices a pulsating vessel in the neck (image below). His ECG findings are insignificant. What can be the possible diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Notice the visible neck pulsations indicating elevated JVP. This is a characteristic sign of tricuspid regurgitation as this does not occur with aortic regurgitation, mitral regurgitation, and Cor-triatrium.
  • The flow of blood from the right atrium of the heart to the right ventricle is controlled by a valve called the tricuspid valve. Tricuspid regurgitation is a condition that occurs when the flaps of the valve do not close tightly enough. It's possible that blood will flow backwards through the tricuspid valve into the atrium, which will require your heart to pump harder in order to force the blood through the valve. The pressure caused by cardiac illnesses such as heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and cardiomyopathy causes the ventricle to enlarge, leading to an expanded heart chamber. As a direct consequence of this, the tricuspid valve is deformed and susceptible to leaking.
  • Fatigue, swelling, cardiac arrhythmias, low cardiac output (effort intolerance), cervical pulsations, abdominal fullness, asthenia, and shortness of breath are the symptoms that might accompany severe tricuspid regurgitation.

Option B: Aortic regurgitation

  • The dancing carotids of aortic regurgitation produce an outward displacement and do not start from the base of the neck, unlike the condition shown in the image.

Option C: Mitral regurgitation

  • Notice the visible neck pulsations indicating elevated JVP. Mitral regurgitation is a left-side lesion and does not lead to change in JVP.

Option D: Cor-triatrium

  • Notice the visible neck pulsations indicating elevated JVP. Cor-triatrium is a left-side lesion and does not lead to change in JVP.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient develops cardiogenic shock following acute myocardial infarction. His urine output decreases in the next few days. He has increased serum urea and creatinine; urine analysis reveals no glucose or protein, but numerous hyaline casts are present. After a few days, he develops polyuria and serum creatinine levels fall. Histopathology of renal biopsy in this patient would reveal?
questions.solution:
Option C: Patchy tubular necrosis

Cardiogenic shock has resulted in the development of acute kidney injury. The history given shows the patient passing from initiation to maintenance and, lastly recovery phase due to ischemic acute tubular necrosis.

  • Morphological features of ischemic ATN
  1. Focal tubular epithelial necrosis at multiple points along the nephron
  2. Large skip areas in between
  3. Rupture of basement membranes (Tubulorrhexis)
  4. Occlusion of tubular lumens by casts (Tamm Horsfall protein)
  • The clinical course of acute kidney injury

Initiation
  • Dominated by the inciting medical, surgical or obstetric event in the ischemic form of AKI
  • The only indication of renal involvement is a slight decline in urine output with a rise in BUN

Maintenance
  • A sustained decrease in urine output to between 40 and 400 ml/day - Oliguria
  • Salt and water overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis

Recovery
  • A steady increase in urine volume that may reach up to 3L/ day
  • The tubules are still damaged, so large amounts of water, sodium and potassium are lost in the flood of urine

The most susceptible part of the nephron for tubular injury is the proximal segment and pars recta.

Option A: Immune complex deposition

  • Immune complexes are deposited in autoimmune diseases and Post streptococcal GN

Option B: Glomerular Crescents

  • Cellular glomerular crescents are defined as two or more layers of proliferating cells in Bowman's space and are a hallmark of inflammatory glomerulonephritis and a histologic marker of severe glomerular injury

Option D: Mesangial deposits

  • They can be seen in other conditions, such as infection-associated glomerulonephritis, inflammatory bowel disease, malignancies, sarcoidosis, and certain dermatologic conditions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the physician with complaints of pain around the umbilicus and passing dark red blood from his rectum for 2 days. The boy's appetite and vitals are normal Examination shows pale conjunctiva. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Meckel's diverticulum

  • Meckel's diverticulum is a mid-gut anomaly, presenting with pain around the umbilicus.
  • A Meckel diverticulum is one of the most common congenital defects of the G.I. tract. 
  • Referred pain of mid-gut derivatives is felt in the peri-umbilical region (T10).
  • It is caused by incomplete extermination of the omphalomesenteric duct. It is normally about 2 inches tall and is located 2 feet above the ileocecal valve.
  • It is seen in 2% of the population, and its ratio in males is more than in females. The mucosal lining of the diverticulum is either native ileal mucosa or heterotopic mucosa. It is usually asymptomatic.
  • It is detected incidentally during abdominal surgery or during imaging investigations.
  • The clinical presentation of the symptomatic Meckel diverticulum is a lower G.I. bleed, which is painless.
  • Patients can also present with acute intestinal obstruction (intussusception or volvulus), diverticulitis, and, rarely, peritonitis due to perforation of a Meckel diverticulum. 

Option A: Angina pectoris

  • In angina pectoris, the patient presents with throbbing chest pain radiating to the neck, jaw, arm, or back.

Option C: Acute cholecystitis 

  • In acute cholecystitis, the patient presents with generalized abdominal pain, fever, and tenderness in the right hypochondrium.

Option D: Renal colic

  • In renal colic, the patient presents with lumbar pain. The site of the pain depends upon the kidneys involved.

questions.text:
Recommendations given by Srivastava Committee:


	School health services
	ROME scheme
	Integration of health services
	Village health guide

choices.text: All four (A, B, C, & D) are correct

questions.solution:
Option C: B and D are correct

  • Statements B and D are correct in the case of Recommendations given by the Srivastava Committee.
  • Shrivastava Committee (1975): Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower, (ROME) Scheme and Village Health Guide scheme.
  • School Health was first recommended by the Bhore committee.
  • Jungalwalla committee: ‘Committee on Integration of Health Services’.

Option A: A, B, and C are correct

  1. School health services- Bhore committee.
  2. ROME scheme- Srivastava Committee.
  3. Integration of health services- Jungalwalla committee.

Option B: A and C are correct

  • School health services- Bhore committee.
  • Integration of health services- Jungalwalla committee.

Option D: All four (A, B, C, & D) are correct

  1. School health services- Bhore committee.
  2. ROME scheme- Srivastava Committee.
  3. Integration of health services- Jungalwalla committee.
  4. Village health guide- Srivastava Committee.

questions.text: Which one of the following structures originates from the superolateral area of ischial tuberosity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Semimembranosus

  • The semimembranosus originates from the superolateral area of ischial tuberosity and inserts on the medial condyle of the tibia.
  • It is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.
  • It is responsible for the thigh extension and the hip joint's internal rotation. At the knee joint, it causes flexion and internal rotation of the leg.

Option A: Semitendinosus

  • Semitendinosus originates from the inferomedial impression of the upper part of the ischial tuberosity, not the superolateral part.
  • It inserts on the proximal end of the tibia below the medial condyle through the Pes anserinus.
  • It is a flexor of the knee and an extensor of the hip.

Option C: Long head of biceps

  • The long head of the biceps femoris arises from inferomedial impression of ischial tuberosity along with semitendinosus. The short head arises from linea aspera of the femur and lateral supracondylar line of the femur.
  • It inserts on the lateral head of the Fibula.
  • The primary function is flexion of the knee. With the knee semi-flexed, the muscle functions as a lateral rotator of the lower leg on the knee. With the hip extended, the biceps femoris is a lateral rotator of the thigh.

Option D: Adductor Magnus

  • The adductor Magnus originates from the lower lateral part of the ischial tuberosity, ischial ramus, and lower part of the inferior ramus of the pubis.
  • It inserts on the medial lip of linea aspera, gluteal tuberosity, medial supracondylar line, and the adductor tubercle of the femur.
  • It has a dual nerve supply
    • The adductor part is supplied by the obturator nerve and is responsible for the thigh's flexion, adduction, and external rotation.
    • The hamstring part is supplied by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve and causes thigh extension and internal rotation.

questions.text: In which of the following segment does a net secretion of potassium (K+) take place?
questions.solution:
Option D: Colon

  • K+ is absorbed or secreted mainly by passive mechanisms.
  • The rectum and perhaps the sigmoid colon can actively secrete K+
  • Colon is responsible for the following actions:
    • Reabsorption of Na+, Cl-, water
    • Secretion of K+, HCO3-

Option A: Duodenum

  • In the duodenum, an active HCO3- secretion in exchange for Cl- occurs at the apical cell membrane, and these bicarbonates are neutralized by gastric acid entering the proximal duodenum.

Option B: Jejunum

  • There is no net secretion of K+ in the Duodenum.
  • K+ secretion occurs in the colon.
  • Reabsorption of Na+, Cl-, K+, water, and Secretion of HCO3-

Option C: Ileum

  • There is no net secretion of K+ in the Ileum.
  • K+ secretion occurs in the colon.
  • Reabsorption of Na+, Cl-, K+, water, and Secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: An 80-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with fever and lymphadenopathy; on examination, lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally in the cervical chain. Her laboratory findings reveal a haemoglobin count of 10.2 gram/dL, a white blood cell count of 8.1 x 109/L, and platelet is 35 x 109/L. Her blood smear shows numerous “Smudge cells” with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. Smudge cells in the peripheral smear are characteristic of which leukaemia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • This patient's lymphocytosis and smudge cells on the peripheral blood smear are highly suggestive of chronic lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • The proliferation and accumulation of a clone of malignant mature B lymphocytes characterise chronic lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • These lymphocytes accumulate in the bone marrow, blood, lymph nodes and spleen.
  • Smudge cells are a common finding in patients with CLL.
  • They are also called basket cells, smear cells or Gumprecht shadows.
  • Smudge cells represent damaged lymphocytes or fragile lymphocytes.
  • They are remnants of cells that lack a cytoplasmic membrane or nuclear structure.
  • The lymphocytes in CLL are stiffer, less deformable and more fragile compared to normal lymphocytes.
  • The smudging of CLL lymphocytes occurs in cells with physical defects and fragility and are destroyed or smudged in the physical process of making a smear.

 

 

Option A: Chronic myelogenous leukaemia

  • Chronic myelogenous leukaemia is characterised by increased and unregulated growth of predominantly myeloid cells in the bone marrow and accumulation of these cells in the blood.
  • The histological finding in chronic myeloid leukaemia shows garden party appearance, i.e. different types of cells, including immature myeloid series of cells including eosinophils, basophils and mature neutrophils, giving a colourful appearance.

 

Option C: Acute myelogenous leukaemia

  • Acute Myelogenous Leukemia is a neoplastic process with blasts of more than 20% in peripheral blood or bone marrow.
  • Auer rods are present in the blasts.
  • These are rod- or needle- or spindle-shaped azurophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

 

Option D: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is a malignant disease of the bone marrow in which early lymphoid precursors proliferate and replace the normal hematopoietic cells of the bone marrow.
  • It is the most common type of cancer in children.
  • A peripheral blood smear will reveal blast cells, large immature cells with punched-out nucleoli.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the clinic with gingival enlargement, oral ulcers, and mobility of teeth. The vital signs are within the normal range. His histopathological biopsy is shown below. Which of the following markers can be used to identify tumour cells in the disease condition related to the HPE picture shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: S-100

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis has special granules inside them as Birbeck granules.
  • These are Penta-laminar tubules, often with a dilated terminal end producing a "tennis racket" like appearance on electron microscopy, which contains the protein langerin.
  • The skeleton is the most commonly involved organ system in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • In addition, the tumour cells also typically express the following:
    • HLA-DR
    • S-100
    • CD1a

Figure: Image showing Tennis racket appearance under the electron microscope

 

Figure: Image showing Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Option A: CD11a

  • B- and T lymphocytes, monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, basophils, and eosinophils express CD11a, a pan-leukocyte marker.
  • Most granulocytes, monocytes/macrophages, NK cells, and B- and T-cell subsets express CD11b.

Option B: HLA-DP

  • HLA-DP serves as a cell surface receptor for either foreign or self-antigens.
  • When MHC receptors present antigens, the immune system searches for foreign invaders like HLA-DP.

Option C: CD107

  • It is an intracellular protein extensively expressed and found in the lysosomal/endosomal membrane.
  • CD107a, which is transiently present on the plasma membrane, can be employed as a marker for CD8+ T cell degranulation after activation.

questions.text: A newborn baby was undergoing cardiac surgery for a congenital cardiac defect (PDA). While performing the surgery the surgeon encountered an abnormal size of his thymus gland which was creating difficulty in performing the surgery. Therefore the surgeon decided to perform partial thymectomy. What does Neonatal thymectomy lead to?

choices.text: Increased antibody production by B cells
Increased bone marrow production of lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Neonatal thymectomy leads to the decreased size of paracortical areas.

B & T cells originate in Bone Marrow.

B cells mature in Bone Marrow while T cells mature in Thymus.

THYMUS:

  • Develops From 3rd & 4th pharyngeal pouches.
  • Maturation of T cells happens.

BONE MARROW

  • B & T cells originate from Bone marrow.
  • B cells mature in Bone marrow.

Lymph nodes:

  • T cells are present in para cortical area.
  • B cells are present in central follicles

Spleen:

  • T cells are present in periarteriolar sheath.
  • B cells are present in germinal follicle [marginal Zone]
  • Following neonatal thymectomy, T-cells can’t mature which will lead to decrease in para cortical area.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of right upper quadrant pain associated with intermittent low-grade fever and unexplained weight loss for the last five months. His examination revealed a blood pressure of 110/80mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 76 beats per minute. His right upper quadrant has mild tenderness. His ultrasound abdomen and C.T. abdomen are requested, demonstrating a cystic lesion with vesicles at its periphery in segments six and seven of the liver. He is advised anti-parasitic therapy along with the removal of the cyst.

Additionally, he has a positive casoni's test. After exploration, the findings are shown in the image below. Identify the condition in the image.
questions.solution:
Option D: Hydatid cyst

  • The condition in the image is hydatid cyst.
  • The causative agent of hydatid cyst is echinococcus granulosus.

Echinococcus granulosus/ dog tapeworm:

  • Definitive host: Dog and wild carnivores.
  • Intermediate hosts: Man and other herbivorous animals.
  • Man is an accidental host (dead end).
  • Eggs of E. granulosus ingested with contaminated food & water: Infective stage of the parasite.
  • Eggs transform to larva (hydatid cysts) that penetrate GIT and migrate to various organs like the liver.
  • Eggs are passed in the faeces; an intermediate host may swallow them. After exposure to gastric and intestinal enzymes, the eggs hatch in the duodenum. The released oncospheres penetrate the intestine and are carried via the bloodstream, where they are filtered out in the various organs. The most common sites are the liver and lungs.
  • Hydatid cyst consists of:
    • Pericyst
    • Ectocyst
    • Endocyst (Germinal epithelium):
      • Most active layer
      • Secretes hydatid fluid
      • Associated with brood capsule and protoscolices.
  • Treatment of hydatid cyst:
    • Mild to moderate size cyst: PAIR therapy (Percutaneous aspiration injection respiration) therapy using scolicidal agents
    • Large size cyst → Surgical removal

Option A: Tachyzoites

  • Tachyzoites refer to the rapidly growing life stage of T. gondii.
  • Also called endozoites or trophozoites.
  • Tachyzoites are responsible for initiating an immune response leading to clinical manifestations seen in both primary and reactivated infections.

Option B: Bradyzoites

  • Bradyzoites are also called cystozoites.
  • They are the life stage found in the tissue cyst and replicate slowly.
  • The bradyzoite stage results from converting tachyzoites into slowly multiplying organisms that replicate by endodyogeny within a Parasitophorous vacuole and form cysts in tissues throughout the body.

Option C: Oocyst

  •  It is a hardy, thick-walled stage of the life cycle of coccidian parasites.
  •  This is shed in the faeces of people infected with cyclospora and cryptosporidium.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has been declared dead on arrival. The parents claim that the baby was found breathless and unresponsive in the morning when the mother had tried to wake him up for breastfeeding. The baby had been healthy and had not shown signs of any discomfort or disease. Which statement among the following, is not true about this condition??

choices.text: Cigarette smoking by pregnant mothers increase the risk

questions.solution:
Option C: Incidence common in females

  • Incidence is more common in males

Option A/B/D: Also known as cot/crib death/ Threefold increase in twins/ Cigarette smoking by pregnant mothers increase the risk

  • Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is also known as cot death or crib death.
  • There is three fold increased in the twins
  • Cigarette smoking and drug abuse by pregnant women increase the risk

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents to the clinic with complaints of a burning sensation and discomfort in both eyes. On examination, congestion is noted around the lateral canthus associated with maceration of the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Angular conjunctivitis

  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by mild-grade inflammation confined to the conjunctiva and lid margins near the angles (hence the name) associated with maceration of the surrounding skin.

  • Moraxella Axenfeld (MA) is the commonest causative organism.(Gram negative diplococci)
  • MA bacilli are placed end to end, so the disease is called 'diplobacillary conjunctivitis.'
  • Rarely, staphylococci may also cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Signs include:
    • Hyperemia of bulbar conjunctiva near the canthi.
    • Hyperemia of lid margins near the angles.
    • Excoriation of the skin around the palpebral angles.
    • Dirty, Foamy mucopurulent discharge at the angles is usually present.
    • Frequent blinking.
  • Source of infection:
    • The nasal tract of healthy persons.
    • Often present in the nasal discharge in cases of Angular Conjunctivitis.
  • Treatment
    • Tetracycline ointment 2–3 times/day × 10–14 days.

Option A: Adenoviral conjunctivitis

  • Adenoviral conjunctivitis usually occurs in epidemics.
  • The patient often has a concurrent pharyngeal infection.
  • Watery discharge is prominent.​​​​​​​
  • Does not affect skin surrounding the eye.

Option B: Apollo Disease

  • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, also known as apollo disease, is characterized by multiple conjunctiva hemorrhages, conjunctival hyperemia and mild follicular hyperplasia-caused due by Enterovirus 70.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
  • This patient does not have Apollo disease as these features are not present.

Option D: Trachoma

  • Trachoma is characterized by lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, foreign body sensation, and other characteristic signs.
  • This patient in the vignette has a different presentation.
  • Caused by Chlamydia.
  • It can lead to permanent blindness.
  • Azithromycin is the DOC.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after sustaining a fall from the front child seat of a bicycle 2 hours ago. The boy is having severe pain in and around the right eye. The boy’s mother reported no history of loss of consciousness or vomiting. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. A computed tomography (CT) scan was performed at the local hospital and showed a pure blowout fracture of the right orbital floor with a slight dislocation of the orbital contents. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Superior wall is most commonly involved
Triad of diplopia, exophthalmos and supraorbital anaesthesia
Results from trauma to the orbit by a relatively large object
Panda sign or racoon eyes are a prominent feature

questions.solution:
Option C: Results from trauma to the orbit by a relatively large object

  • This is a case of a blowout fracture in which the patient presents with complaints of severe right eye pain after trauma to the eye by a large object.
  • Blowout fracture is the most common fracture of orbit.
  • Blow-out orbital fractures generally result from trauma to the orbit by a relatively large, often rounded object.
  • The force of the blow causes a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the infraorbital pressure, with a resultant fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall, which is usually the orbital floor.
  • Orbital imaging shows a hanging drop/teardrop sign.

  • CT of right orbital floor blowout fracture -coronal view shows a defect in the orbital floor and the 'tear drop' sign due to soft tissue prolapse into the maxillary antrum.

 

  • Right orbital floor blowout fracture. (A) Marked periocular ecchymosis, oedema and subconjunctival haemorrhage; (B) restricted elevation (C) mild right enophthalmos.

Option A: Superior wall is most commonly involved

  • The inferior wall is also known as the floor of the orbit.
  • It is most commonly involved in the blowout fracture due to the infraorbital groove.

Option B: Triad of diplopia, exophthalmos and supraorbital anaesthesia

  • The triad of diplopia, enophthalmos and infraorbital anaesthesia typically points towards a diagnosis of orbital blowout fracture.

Option D: Panda sign or racoon eyes are a prominent feature

  • Racoon sign/panda sign seen in case of bilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture (basilar skull fracture).

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to the ENT department for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing sounds like the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping but can easily hear the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. A Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally. A weber test does not lateralise. Audiometry of the patient is done. Which of the following is correct about the findings in this patient's pathology?

choices.text: Dip at 5000 Hz in bone conduction
Dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction
Rarely seen in noise-induced hearing loss
Stereo cilia of the outer hair cells are the first to be affected

questions.solution:
Option D: Stereo cilia of the outer hair cells are first to be affected

  • Boiler notch/Acoustic dip is seen in Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL):
  • Boiler notch at 4000Hz
  • Notch is seen in the BC curve
  • AC curve notch are insignificant
  • Maximum saw at 3000-6000Hz
  • Sound causing maximum NIHL 2000-3000Hz
  • Stereocilia of outer hair cells are the first to be affected.
  • The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, for air and bone conduction. It is usually symmetrical on both sides.
  • At this stage, the patient complains of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in noisy surroundings but no difficulty in day-to-day hearing.
  • As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch deepens and widens to involve lower and higher frequencies.
  • Hearing impairment becomes clinically apparent to the patient when the frequencies of 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz (the speech frequencies) are also affected. NIHL causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea.
  • Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells. Noise-induced hearing loss is preventable. Persons who have to work at places where noise is above 85 dB should have pre-employment and then annual audiograms for early detection. Ear protectors should be used where noise levels exceed 85 dB.
  • They protect up to 35 dB. If the hearing impairment has already occurred, rehabilitation is similar to that employed for other sensorineural hearing losses.

Option A: Dip at 5000 Hz in bone conduction

  • The boiler notch is at 4000Hz.

Option B: Dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction

  • The boiler notch is at 4000Hz.

Option C: Rarely seen in noise-induced hearing loss

  • A boiler notch is commonly seen in noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL).

questions.text: Identify the type of time distribution shown in the Photograph below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Seasonal trend

  • The given image is showing peaking of disease in September of every year; which is showing seasonal fluctuation in the occurrence of a disease known as Seasonal trends.
  • Examples of diseases showing seasonal trends: Measles, URI, and GIT infections.

Other options

Option A: Epidemic

  • An epidemic occurs when a disease spreads quickly across a community, affecting a significant number of people in a little amount of time.
    • Single exposure, point source epidemic - Staph. food poisoning
    • Multiple exposures, point source epidemic - Typhoid
    • Propagated epidemic - Tuberculosis

Option C: Secular trend

  • In the Secular trend, the majority of communicable diseases are reducing with time.
  • Whereas non-communicable diseases are slowly rising.
  • So gradual decrease of communicable & gradual increase of non-communicable is also a secular trend of the disease.

Option D: Cyclical trend

  • A recurrent pattern that occurs often, such as seasonal variations in the abundance of insect vectors or respiratory diseases among elementary school students.  
  • The disease occurs after a gap of fixed years
    • Measles shows a cyclical trend once every 2-3years
    • Rubella shows a cyclical trend once every 6-8years
    • Influenza shows the maximum cyclical trend.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of Van Nuys prognostic index (NPI)?
questions.solution:
Option A: Age of patient

  • Ductal carcinoma-in-situ is the presence of cancer cells inside the milk duct of breast tissue.
  • DCIS is considered the earliest form of breast cancer.
  • DCIS is a non-invasive (benign) tumor.

  • Van Nuy's prognostic index (VNPI) classifies patients with DCIS to guide decisions on the best treatment option.
    • Size of tumor
    • Resection margin width; the amount of healthy tissue surrounding the tumor after removal
    • Age of patient
    • Grade

Option B: Smoking status

  • Smoking is a risk factor for breast cancer in women.
  • It, however, has no role in deciding whether the patient will benefit from radiotherapy or whether it will be a futile effort.

Option C: Gender

  • Breast cancer is rare in men. However, when present, they are associated with a worse prognosis.

Option D: Her-2-neu receptor status

  • Her-2-neu is associated with worse prognosis in breast cancer patients

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of dull right upper quadrant pain for the past month. He has been on a visit to South Africa, and the pain has occurred after his visit. An ultrasound was performed, which revealed the following findings. He was diagnosed with a hydatid cyst. What is the Gharbi classification for this patient’s cyst?
questions.solution:
Option B: Type III

  • The ultrasound image shows honeycomb septa which are suggestive of Gharbi classification 3
  • Gharbi classification of hydatid cyst:
Type I Pure cystic fluid collection
Type II Fluid collection with membrane separation
Type III Fluid collection with septa
Type IV Heterogenous pattern
Type V Completely calcified (reflecting) walls

Option A: Type IV

  • The above image shows that Gharbi classification type IV has a heterogenous echographic pattern.

Option C: Type I

  • As shown in the above image, Gharbi classification type I only has a pure fluid collection.

 

Option D: Type II

  • As shown in the above image, Gharbi classification type II has a Fluid collection with a split wall (floating membrane).

Option E: Type V

  • The above image shows that Gharbi classification type V has thick walls reflecting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came to the OPD complaining of right upper quadrant pain. On examination, hepatomegaly was noted. A triphasic CT scan revealed a hyperdense lesion in the arterial phase, which becomes hypodense in the delayed phase. AFP levels were found to be elevated. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this tumour?

choices.text: Most common malignancy of the liver
Paraneoplastic manifestation includes hypoglycemia, hypercalcemia, and erythrocytosis
Surgery is a palliative method that has a survival advantage
50% of tumours are resectable at the time of presentation

questions.solution:
Option B: Paraneoplastic manifestation includes hypoglycemia, hypercalcemia, and erythrocytosis

  • According to the clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma:
    • Most common primary malignant neoplasm of the liver
    • It is the fifth most common malignancy worldwide
    • More common in men 
    • Paraneoplastic syndromes
      • Hypercholesterolemia (M/C)
      • Hypoglycemia (2nd M/C)
      • Hypercalcemia
      • Erythrocytosis

Option A: Most common malignancy of the liver

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the liver.
  • The most common malignancy of the liver is metastasis from cancers of other organs like colorectal carcinoma.

Option C: Surgery is a palliative method that has a survival advantage

  • TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is only a palliative method that has a survival advantage

Option D: 50% of tumours are resectable at the time of presentation

  • Only 15-20% of tumours are resectable at the presentation time.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female underwent elective cholecystectomy. The gallbladder is sent for histological examination. Which of the following statements is related to the condition given in the image below?

choices.text: Cholesterol deposits in the submucosa of the gallbladder

questions.solution:
Option C: Associated with cholesterol polyp

  • The image given above shows the inside of the gallbladder studded with yellow flecks, which is suggestive of the strawberry gall bladder or Cholesterolosis
  • Cholesterolosis is due to the deposition of cholesterol ester and triglycerides in macrophages in the gall bladder lamina propria, either locally or as polyps.
    • It is an acquired condition.
    • Risk factor includes hypercholesterolemia. It is associated with the presence of cholesterol polyps and cholesterol gallstones.

Option A: It is an inherited condition

  • It is an acquired condition.

Option B: These are only cholesterol gallstones

  • It is associated with the presence of cholesterol polyps and cholesterol gallstones.

Option D: Cholesterol deposits in the submucosa of the gallbladder

  • Cholesterolosis due to the deposition of cholesterol ester and triglycerides in macrophages in the gall bladder lamina propria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with diffuse abdominal pain. On laboratory investigation, amylase was normal, but CEA was raised. CT scan showed a hypodense lesion in the pancreas, which had internal septation and wall calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mucinous cystadenoma

  • CECT showing peripheral egg-shell calcification suggesting the diagnosis of mucinous cystadenoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma:
    • Mucinous cystadenoma is the most common pancreatic cystic neoplasm
    • Females are more prone to it (perimenopausal women). Men are rarely impacted.
    • Columnar epithelial lining
    • The body and tail of the pancreas are the most commonly used locations.
    • Premalignant
    • The mucin-producing epithelium is present, and mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma distinguish them histologically.
    • In most cases, oestrogen and progesterone staining are positive.
    • Linked to an increase in CEA
    • Normal amylase levels
    • The cyst has strong walls and does not connect with the main pancreatic duct on imaging. The cyst wall may contain nodules or calcifications.
    •  CECT shows egg-shell calcification of the periphery ( solitary cyst with fine septations surrounded by a calcification rim).
    • Malignancy is indicated by peripheral egg-shell calcification, and greater tumour size.
    • FNA reveals mucin-rich aspirate and high CEA values (>192 ng/mL).
    • Amylase levels in cyst fluid are low.
    • Distal pancreatectomy is the treatment.

Option A: Serous cystadenoma

  • Pancreatic serous cystadenoma is a benign pancreatic tumour. It is commonly seen in the pancreas' tail and is linked to von Hippel-Lindau disease.
  • A CT scan often reveals a multicystic, lobulated tumour in the pancreatic head, commonly referred to as a "bunch of grapes."

Option C: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm

  • Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) is a form of tumour that can develop within pancreatic duct cells. IPMN tumours produce mucus, and this mucus can develop pancreatic cysts. Although intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms are benign tumours, they can develop into pancreatic cancer.
  • They appear as single or many pancreatic cystic hypodense lesions on CT imaging. For the primary type IPMN, dilatation of the main duct greater than 5 mm is cause for worry. On CT, connection with the pancreatic ducts, particularly side branch lesions, may be difficult to see. They are not calcified.

Option D: Acinic cell tumour

  • Acinar cell carcinoma is a rare malignant exocrine pancreatic tumour. It accounts for 5% of all pancreatic exocrine tumours, making it the second most frequent kind of pancreatic cancer.
  • On contrast-enhanced CT, the tumour is often shown as an enhancing, ovoid, solid pancreatic tumour. Variable hypo/hyperattenuating mass relative to the pancreas, with distinct borders, can be seen along with dilation of non-biliary ducts.

questions.text: In newborns presenting with respiratory distress, what is the primary complication associated with Ryle's tube insertion, prompting chest X-ray assessment by pediatricians?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aspiration pneumonia

  • Pneumonia is inflammation (swelling) and infection of the lungs or large airways. Aspiration pneumonia occurs when food or liquid is breathed into the airways or lungs instead of being swallowed.
  • Aspiration pneumonia is caused by inhaling foreign materials into the lungs. These materials can be Bacteria from saliva and secretions from the mouth and nose. Stomach contents such as digestive juices or vomit.
  • As many as 40% of patients receiving enteral tube feedings aspirate the feedings into their lower respiratory tract, resulting in pneumonia.
  • Dislodged or misplaced enteral feeding tubes, high gastric residual volume (GRV), dysphagia, and poor oral hygiene are all possible causes of aspiration pneumonia.

Option B: Dyspnea

  • The shortness of breath known medically as dyspnea is often described as an intense tightening in the chest, air hunger, difficulty breathing, breathlessness, or a feeling of suffocation.
  • The most common causes of dyspnea are asthma, heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), interstitial lung disease, pneumonia, and psychogenic problems that are usually linked to anxiety. If shortness of breath starts suddenly, it is acute dyspnea.
  • Dyspnea occurs with GERD because stomach acid that creeps into the esophagus can enter the lungs, particularly during sleep, and cause swelling of the airways. This can lead to asthma reactions or cause aspiration pneumonia.

Option C: Pulmonary hypertension

  • Pulmonary hypertension appears to be a ubiquitous complication of acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Pulmonary hypertension contributes to impaired right ventricular performance and reduced cardiac output and is associated with increased mortality.
  • Pulmonary hypertension is high blood pressure in pulmonary arteries, which carry oxygen-poor blood from the heart to the lungs. The earliest symptom is shortness of breath during the usual routine. The most common causes are heart disease, lung disease, and hypoxia.
  • Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) is a dangerous condition that may cause a baby not to get enough oxygen after birth. During pregnancy, babies get all of the oxygen from the mother through the placenta. The placenta is an organ in the mother's womb connected to the umbilical cord.

Option D: Excessive lung fluid

  • Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a condition that causes breathing problems in newborn babies. Babies have fluid in their lungs before birth.
  • The fluid normally goes away when a baby is born. In some babies, the fluid does not go away as quickly as it should.
  • When extra fluid remains in the lungs, a newborn shows respiratory distress. We will provide breathing support and treat the underlying cause of wet lungs.
  • Although it can be difficult to see babies struggle to breathe, their lungs should recover within a few days to weeks.
  • Before birth, a developing fetus does not use the lungs for breathing, all oxygen comes from the placenta's blood vessels. During this time, the baby's lungs are filled with fluid. As the baby's due date nears, the lungs begin to absorb the fluid.

questions.text: What is the name of the fundoplication procedure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nissen’s fundoplication

  • A Nissen fundoplication is a surgery to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). During the procedure, a surgeon creates a sphincter (tightening muscle) at the bottom of the esophagus to prevent acid reflux.
  • Most people notice a significant decrease in acid reflux symptoms after the Surgery.

 

Type of fundoplication

Degree of Wrap

Watson

90 ° anterior fundoplication

Dor

180 ° anterior fundoplication

Toupet

180° posterior fundoplication subsequently modified to 270 °

Belsey Mark IV

270 ° anterior fundoplication

Nissen’s

360 ° fundoplication (most commonly performed)

 

Option B: Watson fundoplication

  • Traditionally, the anti-reflux surgical procedure of choice has been Nissen's operation. However, this technique has a significant incidence of mechanical complications and has a reoperation rate of approximately 7%, leading to the development of alternative approaches.
  • Watson's technique of partial anterior fundoplication has been shown to achieve long-lasting reflux control in adults with few mechanical complications, but there is limited data in the pediatric population.
  • Nevertheless, a high incidence of mechanical side effects has been reported, such as dysphagia, an inability to belch or vomit, and gas bloating, all of which are likely due to the establishment of a super-competent gastroesophageal sphincter by the 360-degree wrap.

 

Option C: Dor fundoplication

  • Dor fundoplication (a partial wrapping of the stomach around the esophagus to make a low-pressure valve) is performed to prevent reflux from the stomach into the esophagus following the myotomy.
  • The Dor fundoplication procedure consists of a 180-degree anterior fundoplication. This type of fundoplication is particularly indicated in patients with severe impairment of esophageal body motility.
  • It is used to treat achalasia. One of the side effects of Heller myotomy is the development of reflux. In order to prevent reflux, Dor fundoplication is performed at the time of Surgery.
  • Patients with a failed fundoplication due to structural laxity will often present with recurrence of or persistent GERD symptoms, including heartburn, regurgitation, and erosive esophageal disease such as peptic stricture formation or reflux esophagitis.

 

Option D: Toupet fundoplication

  • Laparoscopic Toupet fundoplication is a surgical procedure performed for the treatment of GERD. The procedure strengthens the valve between the esophagus and the stomach, preventing the backflow of acid.
  • The Toupet procedure is the better operation because it has a lower rate of dysphagia and is as effective as the Nissen fundoplication in controlling reflux.
  • Laparoscopic Toupet fundoplication achieved a 5-year healing rate of GERD of 85%. Of all operated patients, 3.5% had to be reinstalled on a regular PPI treatment because of postoperative GERD reappearance.
  • The Toupet fundoplication or 270-degree wrap is equally effective in controlling GERD but tends to fall apart with time due to a lack of strong serosal adhesions between the two edges of the wrapped gastric fundus.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male with a history of colicky pain, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, no passage of flatus, and constipation shows a distended abdomen with a tympanic note. The X-ray of the abdomen is done as shown in the image:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Jejunal obstruction

  • No passage of flatus - Small bowel obstruction
  • X-ray of the abdomen shows 
    1. Multiple dilated bowel loops
    2. Circumferential ring-like pattern indicating → JEJUNAL OBSTRUCTION
  • VALVULAE CONNIVENTES
    • Small Bowel Obstruction:
      • Straight segments that are generally central and lie transversely. No/ minimal gas is seen in the colon
      • Jejunum - characterized by valvulae conniventes, which completely pass across the width of the bowel and are regularly spaced, giving a 'concertina' or ladder effect
      • Ileum - Wangensteen has piquantly described the distal ileum as featureless
      • Cecum - A distended cecum is shown by a rounded gas shadow in the right iliac fossa
    • Large bowel Obstruction: Shows haustral folds, which are spaced irregularly, do not cross the whole diameter of the bowel, and do not have indentations placed opposite one another

Option A: Duodenal obstruction

  • Abdominal radiographs may classically show a double bubble sign with a gas-filled distended stomach and duodenum without distal gas.
  • A similar appearance (either filled with fluid or gas) can be seen in other modalities.
    • A double-bubble sign on an abdominal x-ray is a reliable indicator of duodenal atresia with an even higher positive predictive value in patients with Down syndrome.
    • The presence of distal bowel gas, although more classically associated with duodenal stenosis, can be seen in duodenal atresia via anomalous bile duct anatomy

Option C: Intussusception

  • Common in children.
  • A target sign is usually seen.
     

Option D: Colonic obstruction

  • Haustra are seen.
  • The distribution of loops of the intestine is peripheral

questions.text: A nine-month-old male child is brought by his mother to the OPD with complaints of an empty left scrotum and swelling on the left flank that has been present since birth. An ultrasound of the abdomen was done at another center which reported a hernia on the left side. However, the testis was not seen during the scan. A palpable soft tissue mass was noticed in the perineum on the same side as the empty hemi-scrotum. In this case, what is the most common position to look for the testis?

choices.text: At the root of the penis
The medial part of the femoral triangle
The upper part of the femoral triangle

questions.solution:
Option A: At the root of the penis

  • In the given case, the palpable soft tissue mass in the perineum on the same side of an empty hemi scrotum perineum is very suggestive of Ectopic testis, and the commonest position to look for would be the superficial inguinal pouch, but since it's not in the option and ultrasonography already ruled out that place so it should be looking at the root of the penis.
  • An ectopic testis is a type that has passed through the external ring and then has deviated from its usual path of descent.
  • The scrotum is usually empty, and the testis is well-developed.
  • The commonest position of the ectopic testis is at the superficial inguinal pouch, which lies just medial and inferior to the superficial inguinal ring.
Locations of Ectopic Testis

 
  • Superficial inguinal pouch (most common location)
  • At the root of the penis (pubic type)
  • At the perineum (perineal type)
  • Rarely at the upper and medial part of the femoral triangle (femoral type)

 

  • The ectopic testis probably occurs due to the rupture of the main scrotal tail of the gubernaculum testis.
  • The most ectopic testis can be felt (are palpable).
  • Surgical treatment to place an ectopic testis in its normal position by one year of age.

 

Option B: Contralateral scrotum

  • The most common location of the ectopic testis is the superficial inguinal pouch.
  • The contralateral scrotum is not the common location.

Option C: The medial part of the femoral triangle

  • Although ectopic testis can lie in the medial part of the femoral triangle, this is rare.
  • The most common location of the ectopic testis is the superficial inguinal pouch.

Option D: The upper part of the femoral triangle

  • The ectopic testis is rarely found in the upper part of the femoral triangle.
  • The most common location is either a superficial inguinal pouch or at the root of the penis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male race-course farrier presents to his family doctor complaining of persistent pain and numbness, fatigue, and frequent cramps extending bilaterally throughout the upper limbs (especially on the right side). Colour flow Doppler USG is prescribed, which reveals bilateral functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein, which is more severe on the right side. A subsequent angiography-assisted CT scan shows the presence of right subclavian venous thrombosis. What is likely the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation
Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

questions.solution:
Correct options

Option C: Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

  • In this case, as the patient is farrier, he overuses his arm. History of overuse of the arm and functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein suggests the diagnosis of Axillary-subclavian venous thrombosis (ASVT). 
  • Axillary-subclavian venous thrombosis (ASVT) is a condition in which the blood vessel of the upper arm is compressed by a nearby rib or muscle and results in blood clots.
  • ASVT may develop in the subclavian vein or axillary vein.
  • ASVT is a form of DVT that usually results from sudden injury or overuse.
  • Primary ASVT:
    • Less common.
    • History of performing repetitive and prolonged motion activities, leading to damage to the subclavian vein, usually where it passes between the first rib and head of the clavicle.
  • Secondary ASVT:
    • More common.
    • Associated with an easily identified cause such as an indwelling catheter or a hypercoagulable state.
  • Treatment:
    • Once ASVT is diagnosed, anticoagulation therapy should be initiated in order to prevent pulmonary embolism (PE) and decrease symptoms. 
    • Patients diagnosed with acute symptomatic primary ASVT are candidates for catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.

Other Options

Option A: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation

  • Rest and elevation of the limb are the initial management for ASVT.
  • As in this case, the patient's symptoms are severe; only rest cannot cure the damage. 
  • So the patient must be given IV anticoagulants along with catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy.

Option B: Treated with IV anticoagulants alone

  • Anticoagulants are blood thinners and prevent blot clot formation. But already present blood clots are treated by Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.
  • Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy is used to treat acute ASVT. It dissolves the blood clot that can travel to the lungs and can cause shortness of breath and chest pain and lead to death. 

Option D: Ultrasound-guided embolectomy

  • Ultrasound-guided embolectomy is performed when the blood clot has reached to lungs and causes pulmonary embolism.
  • As the patient has not reached this stage, catheter-directed thrombolysis will be used for the treatment.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the physician complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion for six months with bilateral ankle swelling for a month. He is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. On examination, the lower limbs show bilateral pitting edema. An ECG shows a right bundle branch block. Which of the following signs is shown in the image below about the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Stemmer’s sign

  • This is a case of right heart failure leading to systemic venous congestion.
  • The sign shown in the image is Stemmer sign.
  • Stemmer's sign is the inability to pinch the skin of the dorsum of the foot or hand.
  • The Stemmer's positive finding is associated with lymphedema.

Signs of Chronic Lymphedema

Buffalo hump
  • Contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the sub malleolar depressions, and a 'buffalo hump' forms on the dorsum of the foot

Square toes
  • Toes appear 'Square because of the confinement of footwear

Stemmer’s sign
  • Skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis

  

Option A: Ballance's sign

  • Ballance sign is the presence of persistent dullness to percussion in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, with shifting dullness in the right flank.
  • Dullness in the left flank is due to coagulated blood, which may be seen in a patient with a splenic injury.
  • It is observed during a traumatic assessment of the abdomen,

Option B: Dahl's sign

  • Dahl's is a clinical sign in patients with severe chronic respiratory disorders.
  • Areas of thickened and darkened skin are seen on the lower thighs and elbows.
  • Patients with COPD tend to sit forwards with their arms resting on their thighs, leading to chronic skin erythema at contact points.

Option D: Ladin's sign

  • Ladin's sign is a clinical sign in which there is softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix.
  • It is seen in pregnancy at about six weeks gestation.
  • It is detectable with manual examination.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, P2, presents with complaints of a mass descending per vagina, for the last 2 months. She reports discomfort and back pain, aggravated by long hours of standing and relieved by rest. On pelvic examination, there is uterocervical descent beyond the introitus. Which of the following is the most acceptable management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fothergill's repair

  • As the patient's age is 28 years, uterine preservation is a concern.
  • Uterine Preservation surgeries for prolapse are
    • Anterior and posterior pelvic repair
    • Fothergill's repair (Manchester surgery)
    • Shirodkar's procedure
    • Abdominal sling surgeries: Shirodkar, Khanna, Purandre's abdominocervicopexy.
  • Fothergill's repair /Manchester operation
    • The principle of the procedure is to amputate the elongated cervix and approximate the cardinal ligaments anterior to the cervix to elevate and retract it backwards so that the uterus is both supported and anteverted.
    • Cervix is reconstructed, and anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.
    • Curettage is performed at the onset of the operation to exclude the presence of intrauterine pathology.
    • Indicated in the reproductive age group with the prolapse and when the patient refuses hysterectomy
    • Done only if a family is complete because it can cause problems like cervical incompetence

 

Option B: Wertheim hysterectomy

  • Wertheim hysterectomy is a radical abdominal hysterectomy used for the treatment of cervical cancer.

Option C: Perineal exercise x 3 months

  • Perineal exercises can improve the symptoms to some extent, or atleast halt the progression of symptoms, but it is not the best management option.

Option D: Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair is a good management option in postmenopausal or old patients where uterus preservation is not a concern.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with no known co-morbid fell from his bike and sustained a traumatic brain injury resulting in marked expressive dysphasia. His GCS is 14/15 on arrival, and he is vitally stable. He has also sustained lacerations on his legs. CT Brain has been urgently performed, demonstrating findings of subarachnoid haemorrhage. He is also noted to have features of the cerebral salt-wasting syndrome. Which of the following will most likely be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyponatremia

  • In Subarachnoid Hemorrhage → BNP ↑ → Natriuresis → Salt loss, ↓ H2O → Hypovolemic Hyponatremia.
  • Cerebral salt wasting syndrome (CSWS) was proposed that natriuresis and hyponatremia sometimes accompany the intracranial disease, particularly subarachnoid haemorrhage, in which up to one-third of patients often develop hyponatremia.
  • A recent study found that the cause of hyponatremia was attributable to SIADH in 71.4% and acute glucocorticoid deficiency in 8.2%, with the remaining cases caused by incorrect intravenous fluid administration or hypovolemia.

Option A: Elevated serum cortisol

  • Acute cortisol deficiency accounts for a small but clinically important number of cases of hyponatremia.

Option B: Hypernatremia

  • Hyponatremia is the commonest electrolyte abnormality after subarachnoid haemorrhage, not hypernatremia.
  • The aetiology of hyponatremia after SAH is diverse and includes syndrome of inappropriate antidiuresis (SIADH), cerebral salt wasting, acute ACTH/glucocorticoid deficiency, excess iv fluids, and diuretic therapy, and appropriate therapy must be targeted to the correct aetiology to restore eu-natremia.
  • In Subarachnoid Hemorrhage → BNP ↑ → Natriuresis → Salt loss, ↓ H2O → Hypovolemic Hyponatremia.

Option D: Low urine sodium excretion

  • The association of cerebral pathology, hypoonatremia , and failure to retain urine sodium is termed cerebral salt wasting.
  • A low urine sodium concentration (UNa) suggests a non-renal cause of solute depletion, whereas a high UNa suggests renal causes of solute depletion. 
  • Diuretic use is the most common cause of hypovolemic hypo-osmolality.
  • Most etiologies of solute losses causing hypovolemic hypoosmolality will be clinically apparent, although some salt-wasting nephropathies and mineralocorticoid deficiency may be difficult to diagnose during the early phases of these diseases

questions.text: A 36-year-old male comes with a 2-day history of chest pain. The pain has been continuous and does not change with activity. Vital signs show normal blood pressure, mild tachycardia and tachypnea, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The cardiopulmonary exam is normal. An electrocardiogram shows a heart rate of 106 beats/min, left axis deviation, left ventricular hypertrophy, PR depression, and T wave inversions in V2 to V5. Troponin and CPK-MB are minimally elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pericarditis

  • On ECG, there is PR segment depression which denotes damage to the atrial myocardium.
  • The T wave inversion denotes damage to the ventricular myocardium.
  • So, there must be diffuse myocardial damage, which is possible in acute pericarditis.

Option B: Costochondritis

  • The pain of costochondritis is worsened with coughing, deep breathing, or physical activity, and it is usually associated with scoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoarthritis. Therefore it can be ruled out.

Option A: Pulmonary embolism

  • It can be ruled out because ECG findings of a pulmonary embolism are sinus tachycardia and a deep S wave in the lead I, a Q wave in III, and an inverted T wave in lead III, i.e. S1Q3T3 pattern, also known as McGinn-White sign.

Option D: Unstable angina 

  • ECG of unstable angina shows a normal ST normal segment. Sometimes, there is ST depression, and T wave inversion and hemodynamic parameters are normal, so it is unlikely to be unstable angina.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male IV drug user presents with a 3-week history of worsening lethargy and confusion. On examination, his pulse rate is 130bpm, and his blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals raised JVP with large v-waves and a loud systolic murmur. A palpable, pulsatile liver is felt when the hepato-jugular reflex is attempted. What type of murmur is most fitting with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tricuspid regurgitation

  • The patient's presentation, including a loud systolic murmur, a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) with large v-waves, and a palpable liver, suggests a specific type of heart murmur known as a Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) Murmur.

    Here's why:

  • Loud Systolic Murmur: A loud systolic murmur is characteristic of a tricuspid regurgitation murmur. This murmur occurs during systole when blood leaks backward through the incompetent tricuspid valve into the right atrium. This regurgitation creates a turbulent flow and produces the murmur.

  • Raised JVP with Large V-Waves: A raised JVP with large v-waves is indicative of significant tricuspid regurgitation. In TR, blood regurgitates from the right ventricle into the right atrium during systole. This increased blood volume in the right atrium leads to elevated JVP with prominent v-waves.

  • Palpable Liver: The palpable liver is a result of right-sided heart failure. Tricuspid regurgitation can lead to right-sided heart enlargement and failure, causing hepatic congestion and hepatomegaly.

Other options

Option A: Functional murmur

  • It is a heart murmur due to physiological condition outside the heart and not because of any structural defect in the heart
  • It is a systolic murmur of low amplitude and limited to a small area

Option B: Tricuspid stenosis

  • On ECG: large 'a' wave (d/t tricuspid stenosis, the Right atrium of the patient has to generate more force to push blood in forward
    direction)
  • Blunted y descent (due to stenosis filling in Right Ventricle is relatively slower)
  • Presystolic pulsation of liver is seen in Tricuspid stenosis
  • Mid diastolic murmur (like mitral stenosis) which becomes louder on inspiration is heard on left lower sternal border & radiates to the tricuspid area

Option C : Pulmonary stenosis

  • Features of pulmonary stenosis include ejection systolic murmur, ejection click absent, S4 heart sound present.
  • Chest X-ray: Upturned apex of heart
  • ECG: Right axis deviation
  • All right-sided events tend to increase with inspiration except pulmonary ejection click.

questions.text: A 61-year-old female patient presents to your clinic due to sudden episodes of left-sided facial pain for the last two days. She states that the pain feels like a 'sharp stabbing' and is a 9/10 in terms of intensity. The pain lasts about 5-10 seconds and then dissipates rapidly. The pain is often brought on by talking and cold wind. Her past medical history is significant for depression and type 2 D.M. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Trigeminal neuralgia

  • Trigeminal neuralgia is excruciating pain and needles sensations in lips, gums, cheeks, or chin.
  • Occurs spontaneously or with chewing, speaking, or smiling.
  • Presence of trigger zone (face, lips, tongue).
  • Provoked by the cold wind, brushing, or washing face.
  • Female > male.
  • Sudden in onset, persist for weeks to months and remits spontaneously.
  • The treatment for trigeminal neuralgia is anticonvulsant carbamazepine

Option A: Giant cell arteritis

  • Ruled out as it presents with jaw claudication or U/L headache, or temporal headache.

Option B: SUNCT syndrome

  • Ruled out is associated with conjunctival injection and tearing, so red eye should be present in the question.

Option D: Paroxysmal Hemicrania

  • Throbbing and stabbing pain at the temporal and orbit area
  • Duration 2-30 min
  • No alcohol or cutaneous trigger
  • Have autonomic and migrainous features
  • Respond well to Indomethacin.

questions.text: A thirty years old G2P1L1 female presents to your clinic with the complaint of intermittent jaundice. He says she has had jaundice for the past four years, and it comes and goes on its own. She had episodes of jaundice during each pregnancy, which used to start in the late second trimester. In between pregnancies, there was minimal or no jaundice. Initial investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Further investigations reveal that she has an MRP2 transporter defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dubin Johnson syndrome

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It occurs due to a defect in the multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2) protein.
  • Multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2), an ATP-dependent canalicular membrane transporter.
  • This protein is encoded by a gene known as ABCC2 Gene, which is mutated in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.
  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with mild jaundice.
  • Triggering agents/conditions: Pregnancy, Oral contraceptive pills and illness.
  • Kernicterus is absent, with a liver biopsy showing black pigmentation.

Option A: Menke’s disease

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder,
  • It is caused by mutations in genes coding for the copper-transport protein ATP7A.
  • This leads to copper deficiency.

Option C: Familial intrahepatic cholestasis

  • Familial intrahepatic cholestasis causes progressive liver disease, typically leading to liver failure.
  • It is not associated with MRP-2 defect.

Option D: Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis

  • Episodes of liver dysfunction called cholestasis characterize benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis.
  • It is not associated with MRP-2 defect.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presented with complaints of progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, night sweats. Initial investigations revealed B cell lymphocytosis. Flow cytometry results showed CD19,CD20,CD21,CD23,CD5 positive. He is also found to have NOTCH1 mutations, del(17)(p13.1). Which of the following transformation is likely to happen in this patient?

choices.text: Chronic lymphocytic lymphoma into diffuse large B cell lymphoma
Diffuse large B cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma
Small cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma
Chronic lymphocytic lymphoma into small cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
Option A: Chronic lymphocytic lymphoma into diffuse large B cell lymphoma

  • Progression of Chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/small cell lymphoma into diffuse large B cell lymphoma is “Richter transformation”.
  • It is associated with NOTCH1, Del (17)(13.1) mutations.
  • Clinical signs of Richter’s transformation are rapid progression in lymphadenopathy, fatigue, night sweats, fever and weight loss.
  • Treatment is chemotherapy + immunotherapy

Option B: Diffuse large B cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma

  • There is no evidence of the transformation of diffuse large B cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma.

Option C: Small cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma

  • There is no evidence of transformation of small cell lymphoma into chronic lymphocytic lymphoma.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic lymphoma into small cell lymphoma

  • There is no evidence of the transformation of chronic lymphocytic lymphoma into small cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. She further gives a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. CT scan revealed findings suggestive of bronchiectasis. Which lobe is most commonly affected in such patients with the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Left lower lobe

  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic respiratory disorder characterized by a clinical syndrome of productive cough, sputum production, and recurrent respiratory infections due to permanently dilated bronchi.
  • It is a heterogeneous disease; hence there are various causes of bronchiectasis, and the important differences in presentation depend on the different etiology.
  • The distribution of bronchiectasis may be generalized or localized, i.e., confined to one lobe.
  • In most cases, it is generalized, and the bronchiectasis lesions are most commonly found in the lower lobes because mucociliary clearance is facilitated by gravity in the upper lobes.
  • The left lower lobe and the lingulae are the most commonly affected.
  • The bronchiectasis lesions are identified most commonly in the left lower lobe, followed by the right lower lobe and left upper lobe.
  • Ct scan is the most important modality for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.
  • It demonstrates the airways and, to some degree, can helpdistinguish the underlying cause.
  • The most common organisms causing bronchiectasis: Haemophilus influenza (15%), Staphylococcus aureus (13%), Streptococcus pneumonia (5%), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (5%), and Mycoplasma pneumonia (5%)

Option A: Right upper lobe

  • The upper lobes are less frequently involved due to facilitated mucociliary clearance by gravity.

Option B: Right middle lobe

  • The right middle lobes are the second most common location of bronchiectasis, followed by the left lower lobe and lingulae.
  • It mostly occurs in the setting of tuberculosis.

Option C: Left upper lobe

  • The upper lobes are less frequently involved due to facilitated mucociliary clearance by gravity.

questions.text: A pediatrician orders a Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay in a child suspected of phenylketonuria. Which of the following will this test detect?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • In PKU, Ketoacids are produced from excess phenylalanine which give musty odor.

Guthrie's bacterial inhibition test:

  • Screening test for phenylketonuria (PKU)
  • Used to detect the abnormal presence of phenylalanine metabolites in blood i.e.
    • Phenyl pyruvate
    • Phenylacetate
    • Phenyl lactate

Procedure:

  • A small blood sample is taken from the infant's heel and placed in a medium with a strain of Bacillus subtilis, a bacteria that cannot grow without phenylalanine.
  • If phenylalanine metabolites are present, these bacteria reproduce, and the test result is positive, indicating that the patient has PKU.

Ferric chloride test:

Another Diagnostic test for phenylketonuria is the ferric chloride test. This is a screening test in urine samples for phenyl ketones and hence gives a positive result for phenylpyruvate

It is also positive for:

  • Tyrosinemia
  • MSUD
  • Alkaptonuria

However the best method for newborn screening used now a days is mass spectrometry analysis of blood to detect the excess phenylalaline and other metabolites. It has very high sensitivity and can screen for multiple metabolites in single assay in a very short time..

Option A, B and C: refer to explanation of D.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of lower back pain and cyclical dysmenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has been married for the last 4 years and has never conceived. She is referred to the infertility clinic for further evaluation. The patient has regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. Further investigations revealed dark red to bluish vesicles surrounded by flame-like lesions on the peritoneum. Which of the following is the most common site for a lesion?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ovary

  • The most common site of endometriosis is the ovary.
  • Endometriosis is a disorder where tissue resembling the uterus lining grows in some places, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes. Endometriosis affects women of any age.
  • The picture below shows the endometriosis in the ovary:

 

 

  • Endometriotic dysmenorrhea is classically congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea.
  • Other common sites are fallopian tubes, pelvic peritoneum, and uterosacral ligaments. Other sites are less common and occur in:
    • Bowel
    • Lung (periodic hemoptysis)
    • Nose (periodic epistaxis)
    • Eyes (periodic subconjunctival haemorrhage)
    • Previous surgical scar (scar endometriosis, periodic bleeding from a previous surgical scar)
  • Presentation of Endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea) dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
    • Pelvic mass
    • Menstrual abnormalities
    • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
    • Specific symptoms of extrapelvic endometriosis
    • Examination may reveal a cystic pelvic mass suggestive of ovarian endometriosis or a fixed retroverted uterus (suggestive of pelvic adhesions), tenderness or nodularity in POD (suggestive of peritoneal deposits)

Option A: Fallopian tube

  • It is also a site for endometriosis. However, the more common site is the ovary.

Option B: Cervix

  • It rarely harbours endometriotic deposits.

Option D: Vagina

  • It also rarely shows endometriotic deposits.

questions.text: A 30-years-old primigravida with diabetes mellitus at 30 weeks gestation is admitted to the ICU with multiorgan dysfunction. She is oriented in time and place. She has had mild lower abdominal pain for the last few days and reports no trauma history. Her lab parameters suggest thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and an INR of 2.1. Her blood sugar level is 180mg/dL. Which of the following is a common underlying cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Placental abruption

  • This patient has presented with thrombocytopenia, deranged INR and decreased fibrinogen. All are suggestive of DIC. An important cause of DIC in obsterics is placental abruption.
  • Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from its normal attachment site. It may lead to concealed or visible external haemorrhage. In cases of significant haemorrhage, consumption and activation of coagulation cascade may lead to consumption coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) in patients. 

CONSUMPTIVE COAGULOPATHY/ DIC IN OBSTETRICS

  • In the accidental haemorrhage / abruptio placentae, there is intravascular activation of clotting secondary to a significant retroplacental bleed, leading to more procoagulant consumption.
  • DIC is more likely with concealed haemorrhage because of higher intrauterine pressure
  • The retroplacental clot triggers tissue thromboplastin factor, triggering disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

COMMON UNDERLYING CAUSES OF DIC:

Endothelial Injury

Release of Thromboplastin

Release of Phospholipids

Preeclampsia, eclampsia, HELLP

Hypovolemia

Septicemia

Septic abortion

Chorioamnionitis
