Amniotic fluid embolism

IUFD

Abruptio placentae

Intra-amniotic hypertonic saline

Incompatible blood transfusion

Option A: Gestational diabetes

  • Gestational diabetes is diagnosed in pregnant patients after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Such patients have underlying risk factors, such as obesity and prior gestational diabetes.
  • Patients that have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus prior to pregnancy cannot be diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
  • DIC is not caused by GDM, however chances of DIC are more in overt diabeteics

Option C: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is the attachment of the placenta at or near the internal cervical opening instead of its normal attachment site.
  • It causes visible external bleeding.
  • Placenta previa does not cause DIC unless associated with massive hemorhhage.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: Rupture of the uterus

  • The uterus rupture is an obstetrics emergency that leads to the rapid demise of the fetus and/or mother.
  • Emergency C-section with the repair of the uterus is indicated.
  • Uterine rupture would cause DIC only if associated with massive hemorrhage

questions.text: A 70-year old male underwent transurethral resection of the prostate for BPH under spinal anaesthesia. The patient is positioned in a lithotomy posture, and the surgery is done successfully. What is the most common complication that can occur because of the injury during surgery?
questions.solution:
Option C: Retrograde ejaculation

  • The transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is the surgery done under spinal anaesthesia, in which a 26Fr resectoscope with a 30-degree telescope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder. Cysto-urethroscopy is done. The prostate is assessed for size. Both ureteric orifices are inspected, and the bladder is seen. Strips of tissues are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of verumontanum using a diathermy loop mounted in front of the scoop. First median lobe and then lateral lobes are resected. Chips of a prostate pass forward to the bladder, and the Ellik evacuator evacuates these pieces.
  • Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication that occurs during surgery. It is due to injury of the internal urinary sphincter.
  • Retrograde ejaculation is the process in which semen enters the bladder instead of discharging through the penis.
  • The internal urinary sphincter is under the control of the L1 sympathetic ganglion. And ejaculation is under the sympathetic system.
  • Normally, at the time of ejaculation, the internal urinary sphincter is closed. But with the injury of the internal urinary sphincter, it can’t function properly.
  • Retrograde ejaculation is seen after:
    • TURP (Injury of Internal urinary sphincter)
    • Bilateral Lumbar sympathectomy
    • α Blockers (Relaxation of Smooth muscles of internal urinary sphincter)      

Option A:  Erectile dysfunction

  • The erection is under the control of the parasympathetic system, so erectile dysfunction is not a complication of TURP.  

Option B: TURP syndrome

  • The complication after surgery due to continuous irrigation leads to dilutional hyponatremia called TURP syndrome.

Option D: Urinary incontinence

  • It is least common complication may be < 1% of cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of swelling in front of her neck. She gives a history of irradiation to her neck during her childhood for Hodgkin lymphoma, which was cured. Her neck examination reveals a hard mass in front of her neck. A FNAC of the thyroid lump is done, which confirms a thyroid carcinoma with no lymph node involvement. Her biopsy picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Papillary carcinoma

  • In the case mentioned above, the patient's clinical features of swelling in the front of the neck associated with hoarseness of voice and biopsy findings suggest Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
  • Pathology of papillary thyroid carcinoma:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei aka Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Dystrophic calcification- Psammoma bodies

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and usually is associated with an excellent prognosis, particularly in young patients.
  • Occasionally, a metastatic PTC manifests as a painless lateral neck mass that is clinically detected before detecting the primary thyroid lesion called lateral aberrant thyroid
  • Prognostic risk classification for PTC includes the AGES and AMES scoring systems.
  • The absence of distant metastasis at initial treatment and size less than 4cm are other important positive predictors.
  • Total Thyroidectomy is recommended for all PTCs 1cm or larger
  • PTCs less than 1 cm in diameter are defined as microcarcinomas.

Option B: Follicular carcinoma

  • Follicular thyroid cancer is the second most common type, making up about 10 to 15% of all thyroid cancers.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of thyroid cancer.
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) cells can be secreted by various tumor markers, including calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).

Option D: None of the above

  • The clinical case and biopsy picture above suggest Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 21 Yr old male came to the hospital with complaints of vague abdominal pain associated with the passage of black, tarry stools. His blood pressure is 110/70mmHg, and his pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows a diffusely tender abdomen. His medical history includes several months of multiple joint pain. His lab results revealed that he has ANCA-negative vasculitis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa

  • Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries. 
  • The most common arteries involved are 
    • Renal
    • Mesenteric 
  • Usually, the pulmonary arteries are spared. 
  • It is linked to the hepatitis B virus rather than the ANCA. 
  • HBsAg and HBsAb combine to form complexes that accumulate in arteries. 
  • The symptoms are caused by infarction of the involved arteries. 
  • Ischemia is caused by a lack of blood supply distal to the involved region of the artery. 
  • Morphological Features are 
    • Transmural necrotising inflammation 
    • Superimposed aneurysm or thrombosis 
    • Infiltration of neutrophils, eosinophils and mononuclear cells in the arterial wall. 
    • Fibrinoid necrosis 
    • Luminal fibrosis 
  • Common symptoms are 
    • Myalgia 
    • Peripheral neuritis 

Option A: Wegner granulomatosis

  • Wegner granulomatosis involves ENT regions, lungs and kidneys. 
  • It is associated with c-ANCA 

Option B: Churg strauss syndrome

  • It is also known as allergic granulomatosis 
  • It affects small vessels. 
  • It is associated with P - ANCA.

Option D: Microscopic polyangiitis

  • It is a type of vasculitis that affects small arteries and venules. 
  • It is associated with P-ANCA.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents to the gastroenterology outpatient department with complaints of constipation followed by diarrhoea for the last three months. She is diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome and noted that it is constipation dominant. The medication lubiprostone is advised for this patient. What is the mechanism of action of the drug involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chloride channel activator

  • In this case, the patient presented with on-and-off constipation and diarrhoea and has been diagnosed with constipation-dominant IBS. She is given lubiprostone for the treatment of this disease.
  • Lubiprostone activates type 2 chloride channels located in epithelial cells. This results in an efflux of chloride into the lumen of the intestine.
  • Due to the change in an osmotic gradient across the intestinal wall, the resultant fluid secretion into the lumen causes a bolus effect. This softens the stool, increases intestinal transit, and relieves constipation.
  • Lubiprostone has low systemic bioavailability because it acts locally, inside the intestinal tract and is rapidly metabolized.

Option B: Chloride channel inhibitor

  • Lubiprostone acts on the intestinal epithelial border and stimulates chloride channels.

Option C: Sodium channel activator

  • Sodium channels are activated by drugs such as aconitine and grayanotoxin.

Option D: Sodium channel inhibitor

  • Quinidine and procainamide are two of the many drugs that inhibit sodium channels.

questions.text: A seventy-four years old male is brought to the emergency department by his son. The patient is somnolent but responds to voice commands. His son states that his father has been acting weird lately, and his behaviour has been very inappropriate. He gets aggressive occasionally and is tired and lethargic the rest of the while. Since then, he has become excessively drowsy now. He is a chronic patient of hepatitis C. The histological findings of a liver biopsy taken from a hepatitis C patient show apoptotic bodies. Apoptotic cells exude soluble substances that attract phagocytes. Some cells may also create proteins that attach to apoptotic cells, causing them to be engulfed. Which of the following cells participates in this "efferocytosis" process?
questions.solution:
Option A: Macrophages

  • Cells that are dying by apoptosis also secrete soluble factors that recruit phagocytes.
  • Macrophages may produce proteins that bind to apoptotic cells (but not live cells), leading to their engulfment.
  • Apoptotic bodies may also become coated with natural antibodies and proteins of the complement system, notably C1q, which are recognized by phagocytes.
  • Thus, numerous ligands induced on apoptotic cells serve as “eat me” signals and are recognized by receptors on phagocytes that bind and engulf these cells.
  • This process of apoptotic cell phagocytosis is called efferocytosis; it is so efficient that dead cells disappear, often within minutes, without leaving a trace.

Option B: T lymphocytes

  • Macrophages secrete proteins that bind to apoptotic cells leading to the engulfment of cells.
  • T lymphocytes are not involved in this process.

Option C: B lymphocytes

  • Macrophages secrete proteins that bind to apoptotic cells leading to the engulfment of cells.
  • B lymphocytes are not involved in this process.

Option D: NK cells

  • Macrophages secrete proteins that bind to apoptotic cells leading to the engulfment of cells.
  • NK cells are not involved in this process.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man underwent phacoemulsification surgery and placement of a foldable intraocular lens in the left eye secondary to a cataract a year back. He now presents to the outpatient department with complaints of hazy vision in that eye. There is no associated redness, pain or watering of the eye. The commonest postoperative complication of cataract surgery is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior capsular opacification:

  • Also called an 'After cataract’ or ‘secondary cataract’.
  • It is the most common late postoperative complication of cataract surgery.
  • It is usually present after 1 year of cataract surgery.
  • It is the opacity that either persists or develops after lens extraction.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Blurry or hazy vision, night blindness, a halo around lights, double vision.

Causes may include:

  • Residual opaque lens matter may persist when it is imprisoned between the remains of the anterior and posterior capsule, surrounded by fibrin or blood.
  • Proliferative type: may develop from left-out anterior epithelial cells.

Treatment:

  • YAG-laser capsulotomy, surgical membranectomy.

Other Complications of Cataract Surgery:

  • Early postoperative complications: Hyphema (collection of blood in the anterior chamber), Iris prolapse, striate keratopathy, flat anterior chamber, postoperative anterior uveitis, toxic anterior segment syndrome, bacterial endophthalmitis.
  • Late postoperative complications: cystoid macular edema, delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy, retinal detachment, epithelial ingrowth, fibrous down growth, After-cataract, glaucoma-in-aphakia and pseudophakia.

Option B: Cystoid macular edema

  • Cystic collection of fluid in the Henle's layer of the macula is a frequent complication of cataract surgery, but it presents within 2-3 months of surgery.
  • In most cases, it does not cause any visual symptoms and spontaneously regresses with time.
  • Fundoscopy may show a honeycomb appearance.
  • Fluorescein angiography may show flower petal patterns due to dye leakage from perifoveal capillaries.

Option C: Neovascular glaucoma

  • It is intractable glaucoma caused by neovascularization of the iris and the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • May present with intense eye pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, blurred vision, red eye and tenderness around the eyes.
  • It usually occurs in conditions which predispose to hypoxia (retinal ischemia), like DM (progressive diabetic retinopathy) and CRVO (central retinal vein occlusion).
  • Other causes include sickle-cell retinopathy, long-standing retinal detachment, and chronic intraocular inflammations.
  • It does not occur as a complication of cataract surgery.

Option D: Chorioretinitis

  • It is the inflammation of the choroid and overlying retina.
  • Also called posterior uveitis.
  • Chorioretinitis usually occurs in toxoplasma, herpes, CMV, TB and other infectious and autoimmune conditions.
  • It does not occur as a complication of cataract surgery

questions.text: A community medicine intern was explaining various national programmes to the village population. Which among the following is the correct program for screening developmental delay, deficiency, and neonatal genetic defects?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rashtriya Bal Swasthya karyakaram (RBSK)

  • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram- RBSK (Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Services) is an initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 ‘D’s viz. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Development delays including disability.

Option A: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

  • Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under NRHM being implemented by promoting institutional delivery amount poor pregnant women.
  • Launched on 12th April 2005.
  • It is a modification of the National Maternity Benefit Scheme.
  • Objectives of JSY: Reduction of maternal mortality and infant mortality (through institutional deliveries and care especially for poor women).

Option B: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)

  • Pregnant women components:
    • Free deliveries (including cesarean section) in public health institutions.
    • Free drugs and consumables.
    • Free diet (Normal delivery: 3 days; Caesarean section: 7 days).
    • Free diagnostics
    • Free blood transfusion (whenever required).
    • Free transport from home to the institution.
  • Child health components:
    • Nutritional rehabilitation centres (NRCs): Inpatient treatment of severely malnourished children and counseling of mothers on proper feeding.
    • Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses (IMNCI): Management of common childhood illnesses.
    • Pre-service IMNCI: Included in medical curriculum to generate trained IMNCI manpower.
    • Facility-based IMNCI (F-IMNCI): Focus on inpatient management of major causes of neonatal and childhood mortality, viz. asphyxia, sepsis, low birth weight, pneumonia, diarrhea, malaria, meningitis, and severe malnutrition.

Option D: Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK)

  • India’s first comprehensive adolescent health program.
    • Development of adolescent population (10-19 yrs); Weekly supplementation of 60mg of iron & 500 mcg Folic Acid.
    • Develop menstrual hygiene by giving a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rs by ASHA.
    • Enhancement of mental health; prevention of violence, and abuse.
  • Target Group: Adolescents 10-19 years of age (243 million; 21% of Indian population) in Urban and rural areas.
  • Strategy: RMNCH+A (Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child Health + Adolescent).

questions.text: The Child-Pugh score puts patients into three categories of Score A (<7), Score B (7-9), and Score C (10-15). The following is a type of which scale?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ordinal

  • Child-Pugh Score' divides the scores into 3 CATEGORIES, hence it is a CATEGORICAL scale.
  • The variables are qualitative and arranged in an order of increasing severity, hence it is an example of an ORDINAL scale.
  • Examples: TNM staging (cancers), Severity of disease, Social classes.

Option A: Nominal

  • Based on NOM (names); No specific order.
  • Examples: Race, Religion, Country of birth, Clinical features, Sites of lymphadenopathy, Sex of child, Type of anemia, ABO blood group, Site of malignancy.

Option C: Quantitative

  • Quantitative variable: It is a variable that can be measured directly.
  • Measured on an ordinal/metric scale.
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Mid-arm circumference, Blood sugar level, ºC/ ºF temperature scale, Body mass index (BMI), Hemoglobin level, and Serum cholesterol level.

Option D: Continuous

  • Continuous variable: It is a variable that has a large number of possible values & several in-between values.
  • Measured on a metric scale.
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Mid-arm circumference, Blood sugar level, ºC/ ºF temperature scale, Body mass index (BMI), Hemoglobin level, and Serum cholesterol level.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female undergoing hysteroscopic myomectomy for submucosal fibroid is noted to have a 500ml fluid deficit while using 1.5 % glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. What is the next step?

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.solution:
Option C: Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

  • Alert at a deficit of more than
    • 750 ml in non-electrolyte distention media like glycine
    • 1000 ml in electrolyte media like NaCl
  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media
  • Excess of non-electrolyte media like glycine can cause hyperammonemia.
  • Excess electrolyte media like saline of more than 2500ml can cause:
    • fluid overload
    • pulmonary oedema
    • cardiac failure.
  • In the abovementioned cases, furosemide must be given to remove the excess fluid.

Option A: Stop the surgery

  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media

Option B: Change the fluid to normal saline

  • Confers no extra benefit

Option D: Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

  • Furosemide needs to be given to remove the excess fluid in case of excess of electrolyte media.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with high-grade fever, shortness of breath, chest pain and dry cough for the last 7 days visited the OPD. He recently travelled from the Middle East and developed symptoms soon afterwards. On physical examination, his chest showed widespread crepitations. Chest X-ray showed in both lung fields. After RT-PCR testing, a clinical diagnosis of the severe acute respiratory syndrome was made. SARS is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Coronavirus

  • A severe acute respiratory syndrome is caused by SARS-CoV (Coronavirus).

  • SARS-CoV (Severe acute respiratory syndrome) is an RNA virus.

  • SARS-CoV-2 attaches to the host cell by binding its S protein to the receptor protein, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2).

  • Spread of the virus

    • Coronaviruses, such as SARS-CoV, can spread through close human contact and droplets from coughing and sneezing.

Symptoms

  • Symptoms appear 2–7 days after a person is exposed to the virus.

    •  The first symptom is a high fever of more than 100.4°F.

  • After 7–10 days, the person might then have noticed the following:

  • Dry cough

  • Shortness of breath

  • Low oxygen levels in the body, known as hypoxia

  • Most people with SARS develop pneumonia.

Diagnosis

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), for a diagnosis of SARS, a person must have the following features:

  • A fever of at least 100.4°F (38°C)

  • One or more symptoms of lower respiratory tract illness, such as cough, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath

  • Radiographic evidence suggests pneumonia

  • No alternative diagnosis to explain the illness

Treatment

  • Isolate the patients and use barrier techniques to prevent spreading, including face masks and goggles.

  • No drugs, including antibiotics, were found to be effective. Supportive care was done.

Prevention

  • Washing hands frequently or cleaning with an alcohol-based detergent.

  • Avoid touching the eyes, mouth, and nose with unclean hands

  • Covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing

  • Avoiding sharing food, drinks, and utensils

  • Staying at least 3 feet away from other people

  • Regularly cleaning surfaces with disinfectant.

Option A: H1N1

  • The influenza virus causes swine flu. It is a respiratory disease of pigs, but few human outbreaks have occurred.

  • The symptoms of the novel H1N1 flu virus in people are similar to the symptoms of seasonal flu and include fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, and fatigue. Sometimes, diarrhoea and vomiting also occur.

  • In a few cases, it may progress to cause pneumonia and respiratory failure.

  • Proper preventive methods and vaccination can prevent one from getting an influenza virus infection.

Option B: RSV

  • RSV (Respiratory syncytial virus) causes acute bronchiolitis in the age group of 1 to 6 months.

  • It causes fever, runny nose, cough, and sneezing.

  • Most people recover in a week, but RSV can be serious, especially for infants and older adults.

  • It is detected by PCR or ELISA and treated with antivirals.

Option C: Parainfluenza virus

  • Symptoms may include fever, runny nose, and cough. Patients usually recover on their own

  • Para influenza type 1 & 2 causes Croup (Acute laryngotracheobronchitis) which radiologically shows steeple signs.

  • Para influenza type 3 causes LRTI( lower respiratory tract infection)

  • It is treated with over-the-counter medicines like acetaminophen.

questions.text: A middle aged adult undergoes orchiectomy. Looking at the gross and the histological findings, which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most common germ cell tumor seen in middle-aged adults: Seminoma
  • Gross findings: Well circumscribed, no hemorrhage, no necrosis
  • M/E: Tumor cells have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery cytoplasm.

questions.text: RNA with catalytic activity are known as Ribozymes? Which of the following is not a feature of the ribozymes but is a feature protein enzymes.
questions.solution:
Option B: ATP use

Ribozyme:

  • Ribozymes are RNA molecules that act as an enzyme in a biochemical reaction.
  • They mostly catalyze the synthesis and breakage of phosphodiester bonds.
  • They can bind specifically and cleave an mRNA substrate.
  • No ATP is used in their reaction whereas some of the protein enzymes such as synthetases uses ATP for their catalytic action.
  • The mechanism of action of ribozyme usually involve binding the substrate, bringing them in proper orientation and proximity which help in group transfer or breaking or making of bonds. 

Other differences between ribozymes and protein enzymes:

 

Ribozymes

Protein enzymes

Composed of

Ribonucleotide

Amino acid

Abundance

Less abundant

More abundant

Example

snRNA, rRNA, ribonuclease p, hepatitis delta, varkud satellite ribozyme, etc.

 

Amylase, lipase, trypsin, maltase, sucrase, lactase, protease, pepsin, etc.

Option A: Kinetic behavior

  • Both ribozymes and protein enzymes has same kinetic behavior. 
  • It means that their kinetic parameters are affected by same factors such as substrate conc., enzyme conc., temperature, pH and inhibitors etc. 

Option C: Specificity

  • Both ribozymes and protein enzymes specifically acts on their substrates.
  • It means that a given enzyme will catalyze reaction of its particular substrate.

Option D: Able to get competitively inhibited

  • Ribozymes and protein enzymes can be competitively inhibited by their substrate analogs.

questions.text: An obstetrician instructs her resident to give a PGF2 alpha injection after trying oxytocin, methylergometrine, and misoprostol to manage PPH. After a few minutes of relief, the patient starts to bleed again, so the doctor asks for a repeat dose of PGF2 alpha. Which of the following is the maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in PPH management which can be given over 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2 mg

  • IM: 0.25 mg, Every 15-30 min,
  • Maximum dose: 8 doses/24 hrs (Total 2mg).
  • Inj. Carboprost (PGF α) stimulates uterine contraction.
  • Never given via I/V route
  • Contraindication: Asthma 
  • S/E: Diarrhea 

Incorrect options:

Option A: 250 μg

Option B: 200 μg

Option D: 20 mg

questions.text: A 49-year-old male complains of diplopia, slurred speech, breathing difficulty, eyelid drooping, and fatigue worsening throughout the day for a month. Symptoms improve with rest. Vital signs stable. No other abnormalities on exam. Which agent differentiates current pathology from the cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT OPTION:

Option D: Edrophonium 2 mg

  • This is a case of myasthenia gravis
  • Edrophonium, which is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is given to patients with myasthenia gravis; a short-lasting improvement in the strength of affected muscles occurs only in myasthenia gravis and not in other muscular dystrophies. This is known as the ameliorative effect and is called the ‘Tensilon’ test.
  • The diagnosis of myasthenia gravis can be confirmed by the 'edrophonium test'. Edrophonium is injected I.V. (2 mg initially which if tolerated; followed by 8 mg after 30-60 sec). Reversal of ptosis, diplopia and increase in the strength of affected muscles lasting 5-10 min constitutes a positive result.
  • Edrophonium Resembles neostigmine in action. has a brief duration (10-30 min), suitable only as a diagnostic agent for myasthenia gravis.
  • Whereas, if the patient is in a cholinergic crisis, edrophonium will further worsen the symptoms. So, it can be used to differentiate myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

Option A: Echothiophate

  • Echothiophate is an irreversible inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase.
  • It is used in the treatment of glaucoma and accommodative esotropia.

Option B: Edrophonium 4 mg

  • The diagnosis of myasthenia gravis can be confirmed by the 'edrophonium test'. Edrophonium is injected I.V. (2 mg initially which if tolerated; followed by 8 mg after 30-60 sec). Reversal of ptosis, diplopia and increase in the strength of affected muscles lasting 5-10 min constitutes a positive result.

Option C: Neostigmine

  • Neostigmine is a drug which inhibits the enzyme cholinesterase.
  • It is commonly used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis but is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: In a town of 20,000 population, a total of 456 births were there in a year out of which 56 were dead born. There were 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and another 34 had died after 28 days and before completing the first birthday. What is the Infant mortality rate in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 225

  • The infant mortality rate (IMR) is calculated as the number of infant deaths (under one year of age) per 1,000 live births.
  • Total live births = 456 - 56 (dead born) = 400
  • Total infant deaths = 56 (within 28 days) + 34 (between 28 days and first birthday) = 90
  • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) x 1000
    • IMR = (90 / 400) x 1000
    • IMR = 225
  • So, the infant mortality rate in this area is 225 per 1,000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with vision problems, light-colored skin, learning disabilities, and a dipped chest bone. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 32. Ophthalmologic examination reveals downward and inward lens subluxation. What is the most likely amino acid accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Homocysteine

Homocystinuria

  • Classic homocystinuria is caused by a deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase
  • Methionine synthase deficiency and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase deficiency can also lead to homocystinuria.
  • Homocysteine accumulation led to a stroke, atherosclerosis, MI, and pulmonary embolism.
  • Homocysteine binds with the endothelium of the blood vessels and activates signaling pathways, which leads to the release of pro-inflammatory molecules. Atherosclerosis is initiated due to endothelial injury. Endothelial injury leads to macrophage and LDL accumulation. This eventually leads to foam cell and fatty streak formation. The extracellular matrix is deposited, and it leads to the development of fibrous plaque
  • Presentation of homocystinuria includes
    • Extensive atheroma formation at a young age affects many arteries but not the coronary arteries.
    • Intravascular thrombosis
    • Osteoporosis
    • Marfanoid habitus, which includes long limbs, dipped in chest bone, crowded oral maxilla, high arch palate, arachnodactyly, and hyperlaxity.
    • Ocular changes which include downward and inwards subluxation of the lens.
    • Atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases which may include angina and myocardial infarction. Stroke is also seen in the patients.
    • Kyphosis and other backbone anomalies.
    • Intellectual disabilities
    • Developmental problems
  • Laboratory investigations show elevated homocysteine levels in the urine.
  • A high-protein diet, especially one that includes red meat and dairy products, can increase blood levels of homocysteine.
  • Vitamin B6 supplementation and dietary modifications may be used for the management of the condition

Option A: Methionine

  • Methionine is not associated with the development of atherosclerosis. Disorders of methionine metabolism include hypermethioninemia.
  • Hypermethioninemia is an excess of a particular protein-building block methionine in the blood. This condition can occur when methionine is not broken down in the body.

Option B: Cysteine

  • Cysteine metabolism defect leads to the development of cystinuria. Cystinuria is not associated with the development of atherosclerotic plaque
  • Cystinuria is characterized by recurrent cystine kidney stones.
  • Treatment includes urine alkalinization and chelating agents and a low intake of methionine.

Option D: Leucine

  • Leucine metabolism disorders are not associated with premature atherosclerosis.
  • Low levels of leucine present with decreased appetite, lethargy, poor feeding, weight loss, skin rash, hair loss, etc.
  • It can also lead to blood sugar fluctuations and muscle weakness.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings:



Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chalazion

  • The given image shows Arlt's line on the upper palpebral conjunctiva - a feature of trachoma.
  • It does not cause chalazion.

Chalazion:

  • A chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Etiology:
    • It is probably due to chronic irritation caused by an organism of low virulence.
  • The glandular tissue is replaced by granulation tissue containing giant cells predominantly.
  • It is often multiple occurring in crops. 
  • It is more common in adults than in children. 
  • Seen in people with oily skin and ocular rosacea.
  • Symptoms
    1. There is no pain unless the chalazion is secondarily infected.
    2. There is disfigurement due to the presence of swelling in the lid.
    3. It may be single or multiple.
  • Signs
    1. A small non-tender hard swelling in the lid, slightly away from the lid margin, is seen.
    2. There are no signs of acute inflammation.
    3. On everting the lid, the conjunctiva over the swelling is red or purple. It is grey in later stages. It may be yellow when secondarily infected by pyogenic organisms.
  • Treatment:
    • It is incised and thoroughly scraped.
    • Injection of triamcinolone directly into the chalazion may cause complete resolution.

Option A: Corneal opacity

  • Trachoma can cause corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness.

Option C: Entropion

  • Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelashes, which can lead to conjunctivitis due to constant irritation.
  • It is a feature of trachoma.

Option D: Herbert's pits

  • In trachoma, regression of the follicles leads to depressed, round, thinned areas known clinically as Herbert's pits.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the eye clinic with a history of redness, pain, and mild diminution of vision in one eye for the past 3 days. The patient also has a history of low backache for the past year. On examination, circumcorneal congestion with the clear cornea and a few fine keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium with 2+ cells in the anterior chamber. Anterior chamber depth is normal, and IOP is also within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: An acute attack of angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
Option B: HLA B-27-related anterior uveitis

  • The history of backache with the features of anterior uveitis (circumcorneal congestion, few fine keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium, 2+ cells in the anterior chamber) point towards HLA B27 associated uveitis.
  • HLA-B27-related anterior uveitis is seen with ankylosing spondylitis and Reiter's syndrome.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an idiopathic chronic inflammatory arthritis, usually involving the sacroiliac and posterior inter-vertebral joints.
  • The disease affects young males (20-40 years) who are positive for HLA-B27.
  • About 30 to 35 percent of patients with ankylosing spondylitis develop uveitis.
  • Uveitis associated with ankylosing spondylitis is an acute, recurrent, non-granulomatous type of iridocyclitis. The disease usually affects one eye at a time.
  • Reiter's syndrome is characterized by a triad of urethritis, arthritis, and conjunctivitis. In 20 to 30 percent of cases, acute non-granulomatous uveitis is also associated.
  • The ocular manifestations include:
    • Acute mucopurulent conjunctivitis may be associated with superficial punctate keratitis.
    • Acute non-granulomatous type of iridocyclitis occurs in 20-30 percent cases of Reiter’s syndrome.

Option A: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis-associated uveitis

  • The clinical history, signs, and symptoms in the scenario are inconsistent with Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is an idiopathic chronic inflammatory arthritis involving multiple joints in children below the age of 16 years. Anterior uveitis associated with this condition is a bilateral (70%), chronic non-granulomatous disease, affecting female children more than males (4:1). It usually develops before the age of 6 years.
  • Nearly half of the patients are positive for HLA-DW5 and 75 percent for antinuclear antibodies.
  • The onset of uveitis is asymptomatic, and the eye is white even in the presence of severe uveitis. Therefore, the slit-lamp examination is mandatory in children suffering from JIA.
  • Complications like posterior synechiae, complicated cataracts, and band-shaped keratopathy are fairly common.

Option C: An acute attack of angle closure glaucoma

  • The clinical history, signs, and symptoms given in the scenario are not consistent with the acute attack of angle closure glaucoma.
  • The patient presents with an attack of sudden onset of severe pain in the eye, which radiates along the branches of the fifth nerve.
  • Frequently there is a history of associated nausea, vomiting, and prostrations. There is a history of rapidly progressive vision loss, redness, photophobia, and watering.
  • The signs are as follows:
    • Lids may be edematous.
    • The conjunctiva is chemo used and congested.
    • The cornea becomes edematous and insensitive.
    • The anterior chamber is very shallow.
    • Iris may be discolored.
  • The pupil is semi-dilated, vertically oval, and fixed.
  • IOP is markedly elevated, usually between 40 and 70 mm of Hg.
  • The optic disc is edematous and hyperaemic.

Option D: Herpetic keratitis

  • The clinical history, signs, and symptoms in the scenario are inconsistent with herpetic keratitis.
  • Ocular infections with herpes simplex virus (HSV) are extremely common and constitute herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and iritis.
  • Ocular involvement by HSV occurs in primary and recurrent forms, with the following lesions.
  • Primary herpes.
    • Skin lesions.
    • Conjunctiva-acute follicular conjunctivitis.
    • Cornea.
      • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis.
      • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis.
      • Dendritic ulcer.
  • Recurrent herpes:
    • Active epithelial keratitis.
    • Stromal keratitis.
    • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic).
    • Herpetic iridocyclitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis presents to an ophthalmologist complaining of non-specific irritation of gradual onset in the right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist finds that her vision is unaffected, but there are necrotic scleral plaques near the limbus without vascular congestion, as shown below. Her daughter noticed a change in the color of the sclera. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Scleromalacia perforans

  • The above is a case of scleromalacia perforans change in color with unaffected vision necrotic scleral plaques suggestive.
  • Necrotizing scleritis without inflammation is called scleromalacia perforans.
  • It occurs in patients who have long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • There are minimal signs of inflammation, and the condition is painless with no redness.
  • Vision remains unaffected.

Option A: Equatorial staphyloma

  • Staphyloma is the ectasia of the outer coats (cornea, sclera or both).
  • It is usually due to inflammatory conditions or trauma, but not autoimmune diseases.

Option B: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum

  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is a progressive disorder characterized by accumulated calcium deposits and other minerals (mineralization) in elastic fibers.
  • Elastic fibers are a connective tissue component, providing strength and flexibility to structures throughout the body.

Option C: Nodular episcleritis

  • It is characterized by a discrete, elevated area of inflamed episcleral tissue. In simple episcleritis, vascular congestion is present without an obvious nodule.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by the paramedics after he collapsed at his house an hour ago. He is unable to understand speech and written words. Physical examination reveals contralateral superior quadrantanopia. CT scan of the head without contrast shows a middle cerebral artery (MCA) lesion. Which of the following MCA branch is responsible for this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery– inferior division
M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery – superior division
M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Option A: M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery– inferior division

  • The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) arises from the Internal carotid artery and supplies the cerebrum, temporal lobes, and insular cortices.
  • The MCA then divides into 4 segments: M1, M2, M3, M4
    • The M1 segment starts from the internal carotid artery and ends at the bifurcation.
    • The M2 segment starts at the bifurcation, travels next to the Sylvian fissure, and ends in branches to the cerebral cortex.
    • The M3 segment travels externally through the insula into the cortex.
    • The M4 segment extends from the Sylvian fissure to the cortex.
  • The cortical branches supply the primary motor and somatosensory areas of the face, trunk, and upper limbs, apart from the insular and auditory cortex.
  • The small central branches give rise to the lenticulostriate vessels, which irrigate the basal ganglia and the internal capsule.
  • The superior division irrigates the lateral inferior frontal lobe, which includes Broca’s area responsible for speech production, language comprehension, and writing.
  • The inferior division of the MCA irrigates the superior temporal gyrus, which involves Wernicke’s area, which is responsible for speech comprehension and language development. It also supplies blood to Meyer’s loop in the temporal lobe, which is the anterior extension of the optic radiation in the temporal horn.
  • Infarction of inferior division causes:​​​​​​
    • Superior quadrantanopia/homonymous hemianopia
    • Left-sided lesion: Wernicke’s aphasia
    • Right-sided lesion: Left-sided visual neglect

Option B: M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery – superior division

  • Lesion of the superior division causes: 
  • Sensorimotor deficit of the face and arm (the leg is less affected, and the foot is spared).
  • Ipsilateral deviation of the eyes or head
  • Initially, global aphasia was followed by motor aphasia in the left-sided lesion (no impairment of alertness).

Option C: Middle cerebral artery stem

  • A lesion or occlusion of the middle cerebral artery at the stem results in:
    • Contralateral hemiplegia affects the face, arm, and leg.
    • ​​​​​​​Homonymous hemianopia
    • If on the left side: global aphasia.

Option D: M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery

  • The stem is the proximal part of M1.
  • Therefore, an occlusion at this point will have the same effect, including contralateral hemiplegia and homonymous hemianopia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presenting with left upper back pain radiating to the left arm, worsened by exercise/activity, and a history of previous treatment with painkillers alone, a Chest X-Ray reveals a mass in the apex of the left lung, suggesting a Pancoast tumor. What symptoms might be associated with this condition?

choices.text: Loss of sweating on the same side of the face

questions.solution:
Option D: Loss of sweating on the same side of the face

The tumour most likely mentioned is apical lung cancer/ Pancoast tumour. It causes:

  • 2° neuron injury (Preganglionic sympathetic fibres).
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome (Cervical sympathetic chain and ganglion involved).
  • Loss of sweating on the same side of the face.
  • A Pancoast tumour is a rare form of lung cancer. This tumour is usually located at the right or left lung's top (apex). As the tumour grows, it can invade the nearest nerves, muscles, lymph nodes, connective tissue, upper ribs, and upper vertebrae. This tumour can cause severe pain in the shoulder and arm.
  • Diagnosis of Pancoast tumours is often missed or delayed because the tumour doesn't have any classic symptoms of lung cancer, such as a cough.
  • Pancoast tumours are also known as superior sulcus tumours. Their particular set of symptoms is called the Pancoast syndrome. Men are more frequently source affected than women. The cancer cell subtypes of Pancoast tumours are:
  1. Squamous cell cancer.
  2. Adenocarcinomas.
  3. Large-cell carcinomas.
  4. Small cell carcinomas.

Option A: Contralateral Horner syndrome

  • Apical lung cancer/ Pancoast tumour causes ipsilateral Horner syndrome (not C/L)Horner syndrome(cervical sympathetic chain and ganglion involved).

Option B: Postganglionic fibres involved

  • 2° sympathetic neuron (preganglionic fibres) injury occurs in apical lung cancer.

Option C: 1° neuron injury

  • 1° sympathetic neuron injury occurs in Wallenberg syndrome
  • 2° sympathetic neuron (preganglionic fibers) injury occurs in Apical lung cancer

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents in the outpatient department with primary infertility undervaluation for the presence or absence of ovulation. The gynaecologist did a physical examination and found no abnormality. She undergoes ultrasound, endometrial biopsy, and cervical mucous microscopy. Which of the following findings is suggestive that ovulation has taken place?

choices.text: Presence of Spinnbarkeit phenomenon in cervical mucous
Sudden reduction in the size of the follicle and free fluid in the pouch of Douglas on USG.

questions.solution:
Option C: Sudden reduction in the size of the follicle and free fluid in the pouch of Douglas on USG.

  • Ultrasound shows a sudden reduction of follicle size (on serial USG) and free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. Endometrial thickness varies as follows.
  • Early proliferative: Thin bright echogenic stripe.
  • Late proliferative: Trilaminar appearance.
  • Secretory phase: Thick and uniformly echogenic.
  • On a serial transvaginal USG, which is done from day 9, one can follow the growth of a dominant follicle till, eventually, it ruptures, which appears as sudden shrinkage in the size of a follicle that is earlier increasing in size.
  • Endometrium shows a trilaminar appearance just before ovulation, which becomes uniformly thick and echogenic after ovulation.

Option A: Pseudostratification in the endometrium

Endometrial biopsy

  • Proliferative endometrium: Shows pseudo stratification and long tubular glands.
  • Early secretory:
    • Subnuclear vacuolation is the first HPE evidence of progesterone secretion, seen on D16 of the cycle.
    • There is the upward displacement of the nuclei of glands along with stromal oedema.
  • Late secretory:
    • Shows tortuous/coiled glands with secretions in the lumen of the gland.
    • Later glands become corkscrew appearing (on D20 of the cycle).
    • Max stromal oedema is seen around D22 of the cycle.

Option B: Presence of Spinnbarkeit phenomenon in cervical mucous

Spinnbarkeit effect

  • Ovulation mucus has the property of great elasticity and will withstand stretching up to 10 cm. 
  • This phenomenon is called spinnbarkeit or the thread test for estrogen activity.
  • During the secretory phase, the cervical mucus becomes tenacious, and its viscosity increases under the influence of progesterone so that it loses the property of spinnbarkeit and fractures when put under tension.
  • This property is called tack. This loss of spinnbarkeit effect is used to diagnose ovulation retrospectively.

Option D: Trilamilar endometrium on USG

Trilaminar endometrium is seen in late proliferative phase and is thus not suggestive of ovulation. Endometrial thickness varies as follows;

  • Early proliferative: Thin bright echogenic stripe.
  • Late proliferative: Trilaminar appearance.
  • Secretory phase: Thick and uniformly echogenic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency at 32 weeks of gestation complaining of nausea and dull right flank pain for 2 days. On examination, her temperature is 100°F, PR is 96/min, and BP is 120/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows uterus midway between the xiphoid and umbilicus with FHTs at 148/min. Urinalysis reveals 50 to 100 WBCs/high power field. WBC is 18,800. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pyelonephritis

  • This patient with right flank pain, fever and high WBC count likely has acute pyelonephritis.
  • Pyelonephritis in pregnancy may occur due to untreated or inadequately treated UTI or asymptomatic bacteriuria.

 

Option A: Duodenal ulcer

  • It presents with epigastric pain that resolves after taking a meal. There will not be any pain in the flank.
  • Urinalysis will be normal in case of duodenal ulcer.

Option B: Volvulus

  • It presents with abdominal pain, constipation and vomiting.
  • Urinalysis will be normal in case of volvulus.

Option C: Placental abruption

  • It presents with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding and abnormal fetal heart rate.
  • There are no features of placental abruption in this patient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who is being treated for infertility gets ovulation induction with clomiphene and Inj. hCG. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension, pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasonogram reveals subclinical ascites. The next step in management should be?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Option A: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record, and fluid balance

  • The patient has a history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of Inj: hCG, which makes her a provisional diagnosis. A case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS and no symptoms of severity such as difficulty in breathing or coagulopathy, so the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, weigh herself daily, and monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and urinary output.
  • Mild OHSS is a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Hospitalize, input-output charting and iv fluid administration

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with:

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

 

Option C: Hospitalize, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

  • Hospitalization is done for more severe forms of OHSS with the abovementioned indications.
  • Albumin infusion is required in a patient with low serum protein values with excess extravascular fluid loss.

Option D: Paracentesis

  • Paracentesis is required in tense ascites causing excessive abdominal distension or causing respiratory distress.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents in the gynecologic OPD with her mother with the complaint of not getting her menses. Her mother says she is worried because all the girls in her school have started getting their periods regularly. On examination, breast development is normal, axillary and pubic hairs are sparse, and the vaginal opening is small and ends in a blind pouch. USG revealed an absent uterus and solid nodular structures in bilateral inguinal regions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • The ultrasound findings suggest the presence of testes, along with the sparsity of axillary and pubic hair, androgen insensitivity syndrome is the most probable diagnosis in the above case.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a disorder in which the individual has a male genotype and female phenotype.
  • Testes and testosterone are present, but receptor dysfunction leads to the development of female sexual characteristics.
  • It has 3 categories depending on the degree of genital masculinisation:
    • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS)
    • Mild androgen insensitivity syndrome (MAIS)
    • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS)
  • Management is symptomatic by hormone replacement therapy, genitoplasty, and genetic and psychological counselling.
  • Gonadectomy is indicated to reduce the risk of testicular neoplasm.

 

Option B: MRKH

  • Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser Syndrome (MRKH) is a Mullerian agenesis syndrome. It is XX genotype but does not have Mullerian components such as the uterus and upper vagina. But it has normal ovarian function, and normal ovaries can be visualised on ultrasound.
  •   MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
    Genotype XX XY
    Gonad Ovaries Testes
    Breast development Normal Normal
    Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
    Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
    Uterus Absent Absent
    Vulva Normal Normal

 

Option C: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome is an XO genotype with an abnormal female phenotype, i.e., ovaries, breasts, and uterus are all underdeveloped.

 

Option D: Pure gonadal dysgenesis

  • These patients have a female phenotype, and the genotype can be XX or XY. The individual fails to develop secondary sexual characteristics and presents clinically with primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the PHC centre with complaints of loose watery stools and vomiting for 1 day. On examination, the child was dehydrated and had a fever. Which of the following can be the most common cause of this child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rotavirus

  • It is the most common and the leading cause of watery diarrhea in children aged <5 years globally.
  • In developing countries, 3/4th of children acquire their first episode of rotavirus diarrhea before the age of 12 months.
  • Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is largely limited to children aged 6-24 months.
  • Transmits by fecal-oral route / indirectly by contaminated fomites.

Option A: E. coli

  • Both industrialized and developing nations have experienced outbreaks of waterborne and foodborne illnesses brought on by novel species like cryptosporidium or novel bacterial strains like Escherichia coli. The E. coli O157:H7 strain was first discovered in 1982 and has subsequently been linked to numerous serious outbreaks of diarrheal disease, occasionally resulting in renal failure.
  • Undercooked hamburger beef and unpasteurized milk have also been associated with the strain. 

Option C: Shigella

Symptomatic differential diagnosis of shigella and cholera

Symptoms Cholera Shigella
Diarrhea Acute watery diarrhea Acute bloody diarrhea
Fever No Yes
Abdominal cramps Yes Yes
Vomiting Yes No
Rectal pain No Yes
Stool >3 loose stools per day, watery like rice water >3 stools per day, with blood or pus

 

Option D: Malnutrition

  • When the body lacks the vitamins, minerals, and other nutrients necessary to maintain healthy tissues and organ function, malnutrition sets in.
  • People who are either undernourished or overnourished can develop malnutrition.

questions.text: A male baby was born at term to an O-negative mother with Coombs positive at delivery. The baby weighed 3 kg at birth; hemoglobin is 16 g/dL, and TSB is 5 mg/dL. He passed black stools within the first 24 hours of life, and his temperature was 97.7°F. After 5 days, the infant's weight was reduced by 60 grams, his axillary temperature was decreased to 95°F, and he was jaundiced up to the chest. Parents also told about the yellow, seedy stool. Lab investigations show that hemoglobin is now 14.4 g/dL, and his TSB is 14 mg/dL. The change in which of the following parameters is of most concern to a pediatrician?
questions.solution:
Option B: Temperature

  • The patient, in this case, has a low body temperature which is 95°F, a normal haemoglobin level and a TSB level at its peak level.
  • All the findings in this patient are normal except for low body temperature.
  • In a normal infant, the temperature should not change.
  • The normal temperature of infants at birth is 97.52°F.
  • Temperature instability in a term infant is frequently a sign of severe infection.
  • Common causes of low body temperature
    • Cold weather
    • Prolonged periods in water
    • Not drying the baby after the bath
  • Low body temperature may be more dangerous for babies of low birth weight.
  • Clinical features of low body temperature
    • Develop blue lips and fingers
    • Feel very cold
    • Act lethargic or sick
  • A body weight loss of 1.5% to 2% per day initially in a normal newborn infant as excessive fluid is excreted.

Option A: Hemoglobin

  • The normal haemoglobin level in infants at birth is 15g/dL.
  • The hematocrit falls as an adaptation to an environment of higher oxygen.

Option D: Stool

  • Infants usually have several meconium stools during the first day or two of life.
  • Changing to soft yellow stools after 1 to 2 days of life is normal.

Option C: Bilirubin

  • Normal total serum bilirubin level at birth is 1-3mg/dL, peaks at about 5-15 days, and declines by week 3.
  • As the hematocrit falls, there is a corresponding increase in serum bilirubin that peaks around 3 to 5 days of life.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of headache and dizziness from last 2 days. She has an infection of a cranial dural sinus that lies in the margin of the tentorium cerebelli and runs from the posterior end of the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus. Which of the following sinuses is affected by inflammation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Superior petrosal sinuses

  • The superior petrosal sinus is one of the types of dural venous sinuses situated beneath the brain.
  • It receives the vascular supply from the cavernous sinus and passes backward and laterally to drain into the transverse sinus.
  • The sinus receives superior petrosal veins, cerebellar veins, inferior cerebral veins, and veins from the tympanic cavity.
  • They may be affected by an arteriovenous fistula or arteriovenous malformation, usually treated with surgery.

  • The patient in question has meningitis (inflammation of the meninges), which causes headaches and dizziness.
  • The superior petrosal sinus runs from the posterior end of the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus along the attached edge of the tentorium cerebelli.
  • So, the sinus affected in the above-given question is the Superior petrosal sinuses.

Option B: Inferior sagittal sinus

  • The inferior sagittal is an area beneath the brain that helps blood drain posteriorly from the center of the head.
  • It drains to the straight sinus, which connects to the transverse sinuses.
  • The inferior sagittal sinus courses along the inferior border of the falx cerebri, superior to the corpus callosum.
  • It receives the blood supply from the deep and medial aspects of the cerebral hemispheres and drains into the straight sinus.
  • Falx cerebri is a dural structure that Separates the right and left cerebrum.

Option C: Sphenoparietal sinus

  • The sphenoparietal sinus is a paired dural venous sinus drains blood from the brain.
  • It drains the superficial middle cerebral vein, frontal ramus of a middle meningeal vein, and anterior temporal diploic vein to the cavernous sinus.
  • The sphenoparietal sinus passes along the sphenoidal ridge of the sphenoid bone between the anterior and middle cranial fossa.
  • Spheno-parietal sinus lies along the posterior edge of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone.
  • The cavernous sinus is present on each side of the sella turcica and the body of the sphenoid bone.

Option D: Straight sinuses

  • The straight sinus, also known as the tentorial sinus or the sinus rectus, is an area within the skull beneath the brain.
  • It receives blood from the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein and drains into the confluence of sinuses.
  • Straight sinus runs along the line of attachment of falx cerebri to tentorium cerebelli.
  • Falx cerebri is a dural structure that Separates the right and left cerebrum.
  • Tentorium cerebelli is an extension of the dura mater that separates the cerebrum from the cerebellum and the Brainstem.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the outpatient department with her mother, complaining that her daughter has not yet menstruated. There is no history of delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics. There is no history of anxiety or mood swings. On examination, there is normal breast development and pubic hair growth. Which of the following best describes the normal sequence of pubertal changes in the female?

choices.text: Peak growth velocity, menarche, thelarche, pubarche
Pubarche, peak growth velocity, thelarche, menarche
Thelarche, peak growth velocity, pubarche, menarche
Thelarche, pubarche, peak growth velocity, menarche

questions.solution:
Option D: Thelarche, pubarche, peak growth velocity, menarche

  • The pubertal development in girls typically takes place over 4.5 years.
  • Sex steroid production during puberty stimulates the development of secondary sex characteristics growth of long bones, which is the reason for a vertical growth spurt.
  • Accelerated growth is the first sign of puberty, and the first recognized pubertal change is breast budding, then, later on, the appearance of pubic hair, peak growth velocity, and menarche.

Delayed or interrupted puberty

  • No periods or any secondary sex characteristics by age 13, have secondary sexual characteristics but not had menarche by age 15 or have not started menarche 5 or more years since the onset of pubertal development.
  • The overall first event in puberty is accelerated general growth.
  • The first specific sign of puberty is breast budding.

Option A: Peak growth velocity, menarche, thelarche, pubarche

  • The first visible sign of puberty is thelarche, not peak growth velocity.
  • The correct sequence of puberty changes is the thelarche, pubarche, peak growth velocity, and menarche.

Option B: Pubarche, peak growth velocity, thelarche, menarche

  • The pubarche is not the first visible sign of puberty.
  • The first visible sign of puberty is thelarche.

Option C: Thelarche, peak growth velocity, pubarche, menarche

  • Thelarche is the first visible sign of puberty, but the second visible sign is pubarche, not peak growth velocity.
  • The puberty-specific event which comes in first is thelarche & then pubarche, peak growth velocity and menarche.

questions.text: A woman, 30 years of age P1L1 calls up her gynecologist to inform that she had intercourse the previous night and is doubtful whether the ejaculation was inside or outside the vagina. The couple has been practicing coitus interruptus for purpose of contraception. She does not want pregnancy. She has a strip of MALA d tablets with her and wants to know if she can use it now. The doctor should tell her that she should :

choices.text: Take 4 tablets stat and repeat after 12 hours
Start the strip now and take one tablet each day for 21 days
Wait for periods and follow up only if she is pregnant

questions.solution:
Option A: Take 4 tablets stat and repeat after 12 hours

  • In this case, the patient presents with unprotected intercourse and wants advice regarding emergency contraception.
  • The Mala-D tablets consist of levonorgestrel and ethinyloestradiol, an emergency contraceptive that can be used in this case.
  • The patient wants contraception within 72 hours of intercourse. Any drug regime for emergency contraception can be used.

Emergency contraceptives

  • IUCD: Can prevent implantation up till the 5th day of unprotected intercourse  
  • Progesterone-only pill: LNG 1.5 mg: can reduce tubal motility and make endometrium 'Out of Phase" for embryo implantation.
  • Combined pill: The Yuzpe regimen can prevent embryo implantation since the estrogen component makes the endometrium unreceptive.
  • Mifepristone, antiprogestin and RU 486 prevent implantation.
  • Ulipristal acetate: SPRM: Selective progesterone receptor modulator
  • OCP containing 50 mcg of EE, used as an emergency contraceptive; the dose is 2 tablets stat (as soon as possible within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse) and repeats after 12 hours.
  • However, the content of Mala-D is 30 mcg of EE. Therefore a double dose is recommended, that is, 4 tablets stat and 4 after 12 hours. The total dose of EE required here is 200 mcg.

 

Option B: Start the strip now and take one tablet each day for 21 days

  • OCPs must be started from day 1 to day 5 of each cycle and taken without a break regularly to prevent pregnancy.
  • Here the day of cycle is not mentioned hence routine way of taking OCPs cannot surely prevent a pregnancy and emergency contraception is indicated as intercourse has already happened.

 

Option C: Take mifepristone + misoprostol

  • It is an incorrect option because these drugs are used to cause an early abortion and not contraception.

 

Option D: Wait for periods and follow up only if she is pregnant

  • The patient should not be advised to wait for periods as pregnancy can occur as the method of coitus interruptus appears to have failed here.
  • The patient should have emergency contraceptives within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: The professor of oncology instructs the medical residents to check the hematocrit levels regularly for all the patients undergoing chemotherapy with a specific new drug as part of their research. These labs are done to monitor the effect of chemotherapy on bone marrow. The hematocrit test measures the volume percentage of red cells in the blood. Its value varies according to age, sex, race, and lifestyle factors. Men normally tend to have higher levels than females. Which of the following reasons explains this gender variation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Menstrual blood loss

  • Women of reproductive age lose blood monthly through menstruation, lowering the red blood cells. Hence this causes a decrease in hematocrit and red blood cell mass.
  • Women lack the androgens needed for the stimulation of erythropoietin.
  • The higher RBC counts in men result from higher levels of androgens that stimulate erythropoietin in the kidney, which then causes red blood cell production from the marrow.
  • Women typically have more fat than men, and the higher the body fat content, the lower the hematocrit level.
  • The hematocrit test measures the percentage of red cells in total blood volume. It is also known as the packed cell volume (PCV) test. It measures the capability of red cells to carry oxygen throughout the body.  
  • A lower than normal hematocrit indicates anemia, infection, or white blood cell disorders such as leukemia and lymphoma, vitamin or mineral deficiencies, and long-term blood loss.
  • A higher than normal hematocrit indicates dehydration, polycythemia vera, lung, or heart disease.
  • Normal hematocrit ranges vary with age, race, gender, and lifestyle factors.
  • Some factors that can lead to inaccurate hematocrit values are pregnancy, living at a high altitude, recent blood transfusion, and severe dehydration.

Option A: Low erythropoietin

  • Erythropoietin is a glycoprotein produced by the peritubular cells of the kidney in response to tissue hypoxia. It then further stimulates the proerythroblasts in the bone marrow to mature and produce red blood cells until oxygen levels return to normal.
  • If the erythropoietin levels are low, it is mainly due to a kidney disorder or anemia resulting from decreased red cell production. Hence it is not responsible for the gender variation in hematocrit levels.

Option C: High estrogen

  • Estrogen does not affect the hematocrit values in women. However, testosterone can stimulate red blood cell production in males. However, it is unknown whether circulating estrogen (sex steroid hormone) can affect hematocrit.
  • However, high estrogen levels in women can risk developing breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancer. It also puts an increased risk of stroke and blood clots.

Option D: Low stem cells

  • Stem cells needed for blood cell production are called pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells. They are present in the bone marrow. Various growth factors induce its stimulation in low O2 states to activate the precursors of red blood cells.
  • Low stem cells are due to bone marrow disorders and result in decreased production of blood cell progenitors. However, their levels are independent of any gender variation.

questions.text: 30-year-old patient presented with chief complaints of disturbed night-time sleep,excessive sleep at day time , and is unable to resist sleep attacks at day time he is also having vivid perceptions, usually dream-like, which occur before the onset of sleep and before awakening, These symptoms are due to abnormality in which of the following areas of the brain?
questions.solution: The patient is having Hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucinations along with disturbed night time sleep and excessive day time sleep is having narcolepsy.Patients with narcolepsy are deficient in the neurotransmitter hypocretin which is secreted from the Hypothalamic neurons , which stimulates appetite and alertness.It is found that the number of hypocretin neurons (Hrct cells) in narcoleptics is 85 to 95 percent lower than in non narcoleptic brains .So Hypothalamus is the region of the brain involved in narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents in the cardiology emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain radiating towards the left arm and exertional dyspnea from the last 4 hours. The attending doctor, after examination, labelled him as a patient of triple vessel disease and advised him to CABG surgery. After surgery, the doctor prescribed him medicine and advised him to use a disinfectant at home for some time. That disinfectant is shown below in the image. What is the disinfectant used to disinfect?
questions.solution:
Option B: Air

  • The patient discussed above is a known case of triple vessel disease for which he underwent CABG surgery. Now he is advised to use a HEPA filter in his room.
  • The given image is HEPA (high-efficiency particulate air) filter.
  • HEPA (high-efficiency particulate air) filter removes microorganisms from the air.
  • HEPA filter traps airborne particles and microbes.
  • It can remove > 95% of all particles, including microorganisms with a diameter > 0.3 p.m.
  • HEPA is a type of mechanical air filter.
  • This air filter can remove at least 99.97% of pollen, dust, mould, bacteria, and any airborne particles with a size of 0.3 microns.
  • The diameter requirement of 0.3 microns responds to the severe case:
  • The most penetrating particle size.
  • Particles that are larger or smaller are trapped with even higher efficiency.

Principles of filtration

  • A HEPA (high efficiency particulate air) filter with an H13 Classification has an overall filter efficiency of 99.95 according to EN1822.
  • The filter penetration should therefore not exceed 0.05%
  • 99.95% + 0.05% = 100%

 

 

 

Option A: Water

  • It is disinfected with chlorine and chlorine-containing compounds. HEPA is not used for the filtration of water.

Option C: Culture

  • In medicine, culture refers to the growth of microorganisms, such as bacteria and yeast, human, plant, animal cells or tissue in laboratory conditions.
  • It is disinfected by autoclaving, thermal washing, radiational washing etc.

Option D: Blood

  • There are 3 types of blood cells – red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
  • It is disinfected in several ways, like physical, ultrasonically, thermal washing,  and many other methods.

questions.text: A 32-years-old male is brought to the emergency after a road traffic accident. He is disoriented. His vitals are as follows; SpO2 84% at room air, blood pressure 100/70 mmHg and pulse 61/min. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the right lung. After initial resuscitation, an airway, as shown in the picture, is passed. The advantage of the given below airway device is?

choices.text: Prevents fall back of tongue post-extubation, can be used in awake patients

questions.solution:
Option A: Prevents fall back of tongue post-extubation, can be used in awake patients

  • A nasopharyngeal airway is passed to secure the airway and prevent the fall back of the tongue. 
  • Advantages of nasopharyngeal airway
    • It is made up of soft silicon.
    • Size is determined → from the tip of the nose or nostril to the ear lobe.
    • Insertion: - we insert it through the nasal cavity bevel facing the septum.
    • It is a comfortable device.-It can be inserted in a conscious or semi conscious patient
  • Disadvantage
    • Epistaxis
    • Gagging, vomiting, aspiration
    • Intracranial insertion
    • Failure of the airway due to obstruction
    • Ulceration with long-term use
  • Contraindication
    • The base of the skull fracture
    • Coagulopathy

Option B: Prevents gagging, vomiting and aspiration

  • The nasopharyngeal airway can cause:
    • Gagging
    • Vomiting
    • Aspiration

Option C: Prevents tongue bite.

  • The nasopharyngeal airway does not prevent tongue bites.
  • It is passed via the nose to prevent the fall back of the tongue in conscious patients.

Option D: Safe in patients on warfarin

  • The nasopharyngeal airway can cause epistaxis.
  • Patients who are on warfarin airway should be placed in a very gentle way.
  • Trauma to the nose can cause bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents in the ENT outpatient department with complaints of thin painless fluid discharge from the ears. On physical examination, the patient has a blood pressure of 126/82 mmHg with a pulse of 93/min. A CBC of the patient comes with mild leukocytosis of lymphocytes. On otoscopic examination of the ear, the patient has multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane and failure to respond to antimicrobial treatment. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis

  • Tubercular otitis media is characterized by thin, painless otorrhoea, many perforations of the tympanic membrane, and an inability to react to antimicrobial therapy. It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Tubercular otitis media:

Etiology:

  • In most cases, infection is secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis; infection reaches the middle ear through the eustachian tube. Sometimes, it is blood-borne from tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. The disease is mostly seen in children and young adults.

Pathology:

  • The process is slow and insidious.
  • Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of the middle ear cleft and caseate.
  • There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane.
  • Multiple perforations may form, which coalesce to form a single large perforation.
  • The middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Caries of bone and ossicles may occur, leading to complications.
  • Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with the formation of bony sequestra, and profound hearing loss are often seen in these cases.

Clinical Features:

  1. Painless ear discharge: Earache is characteristically absent in cases of tubercular otitis media. Discharge is often foul-smelling because of underlying bone destruction.
  2. Perforation: Multiple perforations, two or three in number, are seen in pars tensa and form a classical sign of disease. These may coalesce into a single large perforation, becoming indistinguishable from nonspecific CSOM (chronic suppurative otitis media).
  3. Hearing loss: There is severe hearing loss, out of proportion to symptoms. Mostly conductive, it may have a sensorineural component labyrinth.

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Acute suppurative otitis media can be caused by Staph Aureus. And it can go through the stage of tubal occlusion, the stage of presuppuration. Stage of suppuration where the earache becomes excruciating.

Option C: Candida albicans

  • Candida albicans is a fungal infection; it affects immuno-compromised patients most of the time; it can cause oral candidiasis or esophageal, which can be treated with oral fluconazole.

Option D: Aspergillus Fumigatus

  • Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger, A. Fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is seen in the hot and humid climates of tropical and subtropical countries.
  • Secondary fungal growth is also seen in patients using topical antibiotics for the treatment of otitis externa or middle ear suppuration.
  • The clinical features of otomycosis include intense itching, discomfort or pain in the ear, watery discharge with a musty odor, and ear blockage. The fungal mass may appear white, brown, or black and has been likened to a wet piece of filter paper.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to your clinic with complaints of headache and runny nose for the last 4 days. The patient gives a history of worsening symptoms during summer while playing outside. On examination, you found the features depicted below in the image. Which of the following will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allergic Rhinosinusitis

  • The above clinical features are seen in allergic rhinosinusitis
  • The image depicted explains Dennie morgan's folds
  • Most common allergen- House dust mite/ carpet dust
  • Most common in urban areas & developed countries.
  • Most common in snow-covered area Symptoms® Intermittent < 4 days/ week or < 4 weeks®
  • Persistent > 4 days /week or < 4 weeks
  • On examination
    • Atopic facies
    • Dennie Morgan lines
    • Nasal crease/ allergic salute
  • On Nasal examination: Mucoid secretion in the nasal cavity, the Mulberry appearance of the nasal mucosa. The nasal mucosa is hypertrophied
  • Treatment Steroids (Intranasal spray)

Option B: Vasomotor Rhinosinusitis

  • Results from changes in vascular tone and permeability: Stimulation of afferent sensory nerves is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism, and it activates the parasympathetic nerves that supply the nasal mucosal glands
  • Symptoms include clear watery rhinorrhea and occasionally sweating/epiphora.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option C: Atrophic Rhinosinusitis

  • Causes include aggressive turbinectomy, excessive nasal surgery, nutritional deficiencies (iron or vitamin A or D deficiency), chronic bacterial infection (e.g., Klebsiella ozaena, less common in the antibiotic era), trauma, manifestations of granulomatous diseases, chronic cocaine abuse, and radiation therapy
  • Symptoms include paradoxical nasal congestion/obstruction despite a wide nasal cavity, nasal crusting, and odor.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option D: Rhinitis Medicamentosa

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa (RM), also known as rebound rhinitis, is a condition characterized by nasal congestion that is triggered by the overuse of topical vasoconstrictive medications, most notably intranasal decongestants; recreational use of intranasal cocaine may also cause a similar condition.
