  • Underlying reasons for intranasal decongestant use can usually be identified, such as allergic or nonallergic rhinitis, acute or chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyps, night-time use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • With regular daily use, some patients may develop rhinitis medicamentosa in 3 days, whereas others may not have evidence of rebound congestion after 4 to 6 weeks of use.
  • Management of rhinitis medicamentosa is focused on withdrawal of intranasal decongestants and treatment of congestion and underlying conditions with appropriate interventions.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

questions.text: A 60-years-old male who is a chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath. Underwent initial investigation. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, mainly in the lower lobes and shows mild, localised areas of fibrosis causing a reticular pattern. The patient's histology is given below; which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: DIP (desquamative interstitial pneumonia )

  • History of smoking and chest X-ray finding of the patient's lower lobe affected reticulate pattern points towards the diagnosis of the ILD
  • The histology image shown above shows the accumulation of a large number of macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smokers macrophages ) in the airspace's → DIP (desquamative interstitial pneumonia )
  • DIP has a good prognosis and excellent response to steroids and smoking cessation.

Other options

Option A:  UIP ( usual interstitial pneumonia )

  • Microscopy shows→ Patchy scarring and subpleural fibrosis with extensive areas of honeycomb cystic change seen.

 

Option C: NSIP (non-specific interstitial pneumonia )

  • The fibrosing pattern consists of diffuse or patchy interstitial fibrotic lesions of roughly the same stage of development, an important distinction from UIP (usual interstitial pneumonia).
  • Fibroblastic foci, honeycombing, hyaline membranes and granulomas are absent.

 

Option D: Asthma

  • Chest X-ray in asthma will show hyperinflated lung fields and flattening of diaphragm
  • Microscopic findings in asthma include epithelial detachment, mucus gland hyperplasia, subepithelial fibrosis, and inflammatory cell infiltrate.

questions.text: A 60-years-old male presented to the medicine OPD with the gradual onset of a nonproductive cough and progressive dyspnea. On examination, crackles are heard during inspiration. X-RAY findings are subpleural, and bibasilar fibrosis and reticular abnormalities are seen. The histologic image is given below. Which of the following is true about idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?

choices.text: Females are affected more than males
Nintedanib and Pirfenidone drugs approved for use in IPF

questions.solution:
Option C:  Nintedanib and Pirfenidone drugs approved for use in IPF

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis characterised by recurrent alveolar epithelial injury
  • Smoking is most important etiologic factor
  • Seen in patients more than 50 years
  • Males are affected more than females
  • It is also associated with altered activity of surfactant
  • Nintedanib and Pirfenidone drugs approved for use in IPF
  • Overall prognosis is poor
  • Treatment → Lung transplantation is the only definitive therapy

Option A: Females are affected more than males

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is more common in males

Option B: Age less than 20 years

  • Typical age for the onset of IPF is after the age of 50

Option D: Lobectomy is only definitive treatment

  • Lobectomy is not indicated in IPF
  • Only definitive treatment is lung transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely, if a child has a disorder of fatty acid oxidation?

choices.text: Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids
Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances
Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine
Hepatomegaly, elevated serum liver enzymes, and elevated tyrosine

questions.solution:
Option A: Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids.

  • The symptoms of any birth associated metabolic disease often begins after the first few feedings, when the baby is exposed to nutrients that cannot be metabolized and are toxic. Often there are misguided attempts to encourage feeding, which further poison the child. Inborn errors of carbohydrate, amino acid, or organic/fatty acid metabolism can present in the newborn period. They are characterized by a similar pattern of symptoms that include spitting up, vomiting, exaggeration of the usual physiologic jaundice, lethargy progressing to coma, hypoglycemia, acidosis, hyperammonemia, and, in the case of maple syrup or isovaleric acidemia, unusual odors
  • Disorders of fatty acid oxidation worsen during fasting to cause carnitine depletion, failure of fatty acid oxidation, and excretion of dicarboxylic acid intermediates. Deficiencies in medium-chain fatty acid oxidation are milder and may present after a period of illness with calorie deprivation in children aged 2 to 6 years.

Option B: Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances

  • Galactosemia worsens on exposure to lactose-containing formula, producing hypoglycemia, liver failure, and excretion of urinary sugars (reducing substances).

Option C and E: Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine and Hepatomegaly, elevated serum liver enzymes, and elevated tyrosine

  • Tyrosinemia and maple syrup urine disease are amino acid disorders that worsen after protein feeding and produce elevated levels of tyrosine or branch-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). Tyrosinemia is associated with severe liver failure and maple syrup urine disease with severe acidosis due to conversion of excess amino acids to ketoacids.

Option D: Alkalosis and elevated serum ammonia

  • Urea cycle disorders worsen during fasting (catabolic breakdown) or protein feeding, producing excess ammonia, rapid breathing, and respiratory alkalosis.​​​​​​

questions.text:
A PhD researcher is studying the mechanisms of generation of mutations in beta-Covid strains of coronavirus. For this investigation the scientist needs to use a technique by which he can amplify the sequence of DNA shown below:
5' GCTAATGAT ------------ ATATGGCTA 3'
He decides to use polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to do so. Which of the following would be the most appropriate DNA primer to use for this cycle of PCR?
questions.solution:
For a Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), two primers are required, one that binds to the strand shown in the above image (i.e. the coding strand) and a second that binds to its complementary strand (i.e. the noncoding strand). The primer of the coding strand is complementary to its 3' end. The primer to the noncoding strand is identical to the coding strand's 5' end. To summarize, in order to copy a segment of DNA via PCR, a complementary primer to the 3' end is required along with a reversed copy of the 5' end.

To design the primers for this strand, the following steps are performed:

  • Determine the complementary strand to the one displayed, which will be: 3' CGATTACTA -------- TATACCGAT 5'
  • Determine the primer that will hybridize to the strand shown in the question, which will be starting from the 3' end of the original strand since the polymerase move in the 5'-3' direction. The primer will be 3 ' TATACCGAT, which is conventionally written as 5' TAGCCATAT 3', which is the first primer.
  • Determine the primer that will hybridize to the complementary strand in (step 1), and the primer will be 5' TAGTAATCG 3', which is the second primer.
